P
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:the pure form of the drug methamphetamine, aka ice etc.
Origin:abbreviation
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: abbreviation of 'pure'

Citations
Date: 24/4/2006
Source: Internet - see Notes
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote: On the street, methamphetamine has a range of nicknames including "speed", "pure", "P" "burn" "goey", "crank", "meth", "crystal", "ice" and "Ya Ba". It can be a powder, a crystal 'rock' like form, or a pill.The nickname "P" is unique to New Zealand.
Notes: http://police.govt.nz/safety/meth.htmlAccessed 08/11/2006

Date: 26/5/2006
Source: Dominion Post
Author:
Vol / Page: A1
Edition:
Quote: Authorities have seized $95 million worth of crystal methamphetamine - nearly enough to supply one million people with individual hits of the drug P.
Notes:

Author:
Vol / Page: 15
Edition:
Quote: "I've just got out of Mt Eden jail and 75 percent of the people in my yard there were in there for P or P-related offences."... What Dave and his jailmates want is Pure (P for short), which is the street name for pure uncut methamphetamine.
Notes:

Date: 3/5/2007

Author:
Vol / Page: A3
Edition:
Quote: "I understand it commonly happens in Rotorua. I haven't seen a dog on P, but I've heard about it from drug squad police at conferences." Though there was no suggestion the Manaia dogs were on P, an armed policewoman was on hand as they were cornered and loaded into a dog van.

Date: 19/6/2003
Source: Contact (Wgtn)
Author:
Vol / Page: 1
Edition:
Quote: Staff at Wellington Women's Refuge say a steady rise in violent crime over the past 18 months is linked with soaring use of P, or pure methamphetamine, among white, middle-aged men... Now we're seeing burglars being driven by the need to get money to feed their P habit... She was a full-blown addict by 25. P turned her into "God".
Notes:

Date: 22/9/2002
Source: Sunday Star Times
Author:
Vol / Page: A4
Edition:
Quote: The methamphetamine explosion has coincided with the appearance of a highly pure form of the drug, known on the streets as P. It is sold in crystalline form - like crack cocaine - and is 70%-80% pure... While powder speed is snorted, users heat P in the bottom of a glass pipe and inhale the smoke - a similar process to taking crack.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1925
Source: Random Recollections
Author: bath
Vol / Page: 17
Edition:
Quote: Thatcher, a witty singer of topical songs, seized upon the incident which he recounted at his next entertainment partly in recitative interspersed with songs, and in describing the incident in the bar told how another leading citizen approached the victim, and after the manner of Madam Escott warbled: Take this glass of nice P.B./ Which I now hold in my hand,/ Tis of the brand of Hennissy/ Taste this most superior brand/  The amount of drinking that went on in those days was very much greater than has been the case for very many years. Pale brandy or P.B. was the favourite spirit [in Dunedin, 1860s], and a sparkling moselle, which was dubbed champagne, was popular under the name of No. 2. There was even a bar on board the harbour steamer ... and I have heard No. 2 called for there on the way to Port Chalmers. ...
Notes:

pa
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number: 1
Definition:a fortified village, a fort; a tribal settlement usually fortified.
Origin:Maori
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:hold the pa
Pronunciation:
Notes: 	hold the pa		P.S. Ardern: Pah Road, Auckland) (see also compounds PAFUL)

Date: 0/0/1834
Source: New Zealand (various authors/titles)
Author: MARKHAM
Vol / Page: 29
Edition: 1963
Quote: At 3 pm came to an Anchor at Parkinneigh [Pakanae] a Village and had I suppose 150 Natives on board and a par [<i>pa</i>] or Fort about 12 miles from the Heads. <I>Ibid.</I> 33 Hattay [crossed out by Markham] or Ettay [<i>heti</i>] is a Tea tree, quite different to the Tea tree bush, a sort of myrtle; as Parr a Fort and Hipparr [<i>he pa</i>] a Fort in Cooke, / is put down The Hip or Hit, is only the Article. Tay, it is useless, it only grows eight to twelve feet and the bark rough, and does not change. It seems very often Solitary. Away from every other Tree.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1838
Source: Examination of John Guard
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote: Lesson gives a footnote of which the following is a translation: `Navigators write this word in a variety of ways. The English have adopted <i>hippa</i>, and some of the French write <i>pa</i>. I prefer<i> i-pah, which means THE PAH, as being more in keeping with the spirit of our language.</I>
Notes: 1838-1839 R.P. Lesson footnote in Voyage autour du monde sur la corvette La Coqille transl. Diana Quarmby in 1971 Duperrey's Visit to New Zealand in 1824 54

Date: 0/0/1898
Source: Austral English
Author: MORRIS
Vol / Page: 335
Edition:
Quote: <i>The former [pa] is now considered the more correct spelling. A Maori word to signify a native settlement, surrounded by a stockade; a</i> fort; a fighting village. In Maori, the verb pameans, to touch, to block up. <i>Pa </i>= a collection of houses to which access is blocked by means of stockades and ditches. 1769. `Captain Cook's Journal' (edition Wharton, 1893), p. 147: [and other quotations, incl. a long are from Thompson 1859].

Quote: <i>pa</i>, fortified or stockaded place; used as a place of retreat if danger threatened the ordinary dwelling-place, the kainga; by Cook and by others much later spelt pah to get the proper sound of Maori `a'; pah, pa, in O.E.D.

Date: 0/0/1946
Source: Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page: 55/148
Edition:
Quote: <i>pa</i> has not for many years been spelt pah in Newzealand: pah was Captain Cook's spelling, and was useful as indicating the long vowel, but is not correct Maori, and is not used in writing. [JCA no long v]
Notes: Andersen Maori Words in English

Date: 0/0/1963
Source: In the Sticks
Author: BACON
Vol / Page: 181
Edition:
Quote: <i>pa</i>-Loosely, a Maori village. Properly speaking, a pa was a fortified village; a kaianga was an everyday settlement. In time of war, the populace moved from the kainga to the shelter of the pa. When Tamu spoke of the newcomers in Chapter 14 as `Real pa Maori, eh?' his meaning was, `These are not civilised Maoris; they're real bush Maoris.'
Notes:

Notes:

pa
Homonym Number: 2
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a type of fish hook, couta stick
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1956
Source: NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author: GRAHAM
Vol / Page: 310
Edition:
Quote: BARRACOUTA (MANGA) <i>Leionura atun dentatus</i> (Bloch and Schneider) INCREDIBLE as it may seem these fish, with their well-armed jaws of sharp fang-like teeth, were usually caught on a slightly curved stick about four feet in length. Fastened to this stick was a piece of stout fishing line about three to four feet in length, carrying a piece of red-coloured wood - usually cedar - about five to six inches in length. A bent nail was secured to this piece of wood in the form of a hook but no bait was used. When a school of Barracouta was found the Couta stick, or paw, was brought out ready for fishing. From the cockpit of the launch the piece of wood with the nail was violently swirled with a circular motion in and out of the water, causing a disturbance of the water in a good imitation of a number of Sprats, Pilchards or other small fish jumping in and out of the sea. The Barracouta would swim for such a place. Seeing the piece of red wood moving rapidly through the water they would take it for a fish, snap at it or even jump out of the water for the lure and were caught by the crude iron hook. As the fish was hooked during the time the paw was being drawn through the water the fisherman would swing the fish over his head above the boat or launch and when the caught fish was midway in the air, more or less above the cockpit, would expertly give the stick a dexterous smart twist. As there was no barb on the hook the fish was released and fell into the cockpit. <i>Ibid.</i> 311 Should there be any Barracouta about the... Couta sticks were then set to work to paw the water and attract Barracouta to the spot. <i>Ibid.</i>  314 The Maori also knew he could catch Barracouta without bait and he, too, used a short piece of stick and line with a baitless hook and leaned over his canoe and threshed the water to and fro, which is known as `Kaihau manga!' When the European fisherman called his fishing outfit [315] `paw', the Maori uses the term `pa'. This fish was a great favourite with them and was caught in large numbers. On returning to the shore, the women cleaned the fish and then hung them up on racks to dry in the sun. Old Maoris of Opotiki told me they used a chip of Tawhai (<i>Nothofagus fusca</i>), which is dark red, in the making of a pa (paw).
Notes:

I'll tell you: it's like being shut up with a lot of big kids. They say; `That Opal, she's not a Maori now, she's got a hat and thinks she's a <i>pakeha'</i>.'

Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote: PACIFIC BENCH A wheeled travelling saw bench on which logs are help while it moves past a circular or band saw. It is fitted with knees which permit accurate sawing to thickness or width, and thus can be used for recutting as well as breaking down.

Citations
Date: 10/1/1988
Source: Dominion Sunday Times
Author:
Vol / Page: 14
Edition:
Quote: Corned beef and a frenetic game involving up to 200 a side, both curious legacies of the colonisation of the South Seas, are about to make the big time together. The game is krikiti, kirikiti or kilikiti which arrived in the Pacific well over a century ago in the more sedate form of English cricket. Now a couple of Aucklanders have taken the game that's more a social event than a sport, given it some formal rules, and come up with [dollars]100,000 to remould it under the new name of `Pacific Cricket'.

Date: 0/0/2006
Source: Internet - see Notes
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote: The Pacific gecko is nocturnal and feeds on vegetation or on insects, grubs and berries. By day they hide in cracks in clay banks, under stones or in cracks in tree trunks. Sometimes they are seen basking in the sun. Their colour and patterning are variable and they bear their young in the late summer.

Quote: <i>Blue mackerel Scomber autralasicus</i> ... An Indo-Pacific species ... Often simply called mackerel, from its close similarity to the common mackerel  (<i>Scomber scomber</i>) of the Northern Hemisphere ... In New Zealand it has often been called English mackerel and Pacific mackerel, but it is becoming more widely and appropriately known now as blue mackerel.

The Pacific oyster which has overtaken the rock oyster and is now widely known as 'rock oyster' tends to be much larger, milder and is often quite creamy in texture.

Date: 0/0/1883
Source: High Alps of NZ
Author: GREEN
Vol / Page: 178
Edition:
Quote:  ... as Southerland offered to take a pack for us as far as his horse could go, we quickly bundled together a number of articles in the waterproof sheet and started him off. 	<I>Ibid.</I> 180 The amount to be carried on our shoulders when put together appeared somewhat alarming ... Kauffmann gave a significant glance now and then, as he contemplated the packs, but neither he nor Boss ever grumbled, though they knew full well that the heaviest share of the `swagging' must fall to their lot. <I>Ibid.</I> 182 Some years before, when in Norway, I remember having carried a pack of twenty-two pounds across the Justedal Glaciers, and found it quite a sufficient load. <I>Ibid.</I> 183 As soon as breakfast was over B. ... started off with his knapsack for the Hooker ... Then we helped the packs onto each other's shoulders ...<I>Ibid.</I>  185 ]I then dragged my pack through the thorns ... to ease my shoulders I took off my knapsack ...
Notes:

Date: 0/9/1958
Source: Tararua
Author:
Vol / Page: 27
Edition:
Quote: Food and gear have to be carried. Everyone in New Zealand, almost everyone anyway, puts it in a <i>pack</i>, but probably no one stops to think that the word <i>pack</i> in this sense is not standard English. ... England since 1895 has borrowed <i>rucksack</i> from German dialect; New Zealand has preferred <i>pack</i>. Not that rucsac is not used here; it is noticeable that older Club members used it in several articles in early numbers of <i>Tararua</i>, and it still appears in advertisements. <i>Rucksack</i> seems a bit foreign, as is shown by the less correct but more foreign-looking spelling it is usually given. <i>Pack</i> as a synonym for <i>rucksack</i> is used in Australia to some extent at any rate. This sense of <i>pack</i> would most likely be in use long before it occurred in print. I remember having a home-made <i>pack</i> in Auckland in 1933.
Notes: Ruth Mason `Track and Trail'

Date: 0/9/1958
Source: Tararua
Author:
Vol / Page: 39
Edition:
Quote: With the following dawn two tigers stood by for a quick trip back to Maruia Springs while each pack was [40] searched and emptied.

Date: 0/0/1979

Vol / Page: 203
Edition:
Quote: His luggage [on his visit to Malvern] was contained in a simple, much-stained khaki rucksack that looked old enough to have been in his possession when he was a boy before World War 1. He always called it `the pack'; later in the visit it would be used to hold the food, raincoats, and everything else that we took with us on ... walks. <I>Ibid.</i> 204 Our routine was always the same. One of us would shoulder the pack and we would walk for half an hour.
Notes: (G. Sayer: `Jack on Holiday': 1950s) The quot. possibly represents C.S.L.'s personal usage influenced by soldiers' `pack', WWI.

paddock grazing
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number: 1
Definition:allocating an entire paddock for grazing for up to five days, with hay or silage added in the last 2-3 days.
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:Rural
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 1/6/2001
Source: Fencepost.com
Author:
Vol / Page: Expert Farming
Edition:
Quote: More recently, howver, the heavy labour requirement of this practice [block grazing] has been superseded by a modified system called paddock grazing. This is where up to 5 days pasture feed will be allocated in one hit (often meaning one complete paddock) with any hay or silage allocated usually being fed out in progressively larger amounts in the last 2-3 days. In minimising stress the paddock grazing was clearly superior.
Notes:

paddocking
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:working a gold bearing area by excavating a paddock
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:paddock (goldmining)
Pronunciation:
Notes: goldmining
Citations
Date: 0/0/1978
Source: Looking Back
Author: SINCLAIR & HARREX
Vol / Page: 75
Edition:
Quote: The method used to extract the gold from the gully was 'paddocking'. The top soil was removed off a section of the 'paddock' to expose the auriferous pay dirt.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1879
Source: NZ Tourist, The
Author: BRACKEN
Vol / Page: 24
Edition:
Quote: The operations of `paddocking' and `sluicing'
Notes:

Date: 0/4/1953
Source: NZ Geographer
Author:
Vol / Page: 29
Edition:
Quote: Workings [at Mount Ida, Otago, in 1871] were for the most part alluvial, the distinctive process used being `paddocking'. [fn] Paddocking was the systematic sluicing of large areas of flat ground from which the surface layers were first removed to reveal the `wash-dirt' beneath.
Notes:  (Kibblewhite)

Date: 0/0/1962
Source: Waikaka Saga
Author: EVANS
Vol / Page: 15
Edition:
Quote: Then they began `paddocking'. They marked off a strip of land and stripped off the soil down to the wash. ... When all this first area of wash had been put through the sluice box, they began on the second `paddock'.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1967
Source: West Coast Gold Rushes
Author: MAY
Vol / Page: 169
Edition: 1962
Quote: During May, Haast saw miners on the outskirts of Hokitika, `actively at work paddocking at high-water mark, and cradling the wash-dirt of a thickness of 18 inches to two feet on the sea-beach'
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1970
Source: Gold Trails of Otago
Author: WOOD
Vol / Page: 81
Edition:
Quote: More elaborate methods of winning gold include cradling, crevicing, setting up a sluicebox or `Long Tom' ..., sluicing, paddocking, and underwater dredging.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1983
Source: Gold Fossicker's Handbook
Author: NOLAN
Vol / Page: 113
Edition:
Quote: <i>Paddocking:</i> working alluvial gold in a dry region by storing the paydirt in a gully or bin and washing it when water is available; also, digging or sluicing a claim one section at a time methodically.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1976
Source: Historic Gold Trails of Nelson & Marlborough
Author: NOLAN
Vol / Page: 88
Edition:
Quote: Paddocking: A square of ground was dug down to the paydirt layer. The paydirt was either extracted and worked in a pan, cradle or sluice box, or the paddock had one open end and was sluiced. Paddocks were often waterlogged and had to be continually bailed or pumped dry.
Notes:

Date: 10/5/1862
Source: Otago Witness
Author:
Vol / Page: 8
Edition:
Quote: There are several parties of miners sluicing in the main gully of this basin, who are averaging about 12s (twelve shillings) per day each in shallow sinking or paddocking, the greatest depth not exceeding 3 (three) feet, with plenty of water.
Notes:

Vol / Page: 4

Quote: The ground is of a loose shingly nature, and in paddocking, the sides are continually falling in...

paddocking
Homonym Number: 1

Pai Marire
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a 19th century semi-religious movement begun by Te Ua. [Maori PAI + marire[a-macron] gentle, appeased]
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:also Hauhau(ism), Ringatu
Pronunciation:
Notes: also Hauhau(ism), Ringatu 		also used as a cry when attacking

Source: NZ Tablet
Author:
Vol / Page: 15
Edition:
Quote: [Te Ua] sought consolation by praying tohis God, and Atua Pai Marire... Te Uasent out two prophets to the tribes ofthe Eats Coast to establish the PaiMarire doctrine, Kereopa and Patara.

Vol / Page: 3

Vol / Page: 21
Edition:
Quote: The great moving principle of Pai Marire is that it is a scheme which promises a successful termination of the war with which we are afflicted.
Notes: 1865 Mar 25 Annual Report of the Bishop of Waiapu, Dr. William Williams to the Secretary of the CMS in 1937 Babbage Hauhauism 21

Date: 0/3/1865

Author: CARBERRY
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote: It has lately adopted a new feature as far as the natives are concerned namely fanatisism [sic] which is a bad characteristic in an enemy. ... They invented a new religion which they call `Pai Marire' or the good message. They have given up Christianity ...
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1868
Source: Past and Present of NZ
Author: TAYLOR
Vol / Page: 147
Edition:
Quote: The new faith was called <i>`Pai marire',</i> but afterwards, from the noise the votaries made in their devotions, resembling the barking of dogs, they acquired the name of <i>Hauhaus. </I>
Notes:

Date: 26/12/1870
Source: Ride Through Disturbed Districts
Author: MEADE
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  ... We met a small party of [440] mounted natives, who brought news that an apostle of the new <i>Pai Marire,</i> or <i>Te Hau,</i> fanaticism had arrived at Taupo ... They are called <i>Pai Marire</i>, from the words which they subscribe to their signatures and use in greeting or parting from their co-religionists. The words literally mean `good! be appeased'; but the real tendency of the belief is to unite the Kingites of all sects in one common bond of fanatical hostility to the pakehas. <i>Te Hau </i>means only the <i>hau </i>(faith). <i>Ibid</i> 466 ... a host of perverts were chanting <i>Pai Marire </i>hymns round a <i>Hau-hau</i> post of worship, erected close to the late Christian church.
Notes: 1870 Dec 26 Meade Ride Through Disturbed Dists in 1959 Taylor Early Travs. 439-440

Notes:

Date: 0/0/1959
Source: History of New Zealand
Author: SINCLAIR
Vol / Page: 137
Edition:
Quote: But there was a new and intractable fact to be taken into account in Taranaki: <I>Pai marire</I>- the Good and Peaceful Religion. In 1862 the Angel Gabriel had appeared in a vision to Te Ua, a Maori who had fought the Europeans in Taranaki.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1967
Source: Evil Day
Author: BRATHWAITE
Vol / Page: 380
Edition:
Quote: PAI-MARIRE The Taranaki form of the Hauhau faith. (There was a modified form, even more barbaric, if anything, founded by Te Kooti and rife in East Coast and Urewera Country, known as. <I>Ringa-tu Pai-marire</I>, which revived ritual cannibalism and other revolting practices, strangely enough means `Good and Peaceful.'
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1986
Source: NZ Wars, The
Author: BELICH
Vol / Page: 204
Edition:
Quote: <I>Pai Marire </I>- `The Good and Peaceful', also known as `Hauhauism' - was a syncretic religion originated by the prophet Te Ua Haumene, of the Taranaki tribe, in 1862. It had messianic and millenarian aspects, and theologically combined traditional Maori religion and the Maori versions of Christianity with Te Ua's own innovations. ... The original form of Pai Marire may have died out as early as 1866, with the death of its founder, but related or similar cults developed around leaders such as Hakaraia, Te Whiti O Rongomai, Titokowaru, Te Kooti, and Tawhiao himself.
Notes:

Date: 27/5/1865
Source: Taranaki Herald
Author:
Vol / Page: 2
Edition:
Quote: .. and the words "pai marire", which at first were mere adjectives, by constant repetition became a sort of invocation, in which sense they are now used.
Notes:

Vol / Page: 108
Edition:
Quote: Paikaka, or homebrew, was very prevalent and very potent. It was made from a plant with sugar and anything they liked added, often pumpkin or maize. It was clear like lager and had a kick like a mule.

Vol / Page: 93
Edition:
Quote: <i>Pukkaroo</i>, adjective and noun, (to make) worthless, useless - it could be used, for instance, of an engine that had broken down - is of dubious origin; ... perhaps from the Maori <i>pakaru, </i>... or conceivably ... an adaptation of `buggered'.

Date: 16/9/1863
Source: Journal of William Morgan
Author:
Vol / Page: 85
Edition: 1963

Notes:

Date: 0/0/1871
Source: Dictionary of the NZ Language
Author: WILLIAMS
Vol / Page: 105
Edition:
Quote: <i>pakaru</i>, ... v.t.<i> break in pieces. </I> the usual anglicisation [k 'ru:] <i>puckeroo</i>, etc, the adjectival use of<i> puckeroo</i> (she's puckeroo, mate) and the meaning, suggests a borrowing from the Maori adjectival form; and the common meaning `ruin', and a common form as pa ptc aj <i>puckerood</i>, has suggested to some a co-derivation from <i>bugger, buggered.</i> Maori<i> `pakaru </i>could be heard as [bg'ru:] `buggeroo', but only <i>buckeroo </i>is recorded: cf, however, Australian <i>bugaroo. </i>spg (early)<i> puikero, pukeru; puckaroo, puckeroo, buckeroo, pukaroo, pukkaroo. </I>
Notes:

Date: 13/12/1840
Source: Journal of Ensign Best
Author:
Vol / Page: 267
Edition: 1966
Quote: The Mauries swore that we should all be Puckarooed as well as the gun and away they scuttled.
Notes:

Author: BARNICOAT
Vol / Page: 160
Edition:
Quote: Gideon [a native,] forseeing the collision .... shouted out Puikero! puikero! puikero! (broken).

Quote: Their Cloathing (both Men [and] Women) is a kind of matt or cloth made of silk grass or fine flax, curiously wove and tied about the shoulder that reaches to their knees ... [they] call it an Ahow, [fn ahu] and over it they have one of a coarser sort made of Grass well thrumbed with the same to keep out the wet which they call a Bugy Bugy. [fn] pakepake often made of undressed flax.

Edition:
Quote: I observed that the term `New Zealander' is already employed in this district; only, in lieu of `Noui-Tireni", as the natives of the Bay of Islands pronounce it, they say `Noui-Tirangui' [Nui Tirangi] [sic], which gives the word more of an indigenous sound. The word <i>pakeha</i> serves them to signify all whites, whom they also call `Iouropi' (Europeans). I did not observe that they had a special name for the English.
Notes: (Smith transl. D'Urville's Visit to Tolaga Bay in 1827)

Date: 28/12/2002
Source: Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page: 7
Edition:
Quote: When my lot arrived they crowded the rail of the ship and cried, "What-ho, natives" (or, among the lower orders, like mine, "Wotcher, natives").  The people on the beach, somewhat nonplussed, I expect, needed a name to identify the new arrivals. They chose "pakeha".... These days it is used in government documents, even though there is confusion over just who is Pakeha: are Pacific Islanders Pakeha? Or Malaysian Chinese immigrants? Or Sudanese refugees?... I do not want to be identified as Pakeha, a colonial term that should have died out when the colonial century ended.
Notes: letter from Denis Wederell

Citations
Date: 24/9/1983
Source: Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page: 59
Edition:
Quote: All people who live in urban industrial societies have their lives requlated by measured time. This concept of time is referred to by Maoris as `Pakeha time' and they conform to its dictates inasmuch as they are on time for work, to catch buses or to fulfil engagements. However, because they are bicultural, Maoris function in their own time-frame as well, which they refer to as `Maori time'.
Notes:  [Ranginui Walker]

Date: 0/0/1980
Source: All My Lives
Author: THOMPSON
Vol / Page: 115
Edition:
Quote: The hardest part was getting started. No sooner had I cast Don Selwyn from Wellington as the old man, and Thomas Ratima from Napier as Matt, then, as if intent on proving right the stereotype about `Maori unreliability', they both disappeared without trace. They turned up in the end, of course, and, just to prove me prejudiced and wrong, subscribed more rigorously than anyone to `pakeha time'; but meanwhile I was driven to desperation trying to find the other twenty or so Maoris needed to complete the cast.

Pakeha-Maori
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:2
Definition:a way of speaking that accommodates characteristics of both Maori and English speakers.
Origin:Maori
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Used primarily before revitalisation of te reo
Citations
Date: 0/0/1944
Source: Book of Wiremu, The
Author: Stella Morice
Vol / Page: 50
Edition:
Quote: The meaning of words is as correct as possible, but the pronunciation is just the pakeha-Maori which most of us use.
Notes:

Date: 5/5/1875
Source: Timaru Herald
Author:
Vol / Page: 3
Edition:
Quote: Maori is a very beautiful language; and English is not a bad one as languages go; but that delightful 'patois' called Pakeha-Maori, which is the vulgar tongue among half-castes, loafers, missionaries, Maori doctors, and other kinds of vagabonds in the North Island, goes beyond either of its component roots for breadth of expressions, and euphony of sound. In Maori again no two consonants occur together, so that in using English words in Pakeha-Maori, a vowel must always be stuck in between consonants where they happen to meet.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1941

Author: BAKER
Vol / Page: 16
Edition:
Quote: The colloquial uses of <i>pake-has</i> (the <i>has</i> being accented), for a wealthy white man, and pake-hasn't, for a penniless white, may be noted.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1945
Source: Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page: 54/228
Edition:
Quote: Among composite forms in which the adjective appears are <i>pre-pakeha times, Journal of the Polynesian Society,</i> 27 (1918), <i>pre-pakeha days,</i> V. Roberts <i>Kohikohinga</i> (1929), etc. and the jocular uses <i>pakehas</i> (the `has' being accented) and <i>pakehasn't, </i>for a rich and penniless white man respectively. (These uses may have occurred in print, but I have not seen them; only heard them.)
Notes:  (Baker)

Vol / Page: 13/46
Edition:
Quote: Pakihi has in the South Island been borrowed from the Maori for a patch of country naturally clear of bush and is applied particularly to the poor wet land, unsuitable for development, on the West Coast. Haast wrote of ‘pakis or open tracts of land.' in Nelson. As pakihis are frequently surrounded by bush, a bald spot on one's head may be called a pakihi, but that is slang.

Date: 15/8/1912
Source: NZ Journal of Agriculture
Author:
Vol / Page: 126
Edition:
Quote: EXPERIMENTS ON THE PAKIHI SOILS OF WESTLAND. ... `Pakihi' is a Maori word signifying an opening or clearing free from forest. There are in Westland large areas of sour, swampy, terrace land which supports a flora such as rushes, fern, moss, and plants one usually associates with sour, water-sodden soils. ... This type of country is usually known locally as pakihi land, or `the pakihis'.

Source: Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland
Author: HAAST
Vol / Page: 81
Edition:
Quote: Most of [the gold-seekers] ... begged me to leave them flour enough for at least one day, which I did, ... as I had been assured ... that I should be able to obtain new provisions at the so-called Pakihi, a large forest meadow near Lake Brunner. <i>Ibid.</I> 82 After a mile and a half we came out of the high forest and the pakihi or paddock lay before us. This is the name given by the diggers to a grass-covered plain between one and two miles broad, bordered on both sides by thickly wooded mountains. This place, generally so desolate, was now highly animated. Cattle and horses were grazing peacefully in all directions. Numbers of tents were put up near the forest for the accommodation of gold-diggers, cattle-drivers, and storekeepers.

pakihi
Homonym Number: 1
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:in English usage chiefly South Island, with two main applications: (a) West Coast, usually connoting heavy, swampy (originally bush) land; -->(b) open grass or scrub tract, often in bush country, or above the bush line.
Origin:[none]

Domain:[none]
Region:[none]

pakihi
Homonym Number: 1
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:

See:

Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1851
Source: Southern Districts of NZ
Author: SHORTLAND
Vol / Page: 195
Edition:
Quote: We now advanced along the plain [towards Moeraki], which was covered with `patiti' and ... stunted fern and `tutu'. These plains are called `pakihi,' a word used in the North Island to signify dried up. So that `tupakihi,' the name by which the `tutu' is there known, appears to be a contraction of `tutupakihi,' or `tutu' of the [196] plains, which are well called `pakihi,' being for the most part arid. <i>Ibid.</I> 311 PAKIHI, open country, bare of trees, covered with coarse wiry grass, stunted fern, and low shrubs. It does not necessarily signify `a plain'. The `a' is sounded long and broad in this word, by which it is distinguished from `pakihi,' to be low water, or to drain off as a river after a flood, in which the `a' has a sound both short and soft. `Kua pakihi te wai o Waitaki,' the water of Waitahi has become low.
Notes: 1844 Jan 9 in 1851 Shortland Southern Districts of NZ 195-196

Date: 0/0/1951
Source: High Country
Author: McLEOD
Vol / Page: 43
Edition:
Quote: Then there are two well-known and often disputed words, Parkee and Wareleggo. Parkee is very expressive. It is used of an open space partly surrounded by the dark green birch bush whose compact and shapely foliage suggested to the early settlers the ordered parklands to which they were accustomed. A clearing completely surrounded by bush will be called a `blind Parkee'.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1959
Source: Tall Tussock
Author: McLEOD
Vol / Page: 124
Edition:

Quote: <i>Pseudoslabrus celidotus</i> (Forster). SPOTTY; PAEKIRIKIRI.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1957
Source: Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ
Author: PARROTT
Vol / Page: 131
Edition:
Quote: THE SPOTTY <i>Pseudolabrus celidotus (Richardson) </i>... Maori name: PAEKIRIKIRI ... This was one of the first species of fish collected in New Zealand by Europeans, and was described and named in 1801. The Spotty belongs to the Parrotfish family (Labridae) and is also related to the Butterfish and Kelpfish.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1956
Source: NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author: GRAHAM
Vol / Page: 272
Edition:
Quote: SPOTTY (PAEKIRIKIRI) <i>Pseudolabrus (Lunolabrus) celidotus</i> (Bloch and Schneider) ... [<i>Ibid.</i> 275] The name Spotty is derived from the presence of spots on each side of the fish. The name Butterfish used in the North Island for them is from the yellow or buttery colouring on the undersurface. In Canterbury they are called Guffy, but for what reason I have yet to learn. It is a very pretty fish, more especially when seen in the water.
Notes:

Date: 8/8/1987
Source: Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page: 61
Edition:
Quote: Well out into the [Auckland] harbour was the `paketi pond', where children could easily catch `paketi', as we called the fish usually called `spotties' or, by the Maori, pa[macron]kirikiri.
Notes: Sinclair `At the Point'

Date: 0/0/1855
Source: Te Ika a Maui
Author: TAYLOR
Vol / Page: 411
Edition:
Quote: <i>Kirikiri,</i> and <i>pakirikiri</i>, a rough-skinned fish, having two spines on the back, which it can elevate at pleasure; it is a short but broad fish (<i>labrus paecilopleura</i>). <i>Ibid.</I> 624 Fam. <i>Plectognathi</i>. - The <i>Pakirikiri, (balistes,) </i>file fish, is distinguished by two strong spines at the commencement of the dorsal fin, in shape like the letter V, both fronting the head, and standing out from the fin, these are elevated at pleasure, some fish have only one. The Pakirikiri is abundant in the Bay of Islands.

pampas grass
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:OED : The popular name of a gigantic grass, Cortaderia selloana, having ample silky panicles of silvery hue borne on stalks rising to the height of twelve or fourteen feet; a native of South America, whence it was introduced into Europe in 1843 as an ornament of lawns and  shrubberies.   1850-1 PAXTON Flower Garden I. 175.
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:also purple pampas grass
Pronunciation:
Notes:

Author: TURNER
Vol / Page: 152
Edition:
Quote: <I>Dashing</I> seems to be a shortened form of<I> pan dashing,</I> extracting gold with a pan about thirteen or fourteen inches in diameter. It is tempting to wonder whether the expression `he's done his dash' ... is connected with the gold-miner's <I>dashing. </I>

Quote: Panahi is the well-behaved cousin in the convolvulus family .. Calystegia soldanella, or panahi .. knows its rightful place and like all plants in their rightful place, doesn't become weedy. Panahi is a perennial herb that occupies the edges of coasts and lakes and helps to stabilise sand.

panakeke
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a Maori `pancake' bread
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1966
Source: Kapiti Coast
Author: CARKEEK
Vol / Page: 52
Edition:
Quote: The Maori word for bread is paraoa which is a trans-literation of the word flour. Various kinds of bread were made by the whalers, traders, and missionaries and some of them survive today and are regarded by present-day Maoris as non-Pakeha items of diet. One of these is called rewena (leaven) bread, another is the panakeke, or pancake-type bread.
Notes:

Quote: `You came down easy,' he said. `But this panel over the river will be hard.' `Huh! What's a panel!' I asked. `Hoka, I've begun to have suspicions about you.' He soon showed us the panel. It was no less than a rickety pole bridge, swung on wires attached to branches of trees, and spanning a dark rushing little river that must have been beautiful at some other time.
Notes:

Vol / Page: 71
Edition:
Quote: The other principal species formerly taken were the inanga and kokopu (<i>Galaxias</i> and <i>Retropinna</i>), upokororo (<i>Prototractes</i>), and panoko (<i>Cheimarrichthys</i>); while the lamprey (piharau and korokoro) and fresh water crayfish (koura) were taken in considerable numbers in some districts.
Notes:

Date: 22/5/2004
Source: Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page: 48
Edition:
Quote: ...why is a boss in New Zealand sometimes referred to as a pannikin? I can't pin down the answer to this one. A pannikin is a small drinking vessel used by workers. The expression "pannikin boss" was first recorded in 1911, in the <i>Maoriland Worker</i>: The 'pannikin' boss ... is the man who for a wretched shilling a day more than his fellow unionists sells his body to a mercenary employer to rush, wear and sweat others."

pannikin boss
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a person with minor authority, a foreman. (slightly contemptuous) -->
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: ca1950 (freezing works.) a leading-hand (Colin Gordon, Foxton)
Citations
Date: 0/0/1898
Source: Austral English
Author: MORRIS
Vol / Page: 339
Edition:
Quote: <i>Pannikin-boss,</i> or <i>Pannikin-overseer, n</i>. The term is applied colloquially to a man on a station, whose position is above that of the ordinary station-hand, but who has no definite position of authority, or is only a `boss' or overseer in a small way.
Notes:

Source: Maoriland Worker

Author:
Vol / Page: 17

Date: 20/4/1911

Vol / Page: 15

Quote: The "pannikin" boss usually is in evidence. This is the man who for a wretched shilling a day more than his fellow Unionists sells his body to a mercenary employer to rush, wear and sweat others.
Notes:

Date: 26/6/2004
Source: Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page: 48
Edition:
Quote: Keith Snalam of Blenheim writes: "As an apprentice boy in the 50s, I frequently heard the term 'pannikin boss'. I'm sure it was used as a comment on the state of mind of the foreman or leading hand, that person having just had the big boss from the office on his hammer ... The foreman would be seen approaching the workers in a state which these days would be described as stressed out. Hence the term, 'here comes the panickin' boss'!"  Maybe. Dave Bijoux of Mt Eden suggests: "The pannikin boss drank from the pannikin, as did all the workers: a boss who metaphorically drank from their cup, was part of the community, and was somewhat despised as a prostitute for the workers. Ronald Thomas of Pamlerston North adds: "Perhaps there is a connection between a metal cup that holds a little liquid and a trumped-up boss who holds little authority, but makes a lot of noise about it."
Notes:

Date: 22/9/1915
Source: Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page: 8
Edition:
Quote: "He introduced himself as a pannikin boss," said a witness of another man in the Magistrate's court to-day.  "'Pannikin boss'?" said Chief Detective Boddam, "what is that?"  "The Foreman," explained the witness.

Author: BACON
Vol / Page: 182
Edition:
Quote: <i>papa</I> - In Maori mythology, Papa was the earth-god, Rangi the heavens. ... Today, in legend, Papa is still the earth, but in particular the term is applied to a type of blue-grey clay rock.
Notes:

papa
Homonym Number: 1
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:esp. papa rock, a bluish calcareous marl found in the North Island.
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:Geology
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: [? get dateline from dict. and complete quot.] With the exception of the beds of conglomerate and of limestone, all the members of the Upper Whatatutu are popularly termed `papa'. Thus the term `papa' includes rocks from claystone to sandstone, and on account of this wide meaning has not been used in the text of this report, except under the heading of [????]

Date: 0/0/1855
Source: Te Ika a Maui
Author: TAYLOR
Vol / Page: 415
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Papaka</i>, the crab: the largest is about two and a half inches across the carapace; a small crab, called the <i>rerepari,</i> abounds in the salt marshes. There is also a small crab found in the mussel, which has a very round red body and short legs. I have met with a little fresh-water crab, seventy miles inland; it is not above half an inch across the shell, delicately formed, of a dusky green color. There is no lobster in New Zealand.
Notes:

Notes: (Ngata)

Date: 0/0/1985
Source: Towards Taha Maori
Author: HOWE
Vol / Page: 21
Edition:
Quote: Papakainga - `homeground' does not reveal the spiritual and emotional connotations this word implies. Papakainga is that area where one's original kinship group came from and lived. Whether or not the area has buildings on it, it has strong emotional overtones for any Maori. In this age of the urban Maori, the ability to refer to ancestral areas - the place where one's own history was made - is a matter of deep pride. Once known, one can never leave it - though one may be physically absent all one's life.
Notes:

Date: 16/5/2002
Source: Dominion
Author:
Vol / Page: 6
Edition:

Date: 0/0/1988
Source: Lexicographical & Linguistic Studies
Author: BURCHFIELD
Vol / Page: 195
Edition:
Quote: papalagi /pa|pa:la ^i/. Also papalangi and in shortened form palagi (see below). [Samoan <i>papalagi.</i>] A European, a white man. Also attrib. or as adj. `The first vowel of this word is ofter omitted in colloquial speech, but the initial consonant is then released more slowly than usual.' (G.B. Milner) This shortened form is more usual in New Zealand English. In Samoan the word has no pl. inflexion.

Large numbers are annually secured by the Maoris of this locality. The panokonoko is much esteemed as a food fish.

paperalia
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: A term probably coined by Christchurch Stamp Dealer, Laurie Franks [19**-19**], to cover non-philatelic paper-based oddments in his regular auctions (see quot). Since used for collectable paper ephemera including pamphlets (but seldom books), indentures, wills, engraved invoices, even sometimes bus, tram and train tickets. Term possibly derived by analogy with Marginalia.

Date: 17/12/1985
Source: Laurie Franks Ltd World General catalogue
Author:
Vol / Page: [5]
Edition:
Quote: PAPERALIA. Books, Photos, Historical Documents, Old Prints, etc.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1889
Source: Catalogue NZ Exhibition
Author: PARKER
Vol / Page: 117
Edition:
Quote: There are eleven species of Native Ducks belonging to nine genera, all found elsewhere, except two--the little Flightless Duck of the Auckland Islands (genus <I>Nesonetta</I>) and the Blue Mountain Duck (<I>Hymenolaemus</I>). Among the most interesting of the non-endemic forms, are the Paradise Duck or Sheldrake (<I>Casarca variegata</I>), the Brown Duck (<I>Anas chlorotis</I>), the Shoveller or Spoonbill duck (<I>Rhynchaspis variegata</I>), and the Scaup or Black Teal (<I>Fuligula Novae-Zealandiae</I>).
Notes: 1889 Prof. Parker `Catalogue of New Zealand Exhibition' 117 in 1898 Morris Austral-English 128

paraerae
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:Maori sandals of plaited flax. [Maori paraerae[a1-macron]] (felt as pl)
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 21/10/1847
Source: Journal of an Expedition
Author: BRUNNER
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote: I had often looked forward with dread to the time when my shoes would be worn out, ... but now I can trudge along ... with a pair of native sandals, called y the natives <i>pairairai</i>, made of the leaves of flax, or, what is more durable, the leaves of the ti or flax tree.
Notes: 1847 Oct 21 Brunner Expedition Middle Island in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 288

Date: 20/7/1848
Source: Letters from Otago
Author:
Vol / Page: 16
Edition: 1978
Quote:  ... they [natives] wear shoes made of flax, which they call<i> paralas</i>; they are very humorous creatures ...
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1851
Source: Southern Districts of NZ
Author: SHORTLAND
Vol / Page: 311
Edition:
Quote: PARAERAE, a sandal formed from the plaited leaves of the <i>phormium tenax</i>,;or the `ti' (<i>Cordyline Australis</i>).;Three different descriptions of sandal are made by the natives. That called `paraerae hou' or `kuara' is made of a single layer of plaited leaves of flax; that called `takitahi' is similarly made from the leaves of the `ti;' the third, called `torua' is made of the leaves of the `ti,' but plaited in a double layer, so as to be very durable.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1861
Source: Report on Topographical Exploration of Nelson
Author: HAAST
Vol / Page: 48
Edition:
Quote:  The next day, ... the coast becoming very rocky, we exchanged our boots for Maori sandals (pereiras), which allowed better foothold on the smooth boulders.
Notes:

Vol / Page:

Date: 0/0/1946
Source: Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page: 55/155
Edition:
Quote: <i>pa[a]raha</i>, a climbing plant (Calystegia sepium), a convolvulus. The far-famed Te Rapauraha took his name from this plant as a reminder that when the body of his father was eaten by his enemies they used the leaf (rau) of this plant as a relish. another convolvulus (C. soldanella) is po[o]hue.
Notes: Andersen Maori Words in English

Date: 0/0/1949
Source: Coming of the Maori, The
Author: BUCK
Vol / Page: 2/156
Edition:

Date: 0/0/1930
Source: Topsail Schooner 'Lark', The
Author:
Vol / Page: 73, 78
Edition:
Quote: We followed [the sealers returned c1870s from West Coast to Stewart Island] with our eyes admiring their new hand made seal skin caps with the crest of a penguin or some other Antarctic bird sewn on front. Still wearing their flax <i>pararos</i> as it takes a long time to get used to wearing boots after a sealing trip. ... [78] It is in such places that the sealer is seen at his very best; travelling at great pace over rugged sea-piled rocks ... with their feet covered with flax or grass mats tightly laced ...
Notes: c1930 Capt. William McKillop The Topsail Schooner `Lark' (MS Tasmanian Collection, State Library of Tasmania) 73, 78

Date: 13/1/1844
Source: Southern Districts of NZ
Author: SHORTLAND
Vol / Page: 209
Edition:
Quote: This evening, Huruhuru made me a pair of sandals, such as are in common use among these natives. They are called `paraerae', and are made either with the leaves of the flax-[210]plant, or of the `ti' (cordyline Australis). ... Mine were a pair with double soles, called `torua', ...
Notes:

Vol / Page: 21
Edition: 1978

Date: 0/11/2003
Source: NZ Geographic
Author:
Vol / Page: No. 11/40
Edition:
Quote: Herries Beattie describes a different method: "This tussock was placed in the paraerae (sandal) and the foot inserted. Then the tussock was brought up the leg and tied above the ankle. This protection was called puru and the sandals were then known as tupuru." Patiti was also regarded as "a fine thing to put in the paraerae to keep the feet warm and if one was wading it was warmer with patiti around the feet than without it."

Date: 0/6/1946
Source: Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page: 55/155
Edition:
Quote: <i>paraha,</i> a climbing plant (Calystegia sepium), a convolvulus. The far-famed Te Rauparaha took his name from this plant as a reminder that when the body of his father was eaten by his enemies they used the leaf (rau) of this plant as a relish. Another convolvulus (C. soldanella) is pohue.
Notes: J.C.Andersen

Date: 22/12/1898
Source: Otago Witness
Author:
Vol / Page: 31
Edition:
Quote: [Te Rauparaha's] name signifies a food leaf, the paraha.

Notes: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes

Date: 0/0/1925
Source: NZ Journal of Science & Technology
Author:
Vol / Page: 8/291
Edition:
Quote: <i>Vernacular Name</i>.- Powell [TrNZI 2/84] was the first to point out that two fish were referred to as `smelt' in north Canterbury. These were <i>Galaxias attenuatus</i> and <i>Retropinna retropinna.</i> At present Canterbury residents refer to <i>R. retropinna</i> as `silvery,' on account of the silver line running along the side of the half-grown fish. Maoris refer to this `silvery' as `tikihemi,' and to the adult as `paraki.'
Notes:  (Phillipps)

Date: 0/0/1936
Source: Handbook for New Zealand, The
Author:
Vol / Page: 73
Edition:
Quote: <i>Retropinna retropinna:</i> [European Name] Smelt [Maori Name] Paraki.

Date: 0/0/1940
Source: Fishes NZ
Author: PHILLIPPS
Vol / Page: 54
Edition:
Quote: In some other localities these young [smelt, <i>Retropinna</i>] are called tuarenga. The half-grown fish is termed tikihemi and the adult paraki. Certain races of fish have a broad silvery band running along the side; hence the term `silvery.' It is to be regretted that in Canterbury the term smelt is still used to apply to the minnow, <i>Galaxias attenuatus. </I>
Notes:

See:

Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1868
Source: Contributions to NZ Botany
Author: LINDSAY
Vol / Page: 82
Edition:
Quote: In Otago the general name of the [flax] plant, as a whole, is `Korari,' - or as metamorphosed by the settler, pronounced and spelt `Koura<i>d</i>i,' [a-macron] or `Coradi' [a-macron]. The same term is applied in the North Island equally to the whole plant, and to the dried flower-stem when cut for rafts or other purposes; or exclusively to the flower-stalk. In the North [83] Island, the Flax-plant is also known as `Harakeke,' or `Herekiakia,' - its usual name there. ... The lower part of the flower-stem is `Kaikaha;' the outer part of the leaf `Parakoka;' [a1, o-macron] the refuse of the leaf `Hunga-hunga;' the flax, dressed or not, or scraped fibre, manufactured from the leaf, `Whitau,' or `Muka.'
Notes:

Date: 0/2/1777
Source: Cook's Journals
Author:
Vol / Page: 3/806
Edition: 1967

Notes: 1777 Feb Anderson's Journal in Cook Journals (1967) 3/806 (Queen Charlotte Sound) [also entered at parroquet]

parapara
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:the bird-catching tree, a small tree of northern North Island, with long leaves and sticky fruit that sometimes entrap small birds. [Maori]

Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]

Edition:
Quote: <i>parapara</i>, a tree (Pisonia Bruniniana), bird-catching tree: its sticky leaves are liable to entrap small birds; the tree does not eat them as the sundew does entrapped insects.
Notes: Andersen Maori Words in English

Date: 0/0/1961
Source: Flora NZ
Author: MARTIN
Vol / Page: 163
Edition:
Quote: 4. Parapara (<i>Heimerliodenron brunoniana</i>) leaves opposite, 4-15 in. long; ... fruits long thin, very viscous. [north N. Island].
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1978
Source: Oxford Book of NZ Plants
Author: MOORE & IRWIN
Vol / Page: 60
Edition:
Quote: <i>PISONIA BRUNONIANA.</i> Parapara is a small tree of quick, rather soft growth carrying leaves up to 40cm long, of dark glossy green ... Nodular ridges down the length of the `fruit' ... secrete a glutinous substance ... Most spectacular is the ability of this tarry substance to hold small birds. ... anyone who has seen a waxeye struggling to free itself from amongst a cluster of these fruits can easily understand why parapara has earned the name `bird-catching tree'. ... Where it grows with pukanui (<i>Meryta sinclairii</i>) two of our largest-leaved trees come together.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1988
Source: Forest Vines to Snow Tussocks
Author: DAWSON
Vol / Page: 110
Edition:
Quote: On the mainland as well as on islands, and extending to East Cape and beyond, are the small trees parapara or the `bird catching tree' (<i>Pisonia brunoniana</i>) and tawapou (<i>Planchonella costata</i>).

Date: 0/0/1940
Source: Rakiura
Author: HOWARD
Vol / Page: 205
Edition:
Quote: These are the names used by the southern Maori; in the North Id. Kuaka, Parara and Titi are applied to other birds. Kuaka: <i>Pelicanoides Urinatrix</i>, or Diving Petrel. Black Bill. Wing 4.7 inches. Titi Wainui: <i>Prion Turtur</i> or Dove Petrel. Parara: <i>Prion vittatus</i>, or Broad-billed Petrel. Bill very wide. Wing, 9.5 inches. Titi: <i>Puffinus Griseus</i> or Mutton-Bird. Sooty brown. Bill horn colour. Wing, 12 inches.

Date: 0/0/1847
Source: Savage Life
Author: ANGAS
Vol / Page: 1/323
Edition:
Quote: The other garments of skins are the <i>huru huru</i>, and the <i>parawai</i>; the former is frequently worn, especially during the cold season, by the people of Cook's Straits and the districts south of Taupo [and is made of dog's skins] ... The other dress, called parawai, is exceedingly scarce; it comes from the Southern Island, and is made of strips of dog's fur, arranged indiscriminately all over a very large mat of the finest flax.

Date: 0/0/1974
Source: NZ Agriculture
Author:
Vol / Page: 71
Edition:
Quote: The [wool buyer] takes into account the assessed `yield' which he can expect from each type. (Yield is the amount of wool fibre left after the wool has been washed, and the foreign matter, grease, `suint' (sweat), dust, and vegetable matter have been removed.) The yield is expressed as a percentage of the whole `parcel' of wool.

Domain:Environment

See:

Citations

Author:
Vol / Page: 1
Edition:
Quote: The parea is the local version of the New Zealand wood pigeon or kereru. While it is relatively rare and confined to the south-west, numbers have grown in the past few years .. Parea are often seen on the ground feeding and sometimes nest close to the ground making them easy targets for feral cats.

Parekuraism

Origin:[none]

Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 5/7/2003
Source: Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page: 15
Edition:
Quote: The remarkable feature of this row has been Horomia's style. His parliamentary answers were impenetrable. Having tried to deconstruct dozens of Parekura-isms, I have developed a theory: he tries to say several sentences at once. He can't bear to pick which sentence to say first, in case someone interrupts him, before he's managed to say the others. So he blurts it all out as a compound.

Vol / Page: 2/225

Quote: The species we have identified in the Kaipara and Hokianga are - the Putangi, or `paradise-duck' (<i>Casarca variegata</i>); the grey duck, or Parera (<i>Anas superciliosa</i>); the brown duck, an allied species or variety of the last; the Papanga, or `teal,' or `widgeon' (<i>Fuligula N.Z.</i>), and some other varieties that may be imported birds, or crosses, or other native species.

Date: 22/3/1894
Source: Richmond-Atkinson Papers
Author:
Vol / Page: 2/597
Edition: 1960
Quote: He has had a rough time of it surveying a block on the ranges up the Wai-o-hine in the Wairarapa ...[sic] Once ...[sic] they had nothing to eat but a tui and a more-pork. ... They were stewing the two birds when a kuku-pa (bush pigeon) flew up and perched. Bob shot it ... This is not exactly what the Britishers call `sport' - but there is more of nature about it than 30 gents in pink and tops ... waiting for a wretched little fox who, when he is killed, is not equal for culinary purposes to a more-pork. Once coming up the Waikato in 1851 your Uncle James got a pot-shot at a lot of parera (grey duck) ...
Notes: (C.W. Richmond)

Quote: The story of the Taranaki village of Parihaka and its two visionary leaders, Te Whiti o Rongomai and Toku Kaka, whose campaign of passive resistance culminated in 1881 in the invasion and destruction of Parihaka by 1500 militia, has been a lightning rod for cultural and political energy in this country... The exhibition brings together for the first time the wealth of artwork inspired by Parihaka.
Notes:

Date: 26/8/2000

Vol / Page: 41
Edition:
Quote: As the author rightly says in his preface, Parihaka has achieved an "almost mythic status in our national consciousness"... Even his defiantly impartial hero, reading about Parihaka, is reminded of "what he had seen and experienced as a child and a youth in Ireland; the dawn horror of eviction; red skies and the smell of burning hovels; lamentations and anger; riots and his father dead on the waterlogged road."

Citations
Date: 1/11/2003
Source: Radio NZ / National Radio
Author:
Vol / Page: E13
Edition:
Quote: Another excitement is the flowering of the shrubby rata, Metrosideros parkinsonii, which has springtime, vermilion red bottle-brush flowers from September to November. This rare tree produces its flowers on its old bare stalks, something no other rata or pohutukawa does... In nature, this shrubby rata is found only in Great Barrier Island and in northwest Nelson.
Notes:

Date: 21/1/2010
Source: Internet - see Notes
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote: There are ten native species of rata in New Zealand all in the genus Metrosideros. Four of these form trees (northern rata, southern rata, Bartlett's rata and Parkinson's rata) and the remaining six species are all lianes.
Notes: http://www.nzpcn.org.nz/page.asp?flora_vascular_flowering_plants_dicots_rata

Edition:
Quote: In constitutional terms, the word "Parliament" refers to all of the people needed to pass legislation - that is, both the 120 members of the House or Representatives (known as Members or Parliament, or MPs) and the Sovereign (the British monarch, respresented in New Zealand by the Governor-General).
Notes:

Date: 0/5/2003
Source: NZ Geographic
Author:
Vol / Page: No. 63/50
Edition:
Quote: "Parliament" also refers to a physical place: most specifically the debating chamber where MPs meet, also the building that contains the chamber, and more generally still this building and the several others in which MPs have their offices. This complex consist of four buildings: the Parliamentary Library, Parliament House, the Beehive and a 22-storey high-rise called Bowen House.

Parliamentary Commissioner
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:an officer of parliament, appointed by the Governor-General on the recommendation of the House of Representatives.
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Jim Cameron writes : Britain has a PC for Administration (the ombudsman), a collocation recorded in NSOD. In NZ the ombudsmen's formal alternative title (almost never used) is PC for Investigations. There is also a <i>Parliamentary Commissioner for the Environment</i>.

parroquet / paroquet
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:parakeet
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 17/11/1888
Source: Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page: 2
Edition:
Quote: A person sued another for £2 for the detention of a paroquet.   The defendant's counsel asked that the plaintiff be non-suited, on the ground that the paroquet came under the head of <i>ferae naturae</i>, and that any such bird on escaping from its custodian became <i>res nullius</i>, and could not be the subject of larceny or a civil action.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1835
Source: Boultbee Journal
Author:
Vol / Page: 104
Edition: 1986
Quote: The birds are not remarkably musical - the linnets are rather so; The Bell-Bird, is of a purple colour, with a white spot on the breast, shaped like a bell. The Saddle back, is a brown bird with a bright red spot on its back like a saddle, these two last species, are about the size of a thrush. There are green parroquets, large hawks, and several kinds of wild ducks, besides Emus, greenbirds and woodhens, which are birds of excellent flavour.

parrotfish
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:in New Zealand usually a generic common name for various wrasses, such as banded parrotfish, green parrotfish, orange parrotfish, Sandager's parrotfish, scarlet parrotfish; a generic name for various fishes usu. of family Labridae, brightly-coloured with beak-like jaws [AND Labriformes, bright with beak-like jaws 1803]
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: see also rock cod

Quote: <i>Wrasses</i> A family (Labridae) of tropical to warm reef-dwelling fishes. Most of New Zealand's sixteen species are shared only with Australi. Quote: [species name] parrotfish .. [scientific name] -- [other name(s)] other than Pseudolabrus sp. ...  [species name] wrasse .. [scientific name] <i><i>Pseudolabrus </i></i>sp. .. [other name(s)] parrotfish. Use this code for fishing returns

parsley leafed pine
Homonym Number:

Sense Number:
Definition:an indiginous pine characterised by lacy leaf appearance.
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: <i>Phyllocladus trichomanoides</i> aka parsley-leafed pine, parsley-leaved pine, parsley pine,  celery pine, tanekaha;  found in upper tip of South Island and in the North Island north of a line from Mokau to Mahia Peninsula - latitude 39 degrees.

The name `Parson-bird' is later.]

Date: 0/0/1971
Source: Mr Surveyor Thomson
Author: HALL-JONES
Vol / Page: 55
Edition:
Quote:  ... but our parson bird being beyond reach held on his discourse with much nonchalance. Altogether this bird is a most remarkable one: clothed in feathers of deep black from head to foot, he wears a most grave and sacerdotal aspect. This is not all: he bears out closer the clerical resemblance by the possession of two pure white feathers under his chin, and the parody is complete when he commences to utter his guttural yet energetic notes. Sitting on the branch of a tree as a pro tempoire [????] pulpit, he wags his paw [????] and shakes his head, bending to one side, and then to another; as if he remarked to this one and to that one ... etc
Notes: 1850s in 1971 Hall-Jones Mr Surveyor Thomson 55-56 (Griffiths Collection)

Quote: In 1878 Bickerton revealed his partial impact theory of the creation of new stars which formed the basis of his theory of cosmic evolution. The notion that the oblique collision of two stars produces a new, hot, rapidly expanding body without destroying the original two in the process explained virtually all astronomical mysteries for Bickerton, but provoked only indifference or scepticism from scientists.

Date: 0/0/1879
Source: TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page: 11/125
Edition:
Quote: <i>Partial Impact: a possible Explanation of the Origin of the Solar System, Comets, and other Phenomena of the Universe</i>. By Professor A.W. Bickerton, F.C.S. ...
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1948
Source: Life & Times of Sir Julius von Haast
Author: HAAST
Vol / Page: 236
Edition:
Quote: The hypothesis that I am about to describe suggests that this [collisions] is the case, but especially says further that if they do knock against each other, the blow may be a mere graze of the two outsides, or sometimes a large piece of each other may be struck off: and in extremely rare cases they may meet fair; but as this latter is so extremely rare the other cases are those chiefly considered, and so the theory is called <i>Partial Impact.</i> The effect of the collision of our two stars will be to strike a piece off each other where they touch, and each star will travel on with a slice cut off the side of each. The parts of each which met will be left behind by both the retreating bodies, and will probably remain where the collision occurred. But, owing to the way it has been struck off, the two sides being impelled in opposite directions, it cannot help revolving, and it is not unlikely that nearly all the thousands of rotating bodies and systems in the universe may have thus been set spinning by partial impact. At partial impact, rotation must ensue. The matter will tend to spread out more or less in a flare, with frequently gas at the poles and the middle body produced by the collision will generally be very hot, proportional to the mass.
Notes: 188? A. W. Bickerton to the Canterbury Philosophical Institute quoted in 1948 Von Haast Life and Times of Sir Julius Von Haast 236

Date: 1/4/1908
Source: Progress
Author:
Vol / Page: 188
Edition:
Quote: It is most singular that this first, this fundamental, this absolutely basic idea of a third body, has for a quarter of a century been missed by astronomers.  They have been bombarded with tens of thousands of papers and pamphlets.  Diagrams showing the third body have been broadcasted before them by thousands and by hundreds.  A new term - "Partial Impact" - was specially coined to express the idea for their benefit and guidance.  But there they sit in their specialized turrets, regardless; and this prime idea, that the parts struck from grazing suns are welded into a third body, has failed to impress them.
Notes:

pass
Homonym Number: 1
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a narrow or small aperture, down which the quartz is passed from the upper to the lower tunnels
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1944
Source: Korero (AEWS Background Bulletin)
Author:
Vol / Page: 2(8) : 20
Edition:
Quote: Clad in trousers and singlet, they are bust shovelling the quartz down a "pass" to the level below.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1978
Source: Gold Mining at Waihi
Author: McARA
Vol / Page: 193
Edition:
Quote: As the mine workings reached greater depths the ground generally became more solid and stable and more and more shrinkage stopes were worked, until this method became the principal one in use for stopes up to about forty feet in width. The method consisted of putting in the level timbers in the usual way, with short chutes or `passes' installed every other set to allow all the ore in the stope to be lowered evenly as it was worked. <i>Ibid.</I> 209 ... including ... chutes for ore-handling, or `passes' as they were generally known. <i>Ibid.</I> 315 <i>Chutes or passes</i>: Chutes for running the broken ore out of the stopes into the hand-trucks were, for shrinkage stopes, placed between alternate sets (about 10 ft centres). They were about three feet wide, mounted three inches above the truck, and fitted with top and bottom doors. The bottom door was removed and the flow of ore into the truck controlled by jambing a pass-bar across the chute. (This was a short bar about three feet long with a D-shaped handle). The bottom of the chute was inclined at about 50 degrees from horizontal. For filled stopes, the chute was installed at the bottoms of the cribbed ore passes, leading up through the filling to the face of the stope; the ore passes were usually spaced from 18 to 25 ft apart along the stope, this being a convenient distance for men to shovel the ore. <i>Ibid.</I> 329 <i>Passes:</i> See chutes.
Notes:

pass the baby

passing lane
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Jim Cameron writes: British dictionaries (including OED) have <i>crawler lane</i>, which I have seen in NZ (there was one so called on the Bombay Hill highway) and <i>fast lane</i>, current literally and metaphorically here, but not <i>passing lane</i>. (British road atlases use the term <i>passing place</i>. For a time recently there were <i>passing bays</i> on the Rimutaka Hill road). The corresponding Australian term, at least in Victoria, is <i>overtaking lane</i> (Personal observation).

Date: 0/0/1947
Source: Early Runholding in Otago
Author: BEATTIE
Vol / Page: 11
Edition:
Quote: When I first read this inscription [in the Memorial Church, Cave], the word `sheep-men' made me involuntarily flinch. Years later, when I had forgotten it, I suddenly met it again, and again I recoiled. So aghast was I that I spent weeks collecting every old term for `runholders' I could, and I found thirteen, viz., `flock owners,' `flock masters,' `pastoralists,' `run holders,' `run owners,' `sheep owners,' `sheep holders,' `sheep masters,' `squatters,' `station holders,' `station owners,' `stock holders,[sic] and `stock owners.' The word `sheepmen' is a modern Americanism, and using this anachronism mars a splendid memorial. ... [12] Of all the thirteen terms found in old documents, the word `runholder' was the most used, and it is the word that I think should be substituted.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1948
Source: Run, Estate and Farm
Author: SCOTTER
Vol / Page: 6
Edition:

Date: 0/0/1976
Source: Clyde on the Dunstan
Author: VEITCH
Vol / Page: 43
Edition:
Quote: `Hundreds', an old English word referring to enough land to support a hundred families, was the name given to those large blocks of land which were set aside at appropriate intervals for settlement. `Waste lands' or runs, which lay outside the `Hundreds', were leased by the Government to pastoralists.

The <i>tatata</I> [as-acute] is similar in size to the former, having pending from every part, an infinity of small cords six inches long, of no use or ornament; its origin must be ascribed to the arbitrary taste of fashion,

Date: 30/5/1840
Source: New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator
Author:
Vol / Page: 4
Edition:
Quote: On the brow of a slight acclivity, and overhanging it, they have built a stage or terrace of small boughs, on which they eat and sit during the day.  It is called by them a pataka.
Notes:

Date: 20/11/1850
Source: New Zealand Spectator & Cook's Strait Guardian
Author:
Vol / Page: 4
Edition:
Quote: [From the <i>Maori Messenger</i>] They also explained that the matangohi is sacred, his flesh is never eaten, neither is his head exposed, but the body is hung up in a tree and cut up something like that of a pig, after which his remains are placed on a pataka or stage in a tree and there left.
Notes: Part of serialised journal 'by His Excellency the Governer-in-Chief of New Zealand'.

Date: 0/0/1882
Source: Brighter Britain
Author: HAY
Vol / Page: 2/221
Edition:
Quote: The Patatai (<i>Rallus Philippensis</i>) is a small land-rail, plumaged much like the partridge. <i>Ibid.</I> 225 The Putoto (<i>Ortygometra Tabuensis</i>) is a crake, often confounded by settlers with the patatai. It is a smaller bird altogether, having partridge tints on the back, and a grey breast. It chiefly inhabits raupo swamps.

Author:
Vol / Page: 9
Edition:
Quote: At Ophir and along the sunny side of Raggedy Ridge, wherever the tussock has been destroyed by persistent burning, the ground is becoming covered with the patch plants Raoulia australis and Raoulia parkii, which, however beautiful they may be, so effectually cover the ground, as with a carpet, that the growth of grasses or other fodder plants is impossible where they exist.

Date: 0/7/1979
Source: Dominion
Author:
Vol / Page: 5
Edition:
Quote: MR F N HAYES holds one of two female brown teal or pateke ducks which are being airfreighted to a new home in England ... The pateke is a New Zealand species and was until the 1900s widespread. Since then numbers have been drastically reduced, through habitat destruction and by introduced predators, to a stage where it is in danger of extinction, with less than 1000 birds surviving. The birds will be settled at a wildlife sanctuary.
Notes:

Patent Slip
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a slip for ship repair at Evans Bay
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 9/6/2001
Source: Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page: 29
Edition:
Quote: There was a fierce beauty about its scale, the precision of its movements, the way everything meshed to deliver the raw power to haul ships out of the water at the old Patent Slip in Evans Bay... Wellington Provincial Council let a contract for a slip in Evans Bay in 1868 but wrangling between the council and contractor stalled progress and the job was completed by the Wellington Patent Slip Company in 1873. For the next 96 years the slip hauled 6000 ships up the rails on its concrete incline - a total of more than two million tonnes deadweight.
Notes:

paternity order
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a court order declaring a man to be the father of a particular child.
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Jim Cameron writes : See Family Proceedings Act 1980 s 51. This term does not appear to be in legal use in England and is not recorded in NSOD, Collins or ODL. Before 1968, called an <i>affiliation order</i>. The current English equivalent appears to be a <i>declaration of patentage</i>.

Date: 0/0/1892
Source: NZ Official Handbook
Author:
Vol / Page: 167
Edition:
Quote: Of the sea-fishes that are used as food in New Zealand, we have among the constant residents on all parts of our coast the hapuku, tarakihi, trevally, moki, aua, rock-cod, wrasse, and patiki; and while the snapper, mullet, and gurnet are only met with in the north, the trumpeter, butterfish, and red-cod are confined to the south. ... The following is a list of the fishes which are chiefly met with in the market: hapuku, kahawai, red-snapper, snapper, tarakihi, moki, trumpeter, frostfish ... gurnard, mullet, sea-mullet, ... flounder or patiki, ... grayling, smelt, kokopu, sardine, sprat, eel (tuna), black-eel, conger-eel [168], and silver-eel.

Date: 0/0/1956
Source: NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author: GRAHAM
Vol / Page: 191
Edition:
Quote: NEW ZEALAND SAND-FLOUNDER (PATIKI) <i>Rhombosolea plebeia</i> (Richardson) ... The common Sand-flounder is known from one end of New Zealand to the other, sometimes by other names in different localities. In Auckland it is known as the Dab.../ Some refer to it as Tinplate or Three Corner; the latter name is derived from its fancied trangular shape but why Tinplate I am at a loss to know. To other than fishermen and those intimately connected with the fishing industry it is just a Flounder. Some say it is Tinplate because when cooked it fills a plate.
Notes:

Quote: December is a glorious month of dietary amongst the natives on the coast ... The rivers, large or small, abound in eels, <i>hawera, upukuroro, haparu, patiki</i>, and <i>parauki</i>; ... [fn]<i> Hawera</i> and <i>haparu</i> elude identification. <i>Patiki</i> is the sand flounder (<i>Rhom</i>. sp) and parauki is <i>Paraki</i> smelt (<i>Retropinna retropinna</i>).
Notes: 1848 Brunner Expedition Middle Island in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 293

Date: 0/0/1882
Source: Brighter Britain
Author: HAY
Vol / Page: 2/151
Edition:
Quote: In the bays and tidal rivers are the mango or sharks - the most highly-prized food-fish - the tamure or schnapper, the whapuka or rock-cod, the kahawai or mackerel, the porahi or herring, the kanae or mullet, the patiki or sole, and many others. On the shores are oysters, mussels, cockles, mutton-fish, crabs, and other shell-fish in profuse abundance. In the fresh-water creeks are eels (tuna), lampreys (pipiharau), and whitebait (inanga).
Notes:

Date: 0/6/1921
Source: NZ Journal of Science & Technology
Author:
Vol / Page: 4/122
Edition:
Quote: RHOMBOSOLEA RETIARIA Hutton. <i>Black Flounder; Patiki-mohoao</i>. This species, known generally as `river-flounder,' is occasionally taken in the sea. Common in the estuaries of most large rivers, and often taken many miles inland.
Notes: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes

Date: 0/0/1927
Source: Bibliography of NZ Fishes
Author: PHILLIPPS
Vol / Page: 29
Edition: 1971
Quote: <i>Rhombosolea retiaria</i> Hutton. RIVER-FLOUNDER, BLACK FLOUNDER; PATIKI-MOHOAO.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1956
Source: NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author: GRAHAM
Vol / Page: 204
Edition:
Quote: NEW ZEALAND BLACK FLOUNDER or RIVER FLOUNDER (PATIKI-MOHOAO) <i>Rhombosolea (Adamsoma) retiaria adams</i> Whitley and Phillipps/ It is known to fishermen and those in the fishing industry as the River Flounder as it is caught mostly inside or near the mouths of rivers and enters lakes where it lives chiefly among weeds. To some it is known as the Maori Flounder. I have helped to catch these fish in various rivers in New Zealand, Both in the North and South Islands, from the Bay of Islands, Bay of Plenty, Canterbury and Otago.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1966
Source: Sea Anglers' Guide
Author: DOOGUE & MORELAND

Date: 0/11/2003

Edition:
Quote: The camp shelters were made of patiti (tussock) and taru (grass) woven on sticks and were of a temporary nature merely designed to keep off the rain and wind.
Notes: From Beattie "Traditional Lifeways of the Southern Maori"

Date: 0/11/2003
Source: NZ Geographic
Author:
Vol / Page: No. 66/40
Edition:
Quote: Maori names for tussock varied from region to region. In one southern dialect, <i>wi</i> was used for silver tussock (further north the same word was applied to rushes) and <i>patiti</i> seemed to be a general term for tall tussocks, with <i>maania</i> an alternative or the word for red tussock in particular.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1851
Source: Southern Districts of NZ
Author: SHORTLAND
Vol / Page: 10
Edition:
Quote: The hills [at Otakou] are clothed with wood, or a species of grass (<i>tritium Scabrum</i>), known by the name of `patiti'. <i>Ibid.</I> 19 Species of grass (tritium scabrum), known by the name of `patiti'. <i>Ibid.</i> 195 We now advanced along the plain [towards Moeraki], which was covered with `patiti' and ... stunted fern and `tutu'. These plains are called `pakihi,' a word used in the North Island to signify dried up. So that `tupakihi,' the name by which the `tutu' is there known, appears to be a contraction of `tutupakihi,' or `tutu' of the [196] plains, which are well called `pakihi,' being for the most part arid. 	<i>Ibid.</I> 312 PATITI, a coarse grass growing in tufts (<i>tritium scabrum, Raoul</i>).;
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1870
Source: TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page: 2/177
Edition:
Quote: The soil [on Campbell Island] is very wet ... the surface between the tussocks (Patiti) carpeted with beautiful mosses ... The M'Quarrie cabbage, cotton plant (I have an idea that good serviceable paper might be made from the latter), and wild carrot grow abundantly ...The inevitable Piri-piri appears everywhere. ... [178] Greatest elevation [Antipodes Islands] 700 feet, the hills dotted with high tussock (pa-ti-ti), and patches of M'Quarrie cabbage and cotton plant. ... The albatross here is the `lowland', and lays two eggs.
Notes: (Hector Outlying Islands)

Date: 0/5/2003
Source: NZ Geographic
Author:
Vol / Page: No. 63/57
Edition:
Quote: Opposition questions are generally designed to trip up or embarrass a minister, or at the very least to expose weaknesses in the Government's programme, while Government questions amount to little more than invitations to a minister to deliver a pre-written paragraph of Government spin. Such questions are known as "patsies" or "Dorothy Dix" questions, after an American journalist who wrote a famously platitudinous syndicated column giving advise to the lovelorn.

Quote: In some of the dialects .. [t]here are two forms of the preposition "for," the <i>ma</i> and the <i>mo</i>.   <i>He patu mau</i> would be a thing for you to beat with; <i>he patu mou</i>, a thing to beat you with.

Notes:

Date: 0/0/1929
Source: Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.
Author:
Vol / Page: 9
Edition:
Quote: <i>Patu n.</i> any weapon used in the hand. [Maori]
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1932
Source: Letters & Journals of Samuel Marsden
Author: ELDER
Vol / Page: 86
Edition:
Quote: [?18?] [The chiefs] were armed with their patooes (<i>patus</i>). (dagger) The root idea of the word <i>patu</i> is `to strike.' The word is applied by the Maoris to all weapons, and also, with a qualifying adjective, to pounders and beaters of flax, fern-root, etc. The early explorers, e.g. Cook, restricted the term to weapons of the <i>mere</i> type, and, as a generic term for this group of weapons is useful - in fact necessary - the usage, though not strictly a Maori one, has been followed by modern ethnographers.
Notes: 1932 Elder note to Letters and Journals of Samuel Marsden 86

Date: 0/0/1947
Source: Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.
Author:
Vol / Page: 175
Edition:
