Quote: <i>patu</i> short club of stone, whalebone, etc.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1967
Source: Evil Day
Author: BRATHWAITE
Vol / Page: 380
Edition:
Quote: PATU Club-like weapon, made from stone, bone or greenstone (jade) and occasionally elaborately-carved hardwood. In spite of club-like appearance, it was a short-sword, and with its sharpened edge, could lift the top from a man's skull, or pierce between his ribs with comparative ease.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1804

Date: 0/0/1814
Source: Letters & Journals
Author:
Vol / Page:  92 and fn [=hoeroa]
Edition: 1932
Quote: The battle then became general. A number of women were in the heat of the action, among whom was Tippahee's old wife, not much less than seventy years of age, and Duaterra's wife bearing in her hand a patoo about seven feet long, made out of the jawbone of a whale. [fn] This weapon, the <i>hoeroa</i>, was made almost invariably of whale bone. All specimens extant are made from the lower jaw of the sperm whale. Both ends are rounded, one end being elaborately carved; there is often, also, some carving about the middle. About five feet in length, it seems to have been used, for the most part, as a missile weapon. - <i>Vide</i> Elsdon Best, <i>The Maori As He Was</i>, p.276 <i>et seq. </I>
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1814
Source: Letters & Journals
Author: MARSDEN
Vol / Page: 91
Edition: 1932

Notes: [(for Patus) PATU; with useful note] (Griffiths Collection)

Date: 0/0/1814
Source: Letters & Journals
Author: MARSDEN
Vol / Page: 86 and fn
Edition:
Quote: The chiefs were all seated on the ground, according to their custom, and their warriors standing up with their spears fixed upright which were from 15 to 20 feet in length and upwards. They were armed also with their pattooes (<i>patus</i>). [fn] The root idea of the word <i>patu</i> is `to strike.' The word is applied by the Maoris to all weapons, and also, with a qualifying adjective, to pounders and beaters of flax, fern-root, etc. The early explorers, e.g. Cook, restricted the term to weapons of the <i>mere </i>type, and, as a generic term for this group of weapons is useful - in fact necessary - the usage, though not strictly a Maori one, has been followed by modern ethnographers.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1817
Source: Voyage Round the World
Author: NICHOLAS
Vol / Page: 1/69
Edition:
Quote: patoo patoo. [J.C.A. notes `the form has long been discarded. Moreover it is not duplicated' cf Nicholas's <i>kiki</i> `food' (kai).] <i>Ibid.</I> 1/89 The men in the canoes ... exhibited ... mats, spears, hooks, fishing-lines, thread, <i>patoo pattoos</i>, (war implements,) for all which they received many useful articles in return. <i>Ibid.</I> 2/337 A war club Pattie

Date: 14/5/1990
Source: Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page: 100
Edition:
Quote: To [the locals], the most striking thing about these foreigners was their white skin. This feature was a characteristic of creatures known to them as Patupaiarehe, the fairy-like inhabitants of the forest. These white-skinned beings of the imagination were also known as pakepakeha and pakehakeha. These words are the direct antecedents of the word Pakeha. There is nothing pejorative about this derivation of the meaning and use of the word Pakeha to denote the white strangers who came to these shores in the 18th century.
Notes:

pavlova
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a meringue dessert cake, for which the first recipe was published in 1929 in New Zealand.
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Note on conversation with Deidre Macken (60 yrs) about her mother's story (86 yrs). She was in the Wellington Ballet Company in 1926 and on news of Pavlova's tour wrote to her manager enquiring how they could help make her tour and reception more pleasant, her favourite colours, foods, etc. She expressed a great liking for meringue (cakes) so they consulted a chef who produced 3 attempts (e.g. a square cake was rejected in favour of a round one); finally the `soft-centre' variety was chosen. In her honour they named it Pavlova (?cake) and they presented this to Pavlova (? at a gathering) and she liked it a great deal. D. Macken is to research this - ? Ballet company records, etc. Deidre Macken (04) 384-6073 -  H.D. Macken, Nairn St.
Citations
Date: 2/2/1999
Source: Dominion
Author:
Vol / Page: 00
Edition:
Quote: The Editor,The DominionPavlova - Name and NatureSir, -- In spite of silly claims regularly surfacing especially in Australia (Dominion 2/2/99), the facts of the development of the confections and the date the name `pavlova'  was applied to them have been reasonably well known for some years now. They may be found in the Dictionary of NZ English (1997), the Australian National Dictionary (1988), and the writings of Professor Helen Leach of Otago University.The name `pavlova' post-dated the ballerina Pavlova's Australasian tour of 1926, and was first applied in New Zealand by the Davis Gelatine Company in 1927 to a jelly dessert whose moulded multicoloured shape may have suggested a tutu. It was next (in 1929) applied independently (and only  in NZ) as `pavlova cake' or `sponge' or `meringue' to the previously well known so-called `meringue cake' or `sponge'. The recipe change to the legendary pavlova icon is usually reputed in NZ to be the addition of vinegar to give the soft centre, and in Australia, the trademark of passionfruit in the topping. (The name `pavlova' does not occur in either the Futter book (1926) or the Terrace Tested Recipes (1927) mentioned in your report.)The elliptical simple form `pavlova' for the meringue is recorded earliest in Australia from 1940 (so AND, two of whose quotations acknowledge NZ as the originator) and in NZ from 1953 (DNZE).There is no evidence that the name `pavlova' was applied in Australia before 1940.  Both countries share the earliest recorded date 1966 (and the same quotation) for the abbreviation `pav'.The New Zealand Dictionary Centre at Victoria University (Box 600, Wellington) would be glad of any pre-datings of any of the above, with author, title, date, and page references.Harry Orsman
Notes: Check date of publication. "Terrace Tested Recipes collected by the Ladies of Terrace Congregational Church" was published by Whitcombe & Tombs in 1927 (191 pp). There were three editions in 1927; the first is held by Turnbull, the 3rd was held by Te Papa (Hector Library) but recent report (HO) says they no longer have it.

Date: 18/5/2002
Source: Dominion Weekend Magazine
Author:
Vol / Page: 5
Edition:
Quote: Contrary to what they'll tell you in Perth, Western Australia, Bert Sache, a chef at the Esplanade Hotel did not invent the pavlova. All he did, in 1935, was to make a meringue and cream cake that he said was "light as Pavlova", the Russian ballet dancer who six years earlier had stayed at the hotel. but the name stuck and thus was born the myth about its origins. The truth is that the large meringue with the marshmallow centre - the heart of the pavlova - was common in New Zealand in the early 1930s, even earlier. In 1927, for instance, there was a recipe for a meringue cake submitted by a Mrs McRae in the second edition of <i>Terrace Tested Recipes</i>, collected by the ladies of the Terrace Congregational Church in Wellington.
Notes:

Date: 0/3/1991

Quote: <i>Pavlova</i> [heading below a coloured picture of a fluted (`pleated' or `tutued') turned-out moulded jelly mound, coloured in layers from top to bottom green, white, orange-yellow, and red, and standing on a plain dish, with no background] <i>Ingredients </i>1 1/2 cups hot water/ 1 cup orange juice/ 1/2 cup milk/ 3 dessertspoons Davis gelatine/ 6 dessertspoons sugar/ Flavouring/ cochineal - sap green colouring <i>Directions </i>Dissolve all but a teaspoonful of Gelatine ... Date: 0/0/1928
Source: Davis Dainty Dishes
Author:
Vol / Page: 11
Edition:
Quote: <i>PAVLOVA </i>... hot water ... orange juice ... milk ... Davis Gelatine ... sugar ... Flavouring ... Cochineal - sap green ... serve with cream or custard ...
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1937
Source: Davis Dainty Dishes
Author:
Vol / Page: 57
Edition:
Quote: Pavlova. 6 Servings. Ingredients. Davis Gelatine, Hot water, Sugar, 1/4 cup milk, Slices of oranges, 3/4 cup orange juice, Lemon essence, Vanilla essence, Cochineal, Green colouring, Citric acid. Method. First layer: Dissolve 1-1/2 teaspoons gelatine and 1 dessertspoonful sugar in 1/2 cup hot water; add a pinch of citric acid and lemon essence to flavour. Divide the mixture, colour one half red and the other green. Pour the green into a mould. Second layer: Dissolve 1 teaspoon gelatine in 2 tablespoons hot water. Add 1 Dessertspoon sugar to 1/4 cup milk; stir until dissolved. Flavour with vanilla essence. Add gelatine. Carefully pour on to the green layer, which must be firm. Third layer: Dissolve 1 dessertspoon gelatine in 1/4 cup hot water, add 3/4 cup orange juice, 3 dessertspoons sugar or more. When the milk layer is firm, arrange orange circles round the mould and add the orange jelly, which should be thickening a little at a time. Fourth layer: Re-melt the red jelly, if it has set, by standing in hot water. When cold pour over the orange layer, which should be firm. <i>If setting in an ice-chest or refrigerator, use less gelatine - First mixture: 1 teaspoon. Second mixture: 3/4 teaspoon. Third mixture: 3/4 dessertspoon. </I>
Notes: 1937 Davis Gelatine Organisation Davis Dainty Dishes [editions 1-8 1922 to 1936] 57

Quote: It comes as a shock to realise that this all-Australian dessert was in fact first given its name in New Zealand. The great ballerina, Anna Pavlova, toured Australia and NZ in 1926, providing the occasion for the creation of this new dish. "Light as meringue, light as whipped cream", you can hear the chef saying. The first citation is from NZ, in a 1927 booklet put out by Davis Gelatine called <I>Davis Dainty Dishes</i>.

Date: 0/0/1982
Source: Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery
Author: BURTON
Vol / Page: 131
Edition:
Quote: Pavlova is more than a national dish, it is an institution. ... Sweet, airy and laden with calories, the cake was named after Anna Pavlova who visited New Zealand in 1926. ... It is worth mentioning here that the Australians claim to have invented the pavlova, and insist that it was created in honour of Pavlova by a Melbourne woman in 1926. New Zealanders, however, might answer that in the same year a pavlova recipe appeared in a book entitled <i>Home Cookery for New Zealand </i>(although it went under the name of `Meringue with Fruit Filling') and that another recipe actually called `Pavlova' was published the following year. Certainly the classic kiwkfruit (Chinese gooseberry) topping which the Australians have also adopted must belong to New Zealand.
Notes:

Date: 1/1/1987
Source: Otago Daily Times
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote: I would to point out that both the Irish version and the Australian recipe are for a -->meringue cake (sugar and egg whites) and not for the traditional New Zealand pavlova which has a -->soft centre, because of the inclusion of vinegar and cornflour in the N.Z. recipe. I don't think we'll ever discover who had the original idea which transformed a hard oversweet dessert into the delicious dessert of today. I was at University in Dunedin from 1928 to 1932, and well remember my mother making pavlova during the summer holidays - the latest popular recipe from a fellow-member of the local Croquet Club - probably 1928-1929. I remember how carefully she watched over the oven and then turned it onto a plate - almost holding her breath.
Notes: 1987 Jan 1 N. M. THOMSON in Otago Daily Times p.c. `Prester John'

Date: 2/3/1985
Source: Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page: 46
Edition:
Quote: I have for many years cherished the heretical theory that the reason for the lack of any of the distinctive flavour in much of the food served in New Zealand can be traced to the national devotion to Pavlova Cake. This sugary confection has, for most adult palates, all the charm of heavily-scented shampoo folded into well-beaten shaving cream.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1933
Source: Cookery
Author: FINLAY
Vol / Page: 125
Edition:
Quote: No. 452.- MERINGUE SPONGE SANDWICH OR PAVLOVA CAKE. ...Whites of 3 eggs/ 7 or 8 ozs. Sugar/ Pinch of Salt/ 1 Teaspoon vanilla essence/ 1 Teaspoon vinegar/ Suitable tins, 8in. diam. Sandwich tins or special Pavlova cake tin. Method.- Add salt to egg whites. Whisk them stiffly; add sugar gradually and continue beating for a few minutes. Carefully mix in vinegar and essence. Place in greased tins and cook in a slow oven for 1 to 1 1/2 hours. [When cooked, turn out carefully. Fasten cakes together with a filling of whipped cream. Some tart fruit such as raspberries or loganberries may be added to the cream. Cream nay also be piled on top, finishing off with fruit used in centre.]
Notes: c1933 Finlay Cookery 125

Vol / Page: 10

Quote: Pavlova cake has for so many years been a staple of any party ... [`Urumoa' writing from Oamaru searched old recipe books and found] 1. Meringue cake, copied from the Otago Daily Times of June 26, 1934. This is the same as the modern pavlova without the one teaspoon of cornflour. 2. `Cookery' by Miss I. Finlay [see preceding entry], published by the Dunedin City gas department, third edition, about 1933. ... recipe No. 452 for meringue sponge sandwich or pavlova cake, for which I was surprised to see she suggested sandwich tins or a special pavlova tin. When I bought one of the latter recently I thought they were something new! 3. Two privately-published but undated recipe books from Invercargill which must be pre-1933, as we left the city in that year. Both contain recipes for pavlova. [But do they specify the name `pavlova' ? HWO] It would be interesting ... to find out when the teaspoon of vinegar and teaspoon of cornflour were added to the recipe as they give pavlovas their marshmallow-type centre. The recipes I have mentioned list only egg whites, sugar, vanilla and a pinch of salt. Author:
Vol / Page: 21
Edition:
Quote: Pawing is when a dog - in a close encounter of the woolly kind - uses a forepaw to push onto a sheep's nose and force it back. In the North Island runoff at Hawera in 1918, W E Whyte's Boy penned a stubborn trio by pawing the front sheep and literally pushing it into the pen.

Quote: ... the way to ask for a truce in a game is to call Pax ... At the school I went to, the word was <i>Fritz</i>, and the truce was terminated by the call <i>Fritz all over</i>, but we knew that some schools <i>used</i> Fans <i>(from south-west English dialect fain I </i>or <i>fainits ?</i>). Apparently some New Zealand schools use or have used <i>baldy</i>, which sounds like a variant of English <i>barley</i>.

Quote: <i>PEACH A L'AUSTRALIAN </I> Line a mould with Florence paste ... leave paste in moulds till cold ... turn out ... whipped cream ... put a teaspoon in each half of shape, place half a cooked ... peach .. royal icing coloured with carmine, force a border round each half of shapes ... put halves together ... glaze with a glace ... dust over icing sugar ...

If you supply more milk at the height [peak] of the production season you force the company to install more and bigger plant and you therefore help pay for that extra requirement by buying more Peak Notes .. farmers are struggling with all of the rules that impact on Peak Notes and there is a fundamental inequity in the system.

peanut
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a (usually disparaging or derogatory) name for a small, petty, or insignificant thing or person.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: 1949 R Mason `anything undersized, small of its kind' ca 1952 March R.Mason quotes an owner describing his small Renault car as a `peanut'. -- ca 1960's `peanut politician' used disparagingly of a person who (often rather selfimportantly) makes his life's work gaining elective office to minor committees (school committees etc) - Wellington.

peelie
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a marble
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1984
Source: Yesterdays in Maoriland
Author: KEITH & MAIN
Vol / Page: 288
Edition:
Quote: Marbles were the currency of childhood and there were an astonishing number of names for them, some referring to the material or colour, others to value or function in the game. There were agates, aggies, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cats-eye, [sic] chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, mollies, peelies, peewees, pisswees, pretties, Scotties, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers and whities. The march of technology added ball bearings - ballies or steelies - which were unbeatable when it came to smashing an opponent's miserable glassie. World War II[roman] brought `clayeys' often imperfectly spherical they were pathetic terracotta substitutes for real marbles.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1972
Source: Folkgames of Children
Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page: 174
Edition:
Quote: Marbles had a language of its own. There were names for the marbles, the games, and all the various aspects of the play. There were terms for marbles such as `taw' or `shooter', referring to the marbles used to fire with; `dubs', `dates', `stakes', `dukes', or `changers', referring to the marbles put down to be fired at. Then there were the terms referring to particular kinds of marbles: for example, agates, aggies, aggotties, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cat's eyes, chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, molly-bars, mulley-bars [mullibars: large marbles], peelies, peewees, piss-wees, pretties, Scotties, Scottish alleys, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers, white alleys, and in more recent years ball-bearings, chippies, plastics, and woodies.
Notes:

Vol / Page: 173
Edition:
Quote: Cross-cut saws have what is called a peg-tooth and cut both ways. It is a great improvement to sharpen every fifth tooth, counting from the centre to the ends, as a drag tooth, that is, a tooth filed square across and with a considerable hook, this arrangement tends to keep the cut clear of sawdust.

Vol / Page: 113
Edition:
Quote:  `The jade, the pounamu ... It's a beautiful stone ... Look,' he said, holding up a long hooked ear-drop of pearly translucence, `that's tau tau and the stone is called inanga. And this, the pekapeka - they say the shape comes from the bat. This is for the ear, too - the mako, like a shark's tooth ... And these,' - he ran his fingers along a row of ... nephrite adzes - `toki. See this one' - he held the heavy red-mottled adze in his palm - `that's the red kind, totoweka, woodhen's blood. The deep green, that's kawakawa.'

Date: 0/0/1838
Source: New Zealand  (Polack)
Author: POLACK
Vol / Page: 2/417
Edition:
Quote: These vessels are fitted with tryworks or fire-places above which is a battery containing two, and sometimes three iron pots, sufficiently capacious to contain from one hundred and fifty to two hundred gallons each; the fire-place is built of bricks, so laid below as to form channels for water to preserve the floor or main deck from injury. The water is kept confined by a square, formed with a two-inch plank, around the sides, negligence in leaving this pen (as it is termed) dry, has caused many accidents; ... These fire-works are taken down when the cargo is completed, ...

Date: 0/11/1933
Source: Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page: 15
Edition:
Quote: <i>Pen</i>.- (1) A small yard; a division in the sheep-holding part of a woolshed. (2) Shearers catch out of a p., and when they apply for work they ask for a p. `Will you keep me a <i>p</i>. for next year, boss?' is often their farewell. Two shearers usually catch out of one pen and are called <i>p.-mates</i>.
Notes:

pen
Homonym Number: 2

Author: OGONOWSKA-COATES
Vol / Page: 97
Edition:
Quote: <i>Pen</i>. A small fenced-in area. The sheep-holding part of a wool shed is divided into pens connected to the board by a swing door. Shearers catch their sheep out of these pens, which are usually shared, the shearers being pen-mates.

Citations
Date: 0/0/1958
Source: Sheep.  Part 1, Sheep husbandry
Author: STEVENS
Vol / Page: 113
Edition:
Quote: It is not uncommon to find that fleeces which have a high expression of staple character also have lean or pencil type staples, particularly on the fore-arm and the britch. Wool buyers and their manufacturers have no objection to these pencil staples, but with breeders they find little favour, and a sheep is expected to produce meaty staples throughout the fleece.
Notes:

Date: 0/4/2000
Source: NZWords
Author:
Vol / Page: 8
Edition:
Quote: There are two small rocky, peaty islands, some islets and rocks in the group, which is a protected reserve where landings are not allowed, although visiting tourists can cruise close to the coastline in inflatable rubber boats, seeing Snares penguins by the hundred.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1955
Source: Emu, The
Author:
Vol / Page: 53(2) : 187
Edition:
Quote: The Snares Penguin is thus nameless, and to remedy this I propose the following: <i>Eudyptes robustus</i> sp. nov. ... Head jet black, paler on the crown, remainder of upper surface bluish black, each feather having a narrow central streak of pale blue. A rather narrow pale golden yellow band begins near each nostril, passes over the eye and ends in a backwardly and downwardly projecting crest.
Notes:

Date: 24/8/1988
Source: Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page: 21
Edition:
Quote: Canterbury has its own distinctive penguin, the white-flippered penguin, which is a local variant of the Little [sic] blue or fairy penguin found only in New Zealand and Australia. It is slightly heavier than the northern Little blue penguin, and has a distinctive white band along both edges of the flippers. They breed only on Banks Peninsula, Motunau Island and the neighbouring coasts.

Date: 0/0/1889

Author: PARKER
Vol / Page: 119
Edition:
Quote: `The Penguins are characteristic Southern Hemisphere sea-birds, being represented in the Northern by the Puffins. They are flightless, but their wings are modified into powerful fins or flappers. Among the most interesting forms are the following - the King Penguin, <i>Aptenodytes longirostris</i>; Rock Hopper P., <i>Pygoscelis taeniatus</i>; Yellow-Crowned P., <i>Eudyptes antipodum</i>; Crested P., E. pachyrhynchus; <i>Little Blue P., E.</i> minor <i>and</i> undina.'

In addition to filling up the catching pens, he weighed the bales and recorded them, with their descriptions in the wool book. <i>Ibid.</I> 130 The shearers were, of course, the autocrats of the shed, but the `sheep-oh' (penner-up) also held an important position. In addition to filling up the catching pens, he weighed the bales and recorded them, with their descriptions, in the wool book. <i>Ibid.</I> 208 At shearing time [at Benmore, 1892] about 55 men were employed in the shed: 28 to 30 shearers, 2 penners-up, 4 pickers-up, 2 broomies, 6 rollers, 1 classer, 1 fleece carrier, 4 piece sorters, 3 pressers, 1 bale brander, 1 butcher and brander.

penny doctor
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:the larva of the tiger beetle
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: The most widely known game with insects is a game named variously by T.C. students as Butcher Boys (Gisborne, New Plymouth, Kaponga, [405] Te Pohu, Newall, Sth. Wellington), Butcher Bats (Ohau, Takaka), Penny Doctor Beetles (Tauranga, Pipiriki, Rotorua), or Fishing (Morunui). It is a game in which straws which have been suitably moistened with spittle are placed in an insects [sic] hole and are flicked out when the insect bites the end of the straw. Most of the reports of this practice come from the North Island, though it was known in the South as early as 1900 (Waikouaiti).

Citations
Date: 0/0/1942
Source: Maori Place Names
Author: ANDERSEN
Vol / Page: 451
Edition:
Quote:  The larva [of the tiger beetle] is also known as the penny-doctor among boys, [who catch them by putting grass straws in their burrows].
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1951
Source: Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page: 60/93-107
Edition:
Quote: <i>Penny Doctor</i> beetles, also known as `Butcher bats' is a game widely reported by Wellington Training College students as being played in many parts of the North Island. In this game straws moistened by spittle are pushed down the hole of the appropriate beetle. The beetle seizes the end of the straw. When the player feels the straw moving he or she flicks out the beetle. The player who can catch the most beetles wins the game.
Notes: 1951 JPS 60/93-107 (Sutton-Smith) in 1972 Sutton-Smith Folkgames of Children 328

Date: 0/0/1967
Source: Animals of NZ, The
Author: NATUSCH

Date: 8/12/2001
Source: Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page: 48
Edition:
Quote: Andrew Cuningham.. wonders about "the end of the penny section". This literally means the far reaches of the main urban transport route through a city or town which used to cost one penny in the gold [sic] old days. Once you've reached the end of the penny section, you are heading for the suburbs. However, the expression is also used colloquially to mean the end of the easy stuff or the end of the golden weather. Once you're out of th penny section, you have to pay more, or, in this sense, work a bit harder.
Notes:

Date: 22/2/1888
Source: Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page: 3
Edition:
Quote: I have ridden in their 'busses [sic] on several occasions and have each time noticed the dissatisfaction expressed to the guard by the patrons of their line at the charge of 3d demanded from passengers getting in at any part of Molesworth-street, quite irrespective of the distance they may wish to go, even though that distance may only be to the Government Buildings, and this in contradiction to their announcement of the 16th instant, stating that on and after the 17th instant 'busses would run "penny sections, the same as Tram Company."

pension
Homonym Number: 1

Sense Number:
Definition:

Domain:[none]

See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1980
Source: Ghost Towns of NZ
Author: McGILL
Vol / Page: 93
Edition:
Quote: Fred has the `pensions' used for fantan, round metal discs with a square hole in the middle, and a `dew nappy', the ivory half-ball that the game was played with. Pensions were put on the four corners of the card, or points between, and two people took the bank. Even money was paid on the corners and three to one in the middle. There would be several hundred pounds sometimes waiting on the half-roll of the dew nappy.

Date: 0/0/1978
Source: Oxford Book of NZ Plants
Author: MOORE & IRWIN
Vol / Page: 40
Edition:
Quote: <i>NOTOTHLASPI ROSULATUM.</i> The penwiper plant, like <i>Ranunculus haastii,</i> grows on South Island scree slopes ... The leaves form a neat circular rosette, ... in appearance much like the now forgotten penwipers made of overlapping strips of soft cloth on which Edwardian writers wiped the ink off their steel-nibbed pens.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1980
Source: Tussock Fever
Author: McLEOD
Vol / Page: 251
Edition:
Quote: ... everywhere I walked I found a dozen penwiper plants. This lovely little rosette grows in deep, cool shingle ...where its long roots ...feed the huge flower head which rises and scents the air as strongly as carnation or gardenia.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1988
Source: Forest Vines to Snow Tussocks
Author: DAWSON
Vol / Page: 191
Edition:
Quote: The best known scree species is the penwiper plant (<i>Notothlaspi rosulatum</i>) ... which belongs to the cabbage family (Cruciferae). Its rosettes of grey, fleshy leaves closely overlap in a dome-like arrangement, which reminded early settlers of the similarly arranged and sewn together diamonds of felt on which they wiped their quill pens.
Notes:

Date: 0/9/2001
Source: NZ Geographic
Author: No. 53/35
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote: Unlikely as it may seem, many fascinating plants, including the distinctive penwiper, <i>Notothlaspi rosulatum</i>, not only survive but flourish amid the shifting screes and windswept gullies far above the treeline. Ibid. 42 One scree specialist found in eatern parts of the Southern Alps from Marlborough to Canterbury, the attractive penwiper (<i>Notothlaspi rosulatum</i>), grows in a rosette of grey leaves which blend perfectly with their surroundings.
Notes:

See:pipi

Citations
pepino
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:The cultivated tropical South American shrub muricatum, fam. Solenaceae, with sweet juicy, pale cream to orange fruit with longitudinal purple stripes; also known as Peruvian melon, melon shrub, melon pear; introduced into NZ before 1940.

Date: 0/0/1988
Source: Lexicographical & Linguistic Studies
Author:
Vol / Page: 195
Edition:
Quote:  /p |pi:n u/. N.Z. & Austral. [S. Amer. Sp. (Peru).] (See quot. 1968.) 1968 J.C. Th. UPHOF <i>Dict. Economic Plants</i> (ed.2) 490/2 Solanum muricatum Ait. Pepino (Solanaceae). Herbaceous plant. Subtropics. Origin probably Peru. Cultivated in Centr. and S. America. Often sold in markets. Fruits frequently seedless, round to long, greenish yellow with purplish red blotches, juicy, agreeable flavor, somewhat aromatic, crisp; eaten raw. 1980 <i>Ann. Appl. Biol.</i> XCIV. 61 Pepino mosaic virus .. was found in fields of pepino (Solanum muricatum) in the Canete valley in coastal Peru. 1981 <i>Southern Horticulture</i> (N.Z.) Spring 16/1 Group three: blueberries, feijoas, avocado, tamarillos, cherries, babaco, persimmon, Asian pears, macadamias, pepino etc. 1984 <i>Sydney Morning Herald </i>4 Sept. (Good Living) 1 Pepino or Melon Pear or Melon Shrub - a shape and size simialr to an apple cucumber ... Good for decorating dishes such as pavlova and fruit salad, because when sliced the hollow centre and surrounding flesh look like a wheel.
Notes: Burchfield

Citations
Date: 0/9/1852
Source: Leisure Hour, The
Author:
Vol / Page: 640
Edition:
Quote: Stray notes on Australia and the Diggings (Griffiths Collection) Origin of the word `Nugget'. - This word, now so common amongst our population, is a strange sounding word, and destitute of any apparent entymological meaning. It originated at the Ophir diggings in New South Wales, and is probably a corruption of `ingot', which is itself a corruption of `lingot', a little tongue. The wedge of gold which Achan purloined is called, in the original Hebrew, a `tongue' of gold, as a reference to a Bible with marginal readings will show. In California, the word `lump' is generally used, and sometimes the Spanish word `pepite.'
Notes:

Quote: REDSHANK (<i>Polygonum persicaria</i>) is also called persicaria, spotted persicaria, knot weed, smart weed, willow weed, and lady's thumb. Perhaps also it is this weed that on the west coast of the South Island is called water pepper or Walker's weed. It is an annual weed of gardens, crops, and wet pastures.

pepper tree
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:1. see kawakawa. 2. see horopito
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:also pepper
Pronunciation:
Notes: also pepper		assign 1958 Jan NZTJ 46/2 and 1946 JPS 149 1. <i>Drimys</i> (formerly <i>Wintera</i> or <i>Pseudowintera</i>) spp., esp. <i>D.axillaris, </i>and south of Rotorua, <i>D. colorata</i>, =horopito, =Maori painkiller.

perch
Homonym Number: 2
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a measure
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/1/1999
Source: NZWords
Author:
Vol / Page: 2
Edition:
Quote: The use of perch as a square measure in New Zealand - one fortieth of a rood - may be noted.   NSOD gives this as 'rare, except historical'.   It became historical here only in 1968 with the advent of metrication, and was until then anything but rare. The area of every piece of land that could not be expressed simply in acres or roods was described in perches. The word occurred in thousands of land titles, and was used to define the size of any section smaller than the quarter-acre 'norm'. Perch as a linear measure on the other hand (as in NZPOD) I have never seen outside the backs of school exercise books!
Notes:

Percy
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:Geol., see cit.
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/2/1981
Source: Geological Society of NZ Newsletter
Author:
Vol / Page: 51/21
Edition:
Quote: 1980 saw the introduction of a new stratigraphic parameter, the Percy.  No longer do geologists illustrate the scale of the outcrop photographs with such mundane objects as hammer, lens caps, 2 cent pieces and bananas.  If in the forefront of geological technique they now take as an essential item of field equipment, Percy Strong.  Such is Percy’s usefulness as a unit of stratigraphic thickness, and so great is the magnetism of his image on screen, that one lecturer introduced his choicest slide with the pronouncement “that’s Percy”, and only then proceeded to describe the rocks.  It is understood that Cathy, with callous disregard for the visual effect on her husband’s figure, is knitting for Percy a cap-a-pie jumpsuit with 100 horizontal stripes so that thin-bedded sequences may be measured in centi-Percies (cPe); and further that Percy himself now steers clear of field trips in areas of steeply-dipping strata, to avoid the necessity of being photographed in a horizontal position in stream beds.
Notes:

Perendale
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number: 1
Definition:a New Zealand-bred sheep developed in the 1940s and 1950s from Cheviot and Romney genes [after geneticist Professor Peren.]
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:Rural
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:

Author: BROOKING
Vol / Page: 91
Edition:
Quote: In 1960 a society was formed in order to standardise type and promote the breed which was named the Perendale in recognition of the founder's work.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1991
Source: What Sheep is that?
Author: WARMAN
Vol / Page: 24

Quote: The Coopworth like the Perendale, belongs to the new generation of New Zealand bred sheep.

Date: 0/0/1997
Source: Sheep Breeds of New Zealand
Author: MEADOWS
Vol / Page: 70
Edition:
Quote: Professor Peren developed Perendale, the breed subsequently named after him by crossing selected Cheviot rams with Romney stud ewes, and then continuing to breed with the progeny to fix the type.

Notes:

Date: 26/4/1987
Source: Dominion Sunday Times
Author:
Vol / Page: 1
Edition:
Quote:  `Perfing out' for [dollars]80,000 [heading] The number of seemingly fit police quitting the force with average payouts of [dollars]80,000 under recently introduced medical discharge provisions is being criticised within police ranks. A total of 125 officers have been granted medical disengagement on the grounds they are no longer able to carry out police work. Several have then taken up similar investigative work in the private sector. The medical option is colloquially known within the police as `perfing out', based on the acronym of the scheme's original name - police employment rehabilitation fund.

peripatus
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 11/12/1912
Source: Otago Witness
Author:
Vol / Page: 68
Edition:
Quote: His slug is not a slug, but aperipatus... The peripatus is like a slugin general appearance.
Notes:

Date: 26/11/1988
Source: Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page: 42
Edition:
Quote: "We would find wetas and peripatus. Do you know peripatus?... It's a very pretty creature with a crushed velvet body, greyish green - its whole body undulates beautifully - it's the missing link between the worms and the anthropods [sic] like crayfish or woodlice. It's segmented but each segment has a pair of small stumpy legs with two tiny claws."
Notes:

Date: 0/4/2000
Source: NZ Geographic
Author:
Vol / Page: No. 46/60
Edition:
Quote: It is most commonly called peripatus - from the same Greek root as <i>peripatetic</i>, meaning itinerant or wandering... The animal is also called the velvet worm or walking worm - references to two of its more obvious traits. Peripatus are found largely in the southern hemisphere - in Australasia, south-east Asia, Africa and Central and South America. <i>Ibid.</i> 66 I have to roll my peripatus onto its back again to view the circular, lobe-lipped mouth with double pair of sickle-shaped mandibles, and the two lumpy "gun turrets" - oral papillae - used to such effect in the capture and consumption of prey. Both the jaws and oral papillae, as well as the antennae, are pairs of modified limbs. Peripatus are opportunistic and will scavenge in preference to expending energy on hunting. <i>Ibid.</i> 74 Peripatus may boast a lineage more ancient than that of New Zealand's other, more famous, "living fossil," the tuatara. Early marine animals, such as this 500-million-year-old fossil from the Burgess Shale in British Columbia, appear remarkably similar to living onycophorans... <i>P. novaezealandiae</i> females.. have been found to carry embryos at all stages of development at all times of year, and to give birth regardless of the season, albiet more abundantly in summer.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1987

Author: SINCLAIR
Vol / Page: 128
Edition:
Quote: The Perishable, introduced some time during the mid-twenties, was an express goods train that ran between Christchurch and Greymouth - in both directions - on six nights of the week. As well as its usual duties, the train provided a convenient weekend service for Canterbury Mountaineering Club members travelling to Arthur's Pass.

Date: 0/0/1947
Source: Native Animals of NZ
Author: POWELL
Vol / Page: 26
Edition:
Quote: PERIWINKLE (<i>Melarhaphe oliveri</i>). A most abundant shell on high tidal rocks throughout New Zealand. It seldom grows larger than three eighths of an inch and is bluish white with a broad spiral band of bright blue. ... This is a true periwinkle, but that name is frequently applied locally to other shellfish, some of the top-shells and the cat's-eye.

The word originated on the floor of the factory but the practice is not confined to that area. Those who make a habit of perking don't consider it dishonest but factory owners disagree and waste time and effort trying to stamp it out.

Notes:

Date: 0/0/1898
Source: Austral English
Author: MORRIS
Vol / Page: 347
Edition:
Quote: <i>Perpetual Lease,</i> though a misnomer, is a statutory expression in New Zealand. Under the former Land Acts, the grantee of a perpetual lease took a term of thirty years, with a right of renewal at a revalued rent, subject to conditions as to improvement and cultivation, with a right to purchase the freehold after six years' occupation.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1902
Source: Settler's Handbook of NZ, The
Author:
Vol / Page: 24
Edition:
Quote: No. of Area in Holders. Acres. 3. Lands held on perpetual lease .. .. 120 13,008 4. Lands held as leaseholds in perpetuity .. 1,000 191,150

[He= William Rolleston].

So named because they were first brough here by Peruvian sailors, peru peru are unusual long-shaped tubers that have a delicious flavour similar to new potatoes, and are marbled with purple to varying degrees inside. You might also see them labelled as <i>urenika</i> potatoes.

peter
Homonym Number: 2
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:orig. a half-gallon or gallon demijohn used to hold draught beer; thence a half-gallon, flagon of draught beer. =half-gallon jar, =flagon, =jar, =half-g cf Blue Peter.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: ca1930's Canterbury (J. Columbus) originally blue peter, a chemist's blue jar of about three-quarter gallon ca1940 R.Byrne (1951) `Can also refer to half-gallon DYC vinegar flagons popularly used for collecting draught beer'

Author: FORSTER
Vol / Page: 2/220
Edition: 1982
Quote:  We saw a great Variety of bird this day viz. A white & sooty Albatross (<i>Diomedea exulans & palpebrata</i>). The black & sooty Petrel, (<i>Procellaria aequinoctialis & fuliginosa</i>) the black banded Petrel (<i>Procellaria vittata</i>); the small white rumped Petrel (<i>Proc. pelagica</i>) & we saw likewise three times a <i>Port Egmont Hen</i>, which is commonly thought a mark of the vicinity of Land. [ed. fn] The birds listed here are, respectively, the Wandering Albatross; Light-mantled Sooty Albatross; White-chinned Petrel; Great-winged Petrel; <i>Pachyptila</i> spp; Wilson's Storm Petrel and Antarctic Skua. .

phalanger
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:2
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 28/6/1988
Source: Auckland  Star
Author:
Vol / Page: 1
Edition:
Quote:  `I believe that the member for Tarawera is referring to the possum (Trichosurus vulpecula), not opossums (genus Didelphis) which are American marsupials,' [Agriculture Minister Moyle] said in his written reply. ... And for the name, you can be forgiven if you call our imported possum (the `brushtail possum,' to be precise) an opossum. The Aussie possum - there are about six types across the Tasman - looked so much like the American counterpart when first discovered by Europeans that it was called an opossum. As recently as 1981, scientists who turned up for the first New Zealand symposium on marsupials ... were sagely talking about possums in 12 of the papers presented while their colleagues talked about opossums in six papers. All were referring to the same nocturnal nuisance. One of the great achievements of that symposium was to finish up talking the same language after taking a vote that favoured for possum. ... The fur trade is pushing for `NZ phalanger' (a generic name for a group of marsupials) while possum stew exporters are trying to win acceptance for `Kiwi bear' in Oriental restaurants.
Notes:

Date: 25/3/1851

Author:
Vol / Page: 1/80
Edition:
Quote: [The Waikato] runs through ... deep fern fringed with raupo (a bullrush) ...[sic] and the magnificent toi-toi, a gigantic grass whose flower stalk is from 8 to 12 feet and has an exquisite feather of two feet long playing in every air. This grass is ... with the phormium tenax the most remarkable of the open country vegetable products. ... You see many native dwellings & many canoes for they are a most locomotive people, few as ignorant of all but their own kainga as our British Hodge. There are troops of wild ducks & shags, some hawks of large size, bitterns & smaller waterfowl unknown to me.
Notes: (J.C. Richmond)

Date: 0/0/1898
Source: Austral English
Author: MORRIS
Vol / Page: 350
Edition:
Quote: <i>a little child</i>. The word is certainly not Australian. It comes from the West Indies (Cuban <i>piquinini</i>, little, which is from the Spanish <i>pequeno </i>small, and <i>nino</i>, child). The English who came to Australia, having heard the word applied to negro children of the aborigines. After a while English people thought the word was aboriginal Australian, while the aborigines thought it was correct English. It is pigeon-English. [1696: Aust 1830] <i>[351] used as adj. and figuratively, to mean little</I>
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1817
Source: New Zealand (various authors/titles)
Author: NICHOLAS
Vol / Page: 2/171
Edition:
Quote: This fellow [a native servant] ... met me ... telling me that Mrs. King had got a <i>pickeeninnee</i>, (a child) he began to describe her groans ... while ... under the pains of labour; ... <i>Ibid.</I> 1/280 All the inhabitants flocked around us ... and the mothers, pointing to the children they carried in their arms, called out to us repeatedly, <i>homi pickeninnee wow,</i> which means, give the child a nail; ...

Date: 0/0/1981
Source: Fisherman's Bible
Author: WILSON
Vol / Page: 35
Edition:
Quote: BAITFISH, RED <i>Emmelichthys nitidus:</i> A less common species in New Zealand waters this fish turns up unpredictably in vast schools that give the water a red appearance - and the fish its name. Grow up to about 16 inches and known also as picarel, pearl fish and red herring. Colours light pink to dark red.

Citations
Date: 31/3/1917
Source: Camps, Tramps and Trenches
Author: MILLER
Vol / Page: 49
Edition:
Quote: At about 11.15 every morning we go through a piece of agony known as `Piccadilly'. All the New Zealanders in [? Sling] camp, three to four thousand strong, march along a certain section of the road in column of fours. On either side are about sixteen Sergeant Instructors, beautiful fellows, their superb figures almost bursting through their London tailor-made tunics. Their duty and pleasure it is to blast us up in a loud voice for any little irregularity of deportment they may notice or think they notice ...... The camp Commandant and half a dozen of the sherangs dressed in their best ... take the salute.
Notes: nf OED. P5.

Date: 21/10/1933
Source: Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page: 15
Edition:
Quote: When a shearer finishes a sheep, the <i>f</i>. is left lying on the <i>board</i> (q.v.). It is <i>picked up</i> by a boy (the <i>f.-p.</i>), who carries it to a table throws it out flat to be skirted, rolled and classed. The verb, to<i> f.-pick</i>, means `to be a fleece-picker'. To <i>p. up</i> is to do the actual <i>job. </i>
Notes: Acland Glossary

Author: MIDDLETON

Date: 0/0/1964
Source: Collected Stories
Author: SARGESON
Vol / Page: 302
Edition:
Quote: picking up fleeces: the rouseabout (shearer's hand) picks up the newly-shorn fleece, throws it so that it lands spread out on the table, pulls off the short and dirty wool which had been under the belly (<i>bellies</i>), rolls the fleece and puts it into the press. Nowadays the shearer usually shears the belly separately before starting on the fleece.
Notes:

Quote: <i>Picking up</i> The process by which a planing machine produces planed timber which has a hairy surface. This may be the result of blunted or wrongly angled planing knives or reverse grain or tension wood in the timber, or a combination of these. Such hairiness is very hard to eradicate.

pickle
Homonym Number: 2
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:in New Zealand, preserves including separate pieces of fruit or vegetable
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 15/5/2004
Source: Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page: 46
Edition:
Quote: Pickle can usually be used in a broad sense to encompass any food that is preserved in brine or  vinegar, which explains the use of the word by supermarkets to mark the relevant aisle. However, in traditional New Zealand preserving, the word pickle is usually reserved for preserves in which the pieces of fruit or vegetable remain separate, most obviously in onions and gherkins, but also in chow chow and picalilli in which the vegetables are preserved in a thickened mustard sauce.
Notes:

If he was still aboard, the pick-up man came forward on his quick, obedient horse and plucked him expertly from his turbulent mount. A rider could find himself down across the saddle...or with back hard against the shoulder of the pick-up's horse.

Date: 0/0/1982
Source: Perano Whalers
Author: GRADY
Vol / Page: 228
Edition:
Quote: <i>Pick-up boat </i>- The boat used for picking-up whales killed by whale-chasers. The pick-up boat would then tow the whales to the whaling station for processing. Sometimes, if the mother ship was not available for pick-up work, a spare chaser or the one with the least work on hand would take on the task of picking up.
Notes:

picnic
Homonym Number: 1
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:awkward adventure, unpleasant experience, troublesome job.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1898
Source: Austral English
Author: MORRIS
Vol / Page: 351
Edition:
Quote: <i>Picnic, n.</i> Besides the ordinary meaning of this word, there is a slang Australian use denoting an awkward adventure, an unpleasant experience, a troublesome job. In America the slang `an easy or agreeable thing.' (`Standard.') The Australasian use is an ironical inversion of this. -->1896. Modern: -->`If a man's horse is awkward and gives him trouble, he will say, `I had a picnic with that horse,' and so of any misadventure or disagreeable experience in travelling. So also of a troublesome business or other affair; a nursemaid, for instance, will say, `I had a nice picnic with Miss Nora's hair.'' [Check: omit ?]
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1943
Source: English as it is spoken in NZ
Author: BENNETT
Vol / Page: 90
Edition:
Quote: The expressions `too true,' `too right,' in which<i> too</i> has its old intensive value, are in common use; so are `that'll be a picnic', `what a picnic' (where <i>picnic</i> = `trouble, bother')

Quote: <i>pie</i> good, <i>pie on</i> expert or efficient, good at, from Maori `pai', good, `pai ana', suitable; eg `That paint job was pie on, ta muchly.'
Notes:

Author: DIEFFENBACH
Vol / Page: 2/376
Edition:

Quote: ... some 7 per cent of this freezing works wool is produced from the skin ..... In the past these skin pieces were rotted and the wool recovered, since skin rots faster than wool. The process was unpleasant and the wool (known as `pie' wool) often suffered fibre damage.'

Date: 0/0/1957
Source: Canterbury Frozen Meat Company
Author: MACDONALD
Vol / Page: 69
Edition:
Quote:  Some mention should be made of `pie-wool'. This is the wool from pieces which are trimmed off the woolly skin, and are not `painted' with depilatory. Pie-wool is loosened by allowing the skin to putrefy, a repulsive and laborious job, and after separation the wool is washed and dried.
Notes:

Vol / Page: 96
Edition:
Quote: <i>Fleece</i>. The main part of the sheep's wool when shorn. It is picked up in one piece and carried to the wool table, where it is skirted and classed. The small bits and pieces that are cut off separately by the shearer are the locks, bellies and pieces.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1901
Source: TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page: 33/`196
Edition:
Quote:  ... the latter is always skirted and classed, whereas the black fleece was rolled up just as taken from the sheep's back, the belly-pieces being also left in. ... For example, white wool divides, when skirted by the roller at the wool-table, thus: Belly pieces, say, 6d. per pound; first pieces, 8d. per pound; ... fragments or locks, 4d. per pound.
Notes:

Quote: <i>Rhipidura flabellifera</i> Gm. Pied Fantail.
Notes: Myers Endemic Birds

Date: 0/0/1946
Source: Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page: 55/156
Edition:
Quote: <i>pi[i]wakawaka</i>, a bird (Rhipidura flabellifera), pied fantail: the so-called black fantail, which is chocolate-colour (R. fuliginosa) is ti[i]wakawaka. The former is common throughout Newzealand; the latter is common in the South Island but rather rare in the North and is thought to be a mutant of the former. Both names were applied to both birds by the Maori, but for distinction pi[i]wakawaka for the pied and ti[i]wakawaka for the black have been adopted by the Pakeha. The bird is noted for the disaster it caused to Maui in his struggle with the mother of night, Hine-nui-te-po, Death personified.
Notes: Andersen Maori Words in English

Date: 0/0/1966
Source: Birds of New Zealand
Author: FALLA et al.
Vol / Page: 198
Edition:
Quote: FANTAIL <i>Rhipidura flabellifera</i> Maori name: Piwakawaka. ...  Birds of normal colour pattern (`Pied Fantail') make up most of the population in North Island, but the `Black Fantail' (i.e. dark phase) accounts for perhaps a quarter of the population of the South Island subpecies; ...
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1985
Source: Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds
Author:
Vol / Page: 280
Edition:
Quote: Fantail <i>Rhipidura fuliginosa</i> (SPARRMAN, 1787)  North Island Fantail <i>R.f. placabilis </i>BANGS, 1921. South Island Fantail <i>R.f. fulginosa</i>  (SPARRMAN, 1787). Chatham Island Fantail <i>R.f. penitus</i> BANGS, 1911. OTHER NAMES: <i>Piwakawaka, pied  fantail, black fantail. </i>

Pierce's Disease
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: viticulture

Citations
Date: 31/3/2001
Source: Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page: 28
Edition:
Quote: Pierce's Disease, the latest outbreak of agricultural pestilence to rattle the West, is relentlessly tearing through Californian vineyards, worrying winemakers around the world, not least in Australia and New Zealand, for whom California's wine culture has long been a source of inspiration and grapevines... Pierce's Disease is caused by <i>Xylella fastidiosa</i>, a bacteria that lives in the xylem of plants, the thin layer beneath the surface that transports water and nutrients from the roots.

pig fern

Sense Number:
Definition: = HARD FERN (<i>Paesia scaberula</i>), called also ring fern, silver fern
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: [nf dicts] ca1953 Oct R. Mason notes (p.c.) that it has been known by that name in Wellington since at least the mid-1930's to M.White and Margaret Fyfe and that M.M. Small, Wildlife branch, states that it is general in country districts, and usually the only name used. Pigs root for the rhizomes. ?d Tramper 26 (1) 4

Quote: The New Zealand wild pigs supposedly descended from farm animals brought here by James Cook gave rise.. to the coloquial but unflattering <i>Pig Islands</i> (or less logically <i>Pig Island</i>), which is found from 1906, and is well known.. from James K. Baxter's.. poem sequence <i>Pig Island Letters</i> (1966). A <i>DNZE</i> citation from 1946 reports <i>Pig Island</i> as an Australian usage, but there is no entry for it in <i>AND</i>.

Quote: Christchurch appointed itself cultural capital and, pretty soon, those snooty southerners took to calling the north Pig Island, because of its introduced wildlife and the prevalence of pigfern, which sprang up after bushfires and felling.

pigeonwood
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:pigeon(-)wood arborea, Poro kaiwhiri(a), Poporo kauwhiri(a); also called poro-kaiwhiri; a small tree bearing long red berries
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: [1919 July 29] Ver.(WB). = Vernacular names used by settlers, supplied by W. Best, Otaki (And) <i>Hedycarya arborea</i> pigeonwood [a1927] Ver. = Vernacular names heard by J.C. Andersen from sawyers, settlers, etc. (And) (Stony Bay) <i>Hedycarya arborea</i> pigeon wood; a1926 Story Bay, Banks Peninsula (Vernac). (Long, orange-red berries, presumably attractive to pigeons: cf <i>Pigeonberry</i>)

Date: 8/10/1896
Source: Otago Witness
Author:
Vol / Page: 5
Edition:
Quote: Strong barbed wire with the barbs closer than usual is generally used for pig fences. Strong wire netting fastened to posts may serve, but the barb fence is the most reliable. About five or six of these wires, placed not more than 5in apart, well stretched and stapled to stout posts, should be sufficient to check the exploring tendencies of any ordinary and reasonable pig.

Date: 0/0/1906
Source: TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page: 38/545
Edition:
Quote: Congiopodus leucopoecilus, [sic] <i>Richardson. </I> The fish is popularly known as `pig-fish', on account of the grunting noise it makes when taken out of the water and has to gasp for air. It is sometimes called `leather-jacket', a name which, however, is more correctly applied to [<i>Navodon] scaber</i>, another very common fish in Otago Harbour.
Notes: (Thomson, Otago)

Date: 0/6/1921
Source: NZ Journal of Science & Technology
Author:
Vol / Page: 4/121
Edition:
Quote: CONGIOPODUS LEUCOPAECILUS (Richardson). <i>Pigfish; Puramorua</i>. Large numbers commonly sold throughout the year in Christchurch under the name of `silver trumpeter.' Rarely seen in Dunedin markets unless other fish are scarce. ... Distribution: South Island and southern coasts of North Island.
Notes: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes

Date: 0/0/1927
Source: Natural History of Canterbury
Author: SPEIGHT
Vol / Page: 201
Edition:
Quote: The Soldier-fish (<i>Scorpaena cruenta</i>) and the variegated horror with the droll name of Hapuka's Grandfather (<i>Helicolenus percoides</i>) are members of the same order, as also are the Pig-fish (<i>Congiopodus leucopaecilus</i> ) and the Toad-fish (<i>Neophrynichthys latus</i>) whose names appropriately suggest something out of the run of ordinary fish shapes.
Notes: Archey `Native Fishes of Canterbury'

Vol / Page: 112
Edition:
Quote: Pigfish <i>Congiopodus leucopaecilus</i> (Richardson)
Notes: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 112

Date: 0/0/1956
Source: NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author: GRAHAM
Vol / Page: 350
Edition:
Quote: PIGFISH (PURAMORUA) <i>Congiopodus leucopaecilus</i> (Richardson) ...This fish is sometimes called Leather-jacket by many fishermen, probably on account of its leathery skin, but this name is misleading as the proper and popular Leather Jacket is a smaller fish with a tough rough and leathery skin and with one single spine on its back. Many years ago these fish were sold to the public in large numbers but only for a short period when others were exceptionally scarce. scarce. The fish were skinned so that they looked quite different from the fish in its natural state. They were then railed to a country town and sold readily under the name of Snap Jacks or Skip Jacks.
Notes:

Edition:
Quote: <i>Red pigfish Bodianus vulpinus</i> Named from its elongated snout, although `pigfish' is more properly applied to fishes of a different family.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1982
Source: Collins Guide
Author: AYLING
Vol / Page: 252
Edition: 1984
Quote: <i>RED PIG FISH</i> (Pig wrasse, pakurakura) <i>Bodianus vulpinus (Bodianus oxycephalus, Verreo oxycephalus</i>) [253] The long pointed snout ... and forward projecting, fleshy lips suggested the name pig fish for this species.

Pigroot
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:(the Pigroot) the inland road (State Highway 85) from Palmerston, north of Dunedin, into Central Otago, originally a trail followed by 19th-century goldminers. [probably from the presence of wild pigs in the area]
Origin:[none]
Register:

Date: 0/0/1889

Quote:  Only think how much more graceful all the landscape will appear. / No more pigroots, whalebacks, hogbacks - these names that shall not last; / ... <i>Negro-heads</i> shall be re-christened. I for one will take no heed, / While to me there yet remaineth Negrohead, the fragrant weed.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1944
Source: Maori Place-Names of Otago
Author:
Vol / Page: 8
Edition:
Quote: No map the collector has consulted has shown Pigroot Hill or hotel, and yet it is the most prominent and most used name between Palmerston and Kyeburn. Again and again the collector has heard the remark, `I am going into the Central by the Pigroot,' or `I came down by the Pigroot.' So frequently is it used that one might imagine that certain people used it thinking that the word `root' is in reality `route,' but be that as it may, common usage is the deciding factor in place-names, and Pigroot, with its associations back into the fifties, has come to stay. The name was originally [9] bestowed because the wild pigs rooted up the hillside looking for the roots of the taramea, or speargrass, which they enjoy eating, and which is probably one of the main reasons why speargrass is so rare nowadays.
Notes:

Date: 15/10/1864
Source: Otago Witness
Author:
Vol / Page: 8
Edition:
Quote: (Reprinted from the <i>Molyneux Mail</i>) Mr. Kilgour.. has called for tenders to remove and re-erect his premises from the Pigroot to this place.

Date: 0/0/1926
Source: Weeds of New Zealand
Author: HILGENDORF
Vol / Page: 1967
Edition: 66
Quote:  WIREWEED (<i>Polygonum aviculare</i>), also called road weed, mat weed, knot grass, `pig weed,' and hog weed, is common in cultivated land all over the country. It is an annual, with stems up to 2ft. in length trailing over the ground. The stems have swollen nodes (`knot grass') and are very tough (`wireweed').

Date: 0/0/1973

Vol / Page: 102

Date: 0/0/1981
Source: Loughnan Glossary
Author: LOUGHNAN
Vol / Page: 61
Edition:
Quote: .. In a farming context it is usually a sugarbag made into an extemporised rucksack with some rope or a strip of flaxleaf. It can also be a chaff-sack, closed at both ends, and one side slit across at the centre and used with this side uppermost. Thrown across, either under or over the saddle, the two large saddlebags thus formed could be used to bring home some wool plucked from a dead sheep, or as a sheltered place to carry a weakling lamb.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/2001
Source: NZ Memories
Author:
Vol / Page: June/July  12
Edition:
Quote: The couple were loaned an old horse and went off home with a pikau loaded up with meat, vegetables and fresh bread. 3.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1990
Source: Wild Horses & Me
Author: WATTS
Vol / Page: 52
Edition:
Quote: They would arrive about lunchtime with peacows slung over their saddles. A peacow is a chaff sack, sewn up at both ends with a slit made across the centre of one side of the sack. When slung over the saddle it formed two large pockets in which the men carried their 'glad rags' or best clothes.
Notes:

Edition:

Vol / Page: 34
Edition:
Quote:  Dad led the pack horse, and a troop of us youngsters followed on our ponies (bareback), each with a pikau laden with goods. Occasionally an unevenly balanced pikau would slide off, taking the unlucky rider with it. ... Mum supervised the unpacking of the cases [of big stores orders]. Certain packages and parcels were placed in her pikau, ... <i>Ibid.</I> 66 After removing our pikaus, saddle bags and swag, we unharnessed the horses and turned them loose in the `house paddock'.

Date: 0/0/1946
Source: Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page: 55/155
Edition:
Quote:  `Connected with pick-a-back' This is incorrect <i>pikau</i> seems to have Polynesian cognates. The word itself may have been associated with <i>pickaback</i> by English speakers.
Notes: cf 1946 J.C. Andersen Maori words

Date: 0/0/1834
Source: New Zealand (various authors/titles)
Author: MARKHAM
Vol / Page: 42
Edition: 1963
Quote: I crossed a Stream a dozen times, mostly on a Mans back called a (Pekow [<i>pikau</i>] is to carry Upanga [<i>hapainga</i>], lift me up.) [1963 fn] Though the meaning of this sentence is fairly clear, punctuation and syntax are even more defective than usual: <i>pikau</i> means to carry on the back; <i>hapainga</i> is the passive form of <i>hapai,</i> lift up, raise.

Date: 0/0/1970
Source: Way Up North
Author:
Vol / Page: 8
Edition:
Quote: Stories are still told of the prodigious loads they would carry over the hills in their pikaus. <I>Ibid.</i> 33 Still another sack made the standard haversack type of container with shoulder straps for carrying loads on the back. This essential piece of equipment was invariably called a pikau, a Maori word meaning to carry on the back, but also used in either language as a noun.

Date: 0/0/1936
Source: Cookery Book of NZ Women's Institutes
Author:
Vol / Page: 107
Edition:
Quote: Pikelets. One breakfast cup wholemeal, dessertspoon brown sugar, 1 egg, 1/2 teaspoon soda, 1 cup or more milk, 1oz butter or little cream, last 1 teaspoon cream of tartar. Pikelets. Beat 2 tablespoons of sugar with 1 egg till light and frothy. Add scant cup of milk, 1-1/2 cups of flour, 1 teaspoon cream of tartar, 1/2 teaspoon soda. Mix well together and then add 1 tablespoonful hot water and 1 tablespoonful of butter (water and butter are secret of light pancakes). Drop in spoonfuls on greased girdle or oven tray.
Notes: [3rd??? recipe also in 1955 edn]

Vol / Page: 102
Edition:
Quote: PIKELETS (2)/ Beat 2 tablespoons of sugar with one egg till light and frothy. Add scant cup of milk, 1[1/2] cups of flour, 1 teaspoon cream of tartar, 1/2 teaspoon soda. Mix well together then add 1 tablespoonful hot water and one tablespoon of butter (water and butter are the secret of light pancakes). Drop in spoonfuls on hot greased girdle. [cp.] SCOTCH PIKELETS (1) ... 2 cups flour, 2 eggs, 1/4 cup sugar, 2 teaspoons cream of tartar, 1 dessertspoon syrup, 1 teaspoon baking soda, small piece of butter, 1/2 teaspoon salt, 1/2 cup milk. Beat well and cook on hot girdle.

Date: 0/0/1985
Source: Botanist at Bay
Author: SHERWOOD
Vol / Page: 26
Edition:
Quote: The words flew, and enriched Celia's [an English visitor's] vocabulary. `Duck shoving' was the local name for buck-passing between government departments. A `Queen Street farmer' was a city slicker who owned land or stock for tax-fiddle reasons. `Skite' and `drongo' were terms of abuse. A `cow-cockie' was a dairy farmer and inferior for some reason to a `runholder' concerned only with sheep. A `piker' was a faint-hearted person who gave up the fight too soon, ...
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1986
Source: NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary
Author:
Vol / Page: 569
Edition:

Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote: So to cope with the rituals of tramping ... a slang language has developed to suit. ... `Crud' (cloud), `bush-bash', a `gunn' tramper (which must have originated from Davy Gunn's famous trek up the Hollyford Valley to help victims of a plane crash in 1936 ...[Not so: HWO]), `windfall' (a collapsed pile of trees), `pit' (the tramper's true friend, a sleeping bag), `pog' (porridge), `bastard grass' and `lawyer' (two unpleasant plants), `piker' (one who stayed home), `Huey' (all-powerful god of weather) ...

Date: 0/0/1960
Source: Tangahano
Author: KEINZLY
Vol / Page: 114
Edition:
Quote: `Aw, come on. Have a beer.' 'No thanks.' `Piker! Ya old man will.'
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1988
Source: Hills, The
Author: PICKERING
Vol / Page: 8
Edition:
Quote: So to cope with the rituals of tramping, its pains and camaraderie, a slang language has developed to suit. Lots of quick short words to fit in the breathless pauses as you pant uphill. `Crud' (cloud), `bush-bash', a `gunn' tramper (which must have originated from Davy Gunn's famous trek up the Hollyford Valley to help victims of a plane crash in 1936; he travelled 40 km by rowing boat, horse and foot in 21 hours), `windfall' (a collapsed pile of trees), `pit' (the tramper's true friend, a sleeping bag), `pog' (porridge), `bastard grass' and `lawyer' (two unpleasant plants), `piker' (one who stayed home), `Huey' (all-powerful god of weather), and many, many more.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1843
Source: Travels in NZ
Author: DIEFFENBACH
Vol / Page: 1/369
Edition:
Quote: Protestant natives regard their Roman Catholic brethren as belonging to the devils: they are called pikipo, which M. Pompalier explained as being derived from <i>episcopus</i>, which seems to me the most probable derivation. The Protestant missionaries however, say that it means piki-po - always bowing [370] - (piki, bend - po, night). The Protestants, therefore, call their bishop pihopa, while the Roman Catholics have retained the title pikipo for theirs.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1930

Vol / Page: 99

Notes:

Date: 0/0/1936
Source: Treaty of Waitangi
Author: BUICK
Vol / Page: 118fn
Edition:
Quote: In his discussions with the Maoris, Bishop Pompallier had stresed the point that he held the advantage over the Protestant missionaries in that he was a member of the Episcopacy. The best attempt on the part of the natives to render into their own language the word Episcopos, in its varied forms, was <i>pikopo</i>, hence the Bishop and his converts became known as <i>Pikopo</i>.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1903
Source: TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page: 35/319
Edition:
Quote:  ...<i> large numbers of aua or kataha</i> (Agonostoma forsteri); <i>about 60 lb. ... weight of pilchard or mohimohi (Clupea sagax),</i> two varieties; ... hundreds of young red-cod, rarii (<i>Lotella bacchus</i>), and what I believe are young rock-cod, or kokopu or rawaru (<i>Percis colias</i>). The red-cod were from 3 in. to 4 in. in length, and the rawaru, or, as the natives here call them, `toitoi' or `panepane', from 2 in. to 6 in. long.
Notes:  Mair Fish in Piako River

Date: 0/0/1926
Source: TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page: 56/314
Edition:
Quote: There appear to be three species of fish belonging to the family Clupeidae in New Zealand waters, viz., <i>Engraulis antipodum</i>, or anchovy; <i>Sardinia neopilchardus</i>, or pilchard, and <i>Harengula antipoda</i>, or sprat. <i>Ibid.</i> 316 The sprat is the smaller of the two, but in the numerous notices of these fish, the name `sprat' probably includes in many cases immature pilchards. <i>Ibid.</i> 319 In the case of fish-stomachs examined at the station, sprats have been found in red cod, blue cod, southern king-fish, barracouta, and spined dog-fish; and pilchards in barracouta.
Notes: (Young and Thomson)

Date: 0/0/1970
Source: Nomenclature of NZ Fish
Author: SORENSON
Vol / Page: 10
Edition:
Quote: <i>ANCHOVY </i>(a) Scientific name: <i>Engraulis australis</i>. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Anchovy. (c) Other common names: the following names of related Clupeids and Engraulid fish are sometimes applied to anchovy - Herring, Sprat, Sardine, Pilchard, although the true Herring of European waters (<i>Clupea harengus</i>), does not occur in New Zealand. (d) Principal localities where taken: Hauraki Gulf, Gisborne, Tasman Bay, Marlborough Sounds. <i>Ibid.</i> 40 <i>PILCHARD </i>(a) Scientific name: <i>Sardinops neopilchardus</i>. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Pilchard; Sardine. (c) Other common names: Sardine; Sprat; Anchovy; Herring. (d) Principal localities where taken: Auckland, Gisborne, Tasman Bay, Marlborough Sounds.
Notes:

Author: HAMILTON

Edition:
Quote:  ...,with the following results: 581 eels (from 1ft. to 4ft. in length); 8 dozen flounders, of various sizes, large numbers of aua, or kataka (mullet); about 70lb. or 70lb. weight of pilchard, or mohimohi; a few snapper and kahawai; hundreds of red cod and rarii; and a number of kokopu or rawaru.

Date: 0/0/1956
Source: NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author: GRAHAM
Vol / Page: 104
Edition:
Quote: PILCHARD (MOHIMOHI) Sardinops neopilchardus (Steindacher) The Pilchard is known from the northern end of the South Island as the Picton Herring, and off Picton large shoals of these fish have from time to time been recorded. It has no relation to the so-called New Zealand Herring or Yellow-eyed Mullet (Agonostomus forsteri).
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1986
Source: NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author: PAUL
Vol / Page: 40
Edition:
Quote: <i>Pilchard Sardinops neopilchardus</i> ... Sometimes called the sardine. Also occurs around southern Australia. ... In the 1880s a fishery in the Marlborough Sounds produced salted and smoked `Picton Herring', and small fisheries have developed briefly elsewhere. ... Pilchard are caught for groper bait (`bloater'), and have been used also for tuna.
Notes:

Domain:[none]

Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1967
Source: West Coast Gold Rushes
Author: MAY
Vol / Page: 244
Edition: 1962
Quote: It was a matter of nice judgement. The digger recognized four classes of payable ground: `tucker ground' kept him in food with nothing to spare; a `wages claim' gave him a pound or two above living expenses; a `riser' was a rich claim; and a `piler' or `homeward bounder' the richest of all. Probably most of the `pilers' were beach-claims, where the leads were shallow and rich, the outlay small and provisions cheap because of easy access.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1947
Source: Bright Fine Gold
Author: HEINZ
Vol / Page: 200
Edition:
Quote: <i>Pilers</i>: See CLAIMS below.(?) ...  <i>CLAIMS </i>Worthless claims or ground were called schicers or duffers. Those yielding up to [pounds]3 per week per man were known as `tucker' claims; up to [pounds]8 per week were known as `wages' claims; above [pounds]8 were known as `pilers'; the richest of all were known as `Home-ward-bounders.'
Notes:

Quote: In the `Dream of the Shagroon', which bore the date Ko Motinau, April 1851, and which first appeared in the Wellington Spectator of May 7th, the term `Pilgrim' was first applied to settlers; it was predicted in it that the `Pilgrims' would be `smashed' and the `Shagroons' left in undisputed possession of the country for their flocks and herds.
Notes: (Pratt)

Date: 7/5/1851
Source: NZ Spectator
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote: [1851 Apr 19 Lyttelton Times `Government might have founded a colony composed of stragglers from other settlements, of whale-fishers and stock-drivers, but would they have persuaded a body of English gentlemen to transfer their homes to these shores?' The following was written in reply:] `Dream of Shagroon' [title] I saw men of another aspect arrive at the pilgrim-land. ... The Pilgrims looked with contemptuous eye on this people of strange aspect and impure blood, and did despise them. ... I awoke - and lo! the land which was to have been sacred to the orthodox foot only of a `body of English gentlemen', was in possession of the `stragglers, the whalers, and the stock-drivers from other settlements'. Alas! for the goodly land, - the land of the Canterbury Pilgrims.
Notes: 1851 May 7 NZ Spectator and Cook's Strait Guardian (Wellington) in 1947 Reed Story of Canterbury 111

Date: 0/0/1859
Source: Story of New Zealand, The
Author: THOMSON
Vol / Page: 2/188
Edition:
Quote: ... it is worthy of notice, that the colonists, soon after the formation of all the settlements, acquired distinguishing epithets; thus there was an Auckland cove, a Wellington swell, a Nelson snob, a Taranaki exquisite, an Otago cockney, and a Canterbury pilgrim. These epithets, already forgotten, are too characteristic to be buried in oblivion, as each originated in some peculiarity of the leading colonists. The Otago settlers derived theirs from their ignorance of the country in which they lived; the Auckland people from their extensive Sydney connexions; and the origin of the other names are sufficiently obvious without explanation.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1886
Source: Stray Leaves
Author: HART
Vol / Page: 7

Date: 0/0/1898
Source: Austral English
Author: MORRIS
Vol / Page: 353
Edition:
Quote: Canterbury Pilgrims, The first settlers in Canterbury, New Zealand, were so called in allusion to the pilgrims to the shrine of St. Thomas Becket. Chaucer's `Canterbury Tales' were told by such pilgrims. The name was given probably by Mr William Lyon, who in 1851 wrote the `Dream.' See quotation, 1877.

pillar
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: mining

Citations
Date: 0/0/2000
Source: Dream of Nikau Jam, The
Author: HAWES
Vol / Page: 85
Edition:
Quote: To get the coal out, you divvied the seam up into 'pillars' a square chain wide. Then you drove alleyways called 'bords' to the very back of the pillar and you worked back towards the main shaft, taking 'lifts' off the pillars as you went... As you worked at the pillar - picking, shotfiring, shovelling an' that - it got thinner an' thinner until in the end it looked like a big black tornado, or a tree holding up the sky. That's why the last strand of the pillar is called a 'mahuta'.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1901
Source: NZ Illustrated Magazine
Author:
Vol / Page: 4/612
Edition:
Quote: When the seam is worked out in this way the question of taking out the remaining blocks of coal, or pillars arises.

Date: 0/0/1928
Source: Dawn Beloved
Author: DEVANNY
Vol / Page: 169
Edition:
Quote:  ... drives were broken off at right angles to [the dip heading] at distances of two chains apart ; thus forming pillars on either side of the dip, two chains square. These drives were called main levels. The bords were driven about two chains off the dip, and the `stenton' would be driven from the lower level to the one above.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1935
Source: Gold Mining Year Book
Author: BLYTH
Vol / Page: 11

Date: 0/0/1906
Source: Mining Handbook
Author:
Vol / Page: 417
Edition:
Quote: The system of work [in the Grey coalfield] is mainly by bord and pillar, a small portion only of this coal having been worked by the longwall method. In the bord-and-pillar system the bords are 18ft. wide, and pillars 14 yards thick. The pillars are left intact until the boundary of a section is reached, when they are worked back. The roof has in [418] main proved good, enabling a large percentage of the pillar-coal to be won.

Quote: Some of the timber trees are of large growth, particularly three sorts; the first is of the pine tribe and is known by the name of Pimise (Pinus??) in three varieties on the north. The second is something like the Lucombe Oack, and the third is called the Red Gum or Eucalipticus I have seen it in England. ... The three varieties of pine are very tall and handsome, and one in appearance like the Lucombe oak grows tall but not so straight, the Eucalipticy grows to a great thickeness in the stem and frequently not less than fifteen feet in girt but not more than 15 or 20 feet in height before it spreads its large branches in every direction, ...

pin dip
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1981
Source: History of Children's Play
Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page: 223
Edition:
Quote: Pin dips were also another popular amusement. `A pin or a bull or a button, To see a rary rary show show show!' (1875; Tahataki). A piece of glass backed by cardboard was covered with a piece of paper that could be flicked up to show the `rary rary show' or had a slit in it through which one could peep. One saw through the glass a variety of colors, pieces of colored paper, flower petals, pictures, and later pieces off cigarette boxes. Sometimes these had been arranged in some pattern, at other times they were kaleidoscopic only, and the perceiver had himself to add the configurations of intelligibility. The price for the view was always a pin `which we did not want anyhow but always accepted,' a relic from an age when such things were rare. Pin dips were known also as `poppy shows' (perhaps it was the similar flash of color that gave the same name - `the poppy show' - to the exciting experience of seeing a girl's dress blown upward by the wind; pins were not charged for flowers of this sort). In fact, the pin dip or the prick book may have developed from the poppy show. The poppy show was common before 1900 and the prick book after that date, a fact connected with the ever-increasing stock of picture cards and magazine pictures available to children.
Notes:
