pine
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:indigenous pine unspecified
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:kauri pine, screwpine, etc.
Pronunciation:
Notes: kauri pine, screwpine, etc.		In general Maori-derived names have been replacing the -pine names, at a slower rate for the South Island, and probably slower for the names of the timbers as distinct from the trees.
Citations
Date: 0/0/1826
Source: Journal
Author: SHEPHERD
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote: [?a podocarp] Some of the timber trees are of large growth, particularly three sorts; the first is of the pine tribe and is known by the name of Pimise (Pinus??) in three varieties on the north. The second is something like the Lucombe Oack, and the third is called the Red Gum or Eucalipticus I have seen it in England. ... The three varieties of pine are very tall and handsome, and one in appearance like the Lucombe oak grows tall but not so straight, the Eucalipticy grows to a great thickeness in the stem and frequently not less than fifteen feet in girt but not more than 15 or 20 feet in height before it spreads its large branches in every direction, ...
Notes: 1826 Shepherd Journal in 1940 Howard Rakiura 356

Date: 0/0/1981
Source: History of Children's Play
Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page: 117
Edition:
Quote: The <i>tawheras</i> that had been missed had dried and shrivelled, and the white of the <i>tiore</i> had decayed, but the fingers of the `gentlemen' had swollen considerably and now provided us with New Zealand `pineapples.' The really good ones were eight inches long and two-and-a-half inches in diameter. They were wrenched out in the same way as giggies. These `pineapples' were never very much sought after by the general public. They needed what might be called an acquired taste. They were tricky eating too. You bit off all the outside hard, nobbly but not prickly covering, and then gnawed the soft, sweet flesh to the bone.
Notes: 1880 Taranaki in Sutton-Smith History of Children's Play (1981) 117

Date: 0/0/1926
Source: TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page: 662
Edition:
Quote:  From the leaves of the rimu Cook brewed `spruce beer', and the black-pine [matai] furnishes a beverage known to bushmen as `pine-beer'. The tree containing beer may usually be known by a black, smutty-looking stain that extends some way up the trunk; and if a hole be bored at the base the tree may be plugged and tapped like a barrel.
Notes: (J.C. Andersen Popular Names)

Notes:

Date: 0/0/1946
Source: Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author: ANDERSEN
Vol / Page: 55/155
Edition:
Quote: <i>pingao</i> , sea-shore plant (Scirpus frondosus), tumble-weed, after the stiff-spined globular seed-heads: the leaves, drying a bright-orange much used for plaiting ornamental girdles and for tukutuku (lattice-work) becoming rare, is the most robust ... of these [sanbd binders].
Notes: Andersen Maori Words in English

Quote: MYIOMOIRA TOITOI. (NORTH ISLAND TOMTIT.) ... <i>Native names</i>. Miromiro, Komiromiro, Pimiromiro, Ngirungiru, Pingirungiru, and Pipitori}. ... [40] Its note in the early morning is like the Maori syllables <i>ngi-i-ru, ngiru-ngiru,</i> from which it derives its name, the first syllable being rather prolonged. <i>Ibid.</I> 1/42 MYIOMOIRA MACROCEPHALA. (SOUTH-ISLAND TOMTIT.) <i>Native names</i>. Miromiro, Komiromiro, Pimiromiro, Ngirungiru, Pingirungiru, and Pipitori. ... pinhooker
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: US usage in OED : 1944 Richmond (Virginia) Times-Despatch 5 Oct. 18 The fixation of prices this year is bad business for the time-honoured 'pinhooker', the man with relatively small operating capital who, during the more spacious days of tobacco selling when the auctioneer got the green light for a sale from wall to wall, bought tobacco when the market was low and held it until it was high, pocketing the difference. The prices this year are so narrow that the pinhooker's business has been practically squeezed out.] WEBSTER : pinhooker  - a small speculator in tobacco at a local market

Citations
Date: 0/0/1972
Source: Folkgames of Children
Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page: 175
Edition:
Quote: Some of the typical terms used in marbles referred to the act of shooting and the movement of the marbles. Those related to ways of shooting marbles were cribbing, firsts, fudging, funks, funnicks, funnigans, flunks, forces, knee-high, knuckle-down-stiff, knuckles, and lasts. Terms connected with the movement of the marbles were: cannons, clears, dead-stick, double-hits, fires, funs, gees, haystacks, in smug, keeps, kills, kisses, lay-ups, manyes, ones, pink, ringer, rolls, scat, screws, skinned, skun, spiders, sported-off, stays, stops, tracks, throughs.

pink

Word Class:verb

Edition:
Quote: Cascading down opposite sides of Lake Rotomahana, the Pink and White Terraces were colonial New Zealand's premier tourist attraction. Visitors were spellbound by the beauty of the terraces' silica buttresses and mineral pools, which, according to one writer, shimmered "such a blue as is seen nowhere else in nature."

It can also be coloured grey or brown by impurities, and is a number three grade heroin.

Author: STEVENS
Vol / Page: 131
Edition:
Quote: Pink Eye (Contagious Ophthalmia) Pink eye is a very common contagious disease affecting the eyes of sheep. It is caused by micro-organisms which spread from sheep to sheep when they are in close contact, as during handling in yards under hot dusty conditions.

Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:early term for radiata pine
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]

Pronunciation:

Date: 0/6/1921
Source: NZ Journal of Science & Technology
Author:
Vol / Page: 4/123
Edition:
Quote:  SQUALUS FERNANDINUS (Molina). <i>Spiny Dogfish; Pioke</i>. Large numbers are smoked and readily sold in the Auckland markets under the name of `silver-spots.' Distribution: New Zealand coasts.
Notes: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes

Date: 0/5/1922
Source: NZ Journal of Science & Technology
Author:
Vol / Page: 5/97
Edition:
Quote: SQUALUS FERNANDINUS. <i>Pioke.</i> The pioke has been found in the Auckland market continuously throughout the year. It is popularly sold as `silver-strips,' or `silver-spots.' Probably many of the fish are <i>Mustelus antarcticus. </I>
Notes: Phillipps and Hodgkinson Further Notes on Edible Fishes

Date: 0/0/1929
Source: NZ Journal of Science & Technology
Author:
Vol / Page: 11/223
Edition:
Quote: SPINY DOGFISH. <i>Squalus fernandinus,</i> Molina. The spiny dogfish (<i>Squalus fernandinus</i>) is one of those species of shark which has attained importance as an economic species. ... It is generally called oke-oke, or kapeta, by [Maori]; the term pioke is applied by some tribes to this species, while to other tribes pioke is any small species of shark.
Notes: (Phillipps)

Date: 0/0/1888
Source: Birds of New Zealand
Author: BULLER
Vol / Page: 1/14
Edition:
Quote: ... we never saw or heard the notes of either the Piopio, the Tieke, or the Hihi, all of which birds were at one time more numerous even than the Huia. The Zosterops was everywhere abundant, also the Grey Warbler and Rifleman, and ... we found the Tomtit comparatively plentiful; the Parakeet chased its mate through the tree-tops with sharp cries of `twenty-eight'; ... and among the tangle of the underwood the ever-present Flycatcher displayed its pretty fan-like tail.

Date: 0/6/1946
Source: Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page: 55/156
Edition:
Quote: <i> piopio</i>, a bush-bird (Turnagra tanagara), the North Island thrush and (T. capensis) the South Island form: both extinct soon after 1900. A riverbed bird, the dotterel, and a naroow-leaved plant, dianella, also bear this name, but the thrush is usually associated with the name: in any case the dianella has a name tuurutu.
Notes: J.C.Andersen

Date: 0/6/1921
Source: NZ Journal of Science & Technology
Author:
Vol / Page: 4/120
Edition:
Quote: HEMIRAMPHUS INTERMEDIUS Cantor.<i> Garfish</i>, or <i>Piper; Takeke</i>. Occurs in abundance around all the northern coasts. Common, Otago, in spring and early summer. ... Distribution: New Zealand coasts. ... SCOMBRESOX FORSTERI Cuvier and Valenciennes.<i> Skipper</i>. A highly esteemed edible fish, known as `deep-sea piper' at Bay of Islands. Secured midwinter. ... Distribution: Examples have been secured as far south as Hokitika.
Notes: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes

Date: 0/0/1927
Source: Natural History of Canterbury
Author: SPEIGHT
Vol / Page: 198
Edition:
Quote: The well-known garfish or piper (<i>Hyporhamphus intermedius</i>) has the lower jaw protruding far beyond the upper, and uses it for grubbing among the seagrass in shallow bays.
Notes: 1927 Archey `Native Fishes of Canterbury' in Speight et al. Natural History of Canterbury 198

Date: 0/0/1927

Date: 0/0/1967
Source: Animals of NZ, The
Author: NATUSCH
Vol / Page: 50
Edition:
Quote: (Liver fluke of sheep and cattle occurs in parts of New Zealand, but this fluke, <i>Fasciola</i> is an introduced parasite whose intermediate hosts, the freshwater snails <i>Myxas Limnaea</i>, are also introduced. In New Zealand the adult fluke has been reported only in cattle, sheep and goats, in which unpleasant symptoms such as `pipey liver' and `bottle jaw' may occur. Black disease can kill a sheep within a few hours. The fluke concerned occurs in many parts of the world

pipi
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:any of several edible bivalve molluscs, especially the smooth-shelled cockle Paphies australis (now the main sense), also the ribbed cockle Austrovenus stutchburyi.

Author:
Vol / Page: 18
Edition:
Quote: Indeed, pipis abounded in many places along the main beach, while other shellfish made their homes on the rocks, and even when the winning of land from the sea had removed some of the sources of supply there were — right up to less than two decades ago — well stocked pipi beds at Pipitea and Evans Bay, and in Oriental Bay, where Maoris used to improve the shining hour by obtaining supplies, not only for their own use but for European tables — it was a common sight to see Maori women carrying flax kits of pipis from house to house for sale.

Quote: Pipi - the shellfish (mytilus lutus), altogether different from the North island `pipi'.

Date: 0/0/1967

Author: NATUSCH
Vol / Page: 19
Edition:
Quote: Even pipi does not mean the same thing all round New Zealand (a Stewart Island Maori of the older generation would use this name for the mussel) and it would mean nothing at all outside New Zealand. <i>Ibid.</I> 79 M [ytilus] planulatus [the smooth, navy-blue southern mussel]/ called pipi by the Stewart Island Maoris, goes down well if frothed up three times in a kerosene tin over a beach fire and then tipped out on fern leaves.

Quote: In the bays and tidal rivers are the mango or sharks - the most highly-prized food-fish - the tamure or schnapper, the whapuka or rock-cod, the kahawai or mackerel, the porahi or herring, the kanae or mullet, the patiki or sole, and many others. On the shores are oysters, mussels, cockles, mutton-fish, crabs, and other shell-fish in profuse abundance. In the fresh-water creeks are eels (tuna), lampreys (pipiharau), and whitebait (inanga).

Quote: Family MOTACILLIDAE (pipits). The New Zealand pipit belongs to the same family as the European wagtail, but the Australian wagtail is a <i>Rhipidura</i>, like our fantail. Pipit is a dull brownish-grey streaky bird, inconspicuous until with a white flick of the outer tail feathers it rises from the ground.

Date: 0/0/1859
Source: Story of New Zealand, The
Author: THOMSON
Vol / Page: 1/26
Edition:
Quote: Two migratory <i>Cuckoos</i> visit New Zealand in summer from Australia and the southern islands, and depart in autumn. During the warm summer nights they sing sweetly. The Kohoperoa, one of these cuckoos, is about the size and colour of the sparrow-hawk; the Pipiwarauroa cuckoo is a much smaller and a more variegated-feathered bird.
Notes:

Date: 20/10/1860
Source: Richmond-Atkinson Papers
Author:
Vol / Page: 1/645
Edition:
Quote:  ... Read the papers & did Maori, went for about half an hour in the Domain & found a fantail nest (young ones) & a riroriro's with two young ones & an egg. I am inclined to think the egg is a pipiwharauroa's (white, with purple spots at the larger end). Splitting firewood in the afn. I found a fine large centipede - a weri - body brown, with the articulations very plainly marked, legs a pale blue ...
Notes: 1860 Oct 20 Richmond-Atkinson Papers (1960) 1/645 (A.S. Atkinson)

Notes:

Date: 0/0/1907
Source: Plants of NZ
Author: LAING & BLACKWELL
Vol / Page: 202
Edition: 1940 p 211
Quote: The common <i>Acaena</i> was called by the Maoris Piri-piri, but colonists frequently [usually] corrupt the Maori name, and call the plant Bidi-bidi. As a general rule, the Maori names are more incorrectly pronounced as we go southward from Auckland to Otago. This is largely due to the fact that, in the north, Europeans have been brought into closer contact with the Maoris than in the south. In some few cases, the difference in pronunciation may be due to differences in the Maori dialects. The changes that take place often follow phonetic laws - thus the Maori `p' is softened into the European `b' as above, while `r' is replaced by `l' or `d'. Poro-poro (<i>Solanum aviculare</i>) becomes Bulli-bulli, and Puriri becomes Boradi. This also explains such a form as `Kowdie' pine for Kauri pine. Korari - a flax-stalk - similarly becomes Koradi or even Kaladi [1907 edn ?mistakenly, <i>Kalladi</i>]. `K' is also sometimes altered into `g,' this Kie-kie (<i>Freycinetia Banksii</i>) becomes ghi-ghi. The last vowel in a reduplicated syllable was faintly pronounced in Maori, and often disappears altogether in the European form of the word, <i>e.g.</i>, Poro-poro gives Bulli-bull, and Piri-piri gives Bidi-bid.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1926
Source: Weeds of New Zealand
Author: HILGENDORF
Vol / Page: 99
Edition: 1967
Quote: PIRI PIRI (<i>Acaena ... sanguisorbae</i>). This name is commonly corrupted into [called] bidi bid. In the North Island the plant is called hutiwai or utiwai and by mistake poroporo. It is a native species well known to all New Zealanders, and is a weed chiefly on land in process of being brought into occupation.
Notes:

Author: LEVY
Vol / Page: 15
Edition: 1970
Quote: Attuned to the geographical region were some particularly troublesome growths, and of these, the hard fern (or ring fern) became a special pest difficult to control and to guard against. ... This hard fern and piripiri were greatly encouraged by set grazing with sheep, ... 	<i>Ibid.</I> 239 He [the pioneer] did not realise the insidious spread of secondary growth and of bracken fern, hard fern, water fern, manuka, and piripiri under the close and continuous nibbling of the turf by sheep.

Date: 0/0/1898
Source: Merriam-Webster Third International
Author:
Vol / Page: 2029
Edition:
Quote: <i>Pi&#769;.ri-pi&#769;.ri</i> (p&emacr.&#769;.rè.-p&emacr.&#769;.r|e;<i> colloq</i>. p&ibreve.r&#769;.&ibreve.-p&ibreve.r&#769;.~i), <i>n</i>. [Maori.] <i>(Bot.)</i> A saxifragaceous tree of New Zealand <i>(Carodetus serratus)</i>; - called also <i>white mapau, white maple</i>, and <i>birch.</i> It bears a cluster of black berries, resembling those of the ivy, and called by settlers <i>biddy-biddy</i> or <i>biddy-bid</i>. See BIDDY-BID.

piss-
Homonym Number:
Word Class:adverb
Sense Number:
Definition:as an intensifying derogative prefix, placed usu. before (usu. a polysyllabic) aj, and possibly formed onpiss-poorP8 1. pennil;ess, hence 2. RAF abominable, hence 3. general services, to describe anything bad, feeble, ineffective, disgusting, etc still current 1975. P8 does not give any other examples of the usage, nor does it give <i>poor as piss, </i> possibly a re-formation. NZEng <i>piss-awful</i> a common usage; but cf the general structural use: Too piss-clever for his boots; Too piss-beautiful for words; etc. <i>piss-good, piss bad</i> doesn't seem to work. <i>piss-poor</i> I associate with University in the 1940s; <i>piss
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:

Edition:
Quote: Marbles had a language of its own. There were names for the marbles, the games, and all the various aspects of the play. There were terms for marbles such as `taw' or `shooter', referring to the marbles used to fire with; `dubs', `dates', `stakes', `dukes', or `changers', referring to the marbles put down to be fired at. Then there were the terms referring to particular kinds of marbles: for example, agates, aggies, aggotties, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cat's eyes, chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, molly-bars, mulley-bars [mullibars: large marbles], peelies, peewees, piss-wees, pretties, Scotties, Scottish alleys, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers, white alleys, and in more recent years ball-bearings, chippies, plastics, and woodies.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1984
Source: NZ Yesterdays
Author: KEITH & MAIN
Vol / Page: 288
Edition:
Quote: Marbles were the currency of childhood and there were an astonishing number of names for them, some referring to the material or colour, others to value or function in the game. There were agates, aggies, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cats-eye, [sic] chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, mollies, peelies, peewees, pisswees, pretties, Scotties, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers and whities. The march of technology added ball bearings - ballies or steelies - which were unbeatable when it came to smashing an opponent's miserable glassie. World War II[roman] brought `clayeys' often imperfectly spherical they were pathetic terracotta substitutes for real marbles.
Notes:

Quote: WHILE YOU are lurking slothfully in your pit - bed for those not familiar with the language of the hills- ...
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1988
Source: Hills, The
Author: PICKERING
Vol / Page: 8
Edition:
Quote: So to cope with the rituals of tramping, its pains and camaraderie, a slang language has developed to suit. Lots of quick short words to fit in the breathless pauses as you pant uphill. `Crud' (cloud), `bush-bash', a `gunn' tramper (which must have originated from Davy Gunn's famous trek up the Hollyford Valley to help victims of a plane crash in 1936; he travelled 40 km by rowing boat, horse and foot in 21 hours), `windfall' (a collapsed pile of trees), `pit' (the tramper's true friend, a sleeping bag), `pog' (porridge), `bastard grass' and `lawyer' (two unpleasant plants), `piker' (one who stayed home), `Huey' (all-powerful god of weather), and many, many more.
Notes:

Vol / Page: 356

Quote: <i>Pitau, n.</i> Maori name for the <i>Tree-fern</I>. In Maori, the word means - (I) Soft, tender, young shoots. The verb pihi means `begin to grow'; pimeans `young of birds,' also `the flow of the tide.' (2) Centre-fronds of a fern. (3) Name of a large fern.

Date: 0/1/1796
Source: Journal
Author: MURRY
Vol / Page: 1796
Edition:
Quote: Capt. Cook has given so good a description of the Spruce Fire, that it is impossible to mistake it. But he has not taken any notice of the Pitch Pine - Birch - And large Myrtle. The Pitch Pine is remarkable for its black bark, which when cut and rubbed with the finger smells agreeably. It generally grows from 20 to 40 feet without branches, and the wood is much like Norway Pitch Pine, but whiter.
Notes: 1796 Jan Murry's Journal of the `Britannia' in 1908 McNab Hist. Recs 2/534

Citations
Date: 0/0/1978
Source: Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary)
Author: McARA
Vol / Page: 329
Edition:
Quote: <i>Pitcher-drill</i>: A short drill-steel of large diameter used to `pitch' or start a drill-hole. When using the drifter, the pitcher-drill had to be firmly held in position by the man at the nose of the machine until it had bitten far enough into the rock to remain there. Once the hole was pitched the drill was re-aligned on the hole and drilling continued.

pit-sawing
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1982
Source: Brief History of Gold Mining, A
Author: EASTWOOD
Vol / Page: 107
Edition:
Quote: The only means of getting sawn timber was to cut it yourself, by what was called pit sawing. Dad used to make a pit about 20 ft long, and 6 ft deep, place logs around it, roll the logs he wanted sawn into position in the middle... Dad's mate used to go into the pit and dad, who was the taller, stood on top of the log. Dad had to drive the saw downwards, and his mate pulled it, and up and down they sawed, squared the log, cut boards and four by two and so on until they had  sufficient timber for rafters, uprights and floor joists.
Notes:

Date: 0/8/1980
Source: NZ Antique Bottle Collector
Author:
Vol / Page: 4(4)/10
Edition:
Quote: The first such memory is from an 1860 pit sawing site in Stewart Island.
Notes:

Notes: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]

Date: 0/0/1898
Source: Merriam-Webster Third International
Author:
Vol / Page: 2029
Edition:
Quote: <I>Pit&#769;.tos&#769;.po-rum</I> (p&ibreve.t-t&obreve.s&#769;.pò.-r&ubreve.m),<I> n</I>. [NL., fr. Gr. {pitta} pitch + {sporos} seed.] (Bot.) A genus of trees and shrubs, the type of the order <I>Pittosporeae. </I>The seeds, imbedded in a black gluten (whence the name) are contained in berries, which grow in clusters and are indehiscent. Of 55 species 9 are found in Australia and 6 in New Zealand. The scientific term is used as the vernacular name; but various species are also known by other names. Thus <I>Pittosporum undulatum </I>is called <I>native laurel</I> or <I>mock orange; P. tenuifolium, black mapou; P. eugenoides, tarata</I> or <I>white mapou; P. phillyraeoides, poison berry tree, butter bush, willow</I>, and <I>native willow</I>. See under LAUREL, MAPOU, POISON, and TARATA.
Notes:

Source: Taranaki Herald
Author:
Vol / Page: 3
Edition:
Quote: I would direct the thoughtful sender's attention to the desirability of rendering also the species of Pittosporum of New Zealand, nearly a dozen kinds, largely accessible to us ... Unlike the seed of the Karaka, that of the Pittospora will retain its power of germination.

Date: 0/0/1946
Source: Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page: 55/156
Edition:
Quote: <i>piupiu</i>, a garment consisting of a heavy fringe, about nine inches wide or more, made of flax and craped at intervals and dyed black. The flax when drying curling up into pipes. This fringe hung down the bare thighs, and as the wearer moved the gentle click-click of the hard tubes made a sound that was liked as to the frou-frou of a silk dress.
Notes: Andersen Maori Words in English

Notes: (T.H. Potts)

Date: 0/0/1946
Source: Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page: 55/156
Edition:
Quote: <i>pi[i]wakawaka</i>, a bird (Rhipidura flabellifera), pied fantail: the so-called black fantail, which is chocolate-colour (R. fuliginosa) is ti[i]wakawaka. The former is common throughout Newzealand; the latter is common in the South Island but rather rare in the North and is thought to be a mutant of the former. Both names were applied to both birds by the Maori, but for distinction pi[i]wakawaka for the pied and ti[i]wakawaka for the black have been adopted by the Pakeha. The bird is noted for the disaster it caused to Maui in his struggle with the mother of night, Hine-nui-te-po, Death personified.
Notes: Andersen Maori Words in English

Date: 0/0/1834
Source: New Zealand (various authors/titles)
Author: MARKHAM
Vol / Page: 41
Edition: 1963

There is another small bird called a Pea Walker [<i>piwakawaka</i>]. [ed fn. suggesting Markham is describing at first the piwakawaka, fantail, and not korimako or bellbird.]

Quote: In the lower regions the forest was much enlivened by birds. I shot some parrots [fn Nestor meridionalis. Kaka of the natives.], pigeons [fn Columba spadicea, Lath. Kukupa.], and wattle-birds [fn Glaucopis cinerea, Gmel. Kokako.]. Among the branches of the trees hopped the neat fantail flycatcher [fn Muscicapa flabellifera, Gml. Piwakawaka.], and a social bird of a yellow colour, which has been depicted by Forster [fn Orthornyx heteroclytus, Lef.   Popokatea.], and which had much the habits of the finch.

Notes: NB No definition is given but it seems to mean shielding (probably by hand) the pizzle during crutching so it is not cut "Extra care needs to be taken to be sure of not cutting the pizzle."

Date: 0/0/1970
Source: Nomenclature of NZ Fish
Author: SORENSON
Vol / Page: 24
Edition:
Quote: <i>FLOUNDER</i> (four species) (a) Scientific name: (i)<i> Rhombosolea plebeia</i> (ii) <i>Rhombosolea retiaria</i> (iii) <i>Rhombosolea tapirina</i> (iv) <i>Rhombosolea leporina.</i> (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: (i) Flounder (ii) Freshwater Flounder (iii) Flounder (iv) Yellowbelly Flounder. (c) Other common names: (i) Square, Dab, Plaice, Diamond or Diamond-back, Tin-plate, Three Corners. (ii) Blacks, Black Flounder (iii) Greenback [25 `Not common but occasionally taken in southern waters.'] (iv) Yellow Flounder.

Quote: Plantago major Plantain
Notes: (Armstrong Botany Canterbury)

Date: 0/0/1926
Source: Weeds of New Zealand
Author: HILGENDORF
Vol / Page: 161
Edition: 1967
Quote: PLANTAIN (<i>Plantago lanceolata</i>) is commonly called rib grass, lamb's tongue, horse plantain, and soldiers. It is common in pastures and waste places throughout. It forms a rosette of lanceolate leaves about 6 inches long, with prominent or converging veins, giving the name `rib grass'. From the rosette rises the slender flower stalk a foot or more in length, with a crowded mass of tiny brown or black flowers at its tip. These heads are used by children for playing `soldiers,' and so in Scotland the weed is called `Carl Doddie"-that is `Charles and George"- a souvenir of 1745.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1969
Source: Standard Common Names for Weeds
Author:
Vol / Page: 59
Edition:
Quote: <i>plantain [=] broad-leaved plantain: narrow-leaved plantain: swamp plantain</i> [s]
Notes:

Notes:

Date: 0/0/1926
Source: Weeds of New Zealand
Author: HILGENDORF
Vol / Page: 161
Edition: 1967
Quote: BROAD-LEAVED PLANTAIN (<I> Plantago major</i> ), also called ratstail, birdseed, lamb's tongue, and greater plantain, is common on roadsides and trodden places throughout the country and in pastures in the King Country. ... From the middle of the rosette ascends the flower stalk ..., which afterwards give[s] place to seeds, and produce[s] the ratstail appearance that gives the plant one of its trivial names. The long spikes of seed pods are often used for feeding caged birds.
Notes:

plantain
Homonym Number: 1
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:2
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1926
Source: Weeds of New Zealand
Author: HILGENDORF
Vol / Page: 161
Edition: 1967
Quote: PLANTAIN (<I> Plantago lanceolata</i> ) is commonly called rib grass, lamb's tongue, horse plantain, and soldiers. It is common in pastures and waste places throughout. It forms a rosette of lanceolate leaves about 6 inches long, with prominent or converging veins, giving the name `rib grass'. From the rosette rises the slender flower stalk a foot or more in length, with a crowded mass of tiny brown or black flowers at its tip. These heads are used by children for playing `soldiers,' and so in Scotland the weed is called `Carl Doddie"-that is `Charles and George"- a souvenir of 1745.
Notes:

plant-caterpillar
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1898
Source: Austral English
Author: MORRIS
Vol / Page: 360
Edition:
Quote: name given in Australasia to species of caterpillars which are attacked by spores of certain fungi; when chrysalating in the earth the fungus frows inside the body of the caterpillar, kills the latter, and then forces its way out between the head joints, and sends an upgrowth which projects beyond the surface of the ground and gives rise to fresh spores. Many examples are known, of which the more common are <I>Cordyceps robertsii</I>, Hook., in New Zealand; <I>Cordyceps gunni<I>i, berk, in Tasmania; <I>Cordyceps taylori</I> Berk, in Australia.<I> See</I> Aweto.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1930
Source: Yesterdays in Maoriland
Author: REISCHEK
Vol / Page: 70
Edition: 1933
Quote: I remained in this forest till the 20th, finding many kauri grubs; while under the rata roots I also found the Aweta, or plant-caterpillar, which to change into a chrysalis creeps underground, and in many cases instead of becoming a moth becomes - a mushroom!
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1892
Source: Vegetable Wasps and Plant Worms
Author: COOKE
Vol / Page: 139
Edition:
Quote: `The New Zealanders' name for this plant-caterpillar is `Hotete,' `Weri,' and `Anuhe'... The interior of the insect becomes completely filled by the inner plant, or thallus (mycelium): after which the growing head of the outer plant or fungus, passing to a state of maturity, usually forces its way out through the tissue of the joint between the head and the first segment of the thorax ... it is stated that this caterpillar settles head upward to undergo its change, when the vegetable developes [sic] itself.'
Notes:

plastic
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a marble
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1972
Source: Folkgames of Children
Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page: 174
Edition:
Quote: Marbles had a language of its own. There were names for the marbles, the games, and all the various aspects of the play. There were terms for marbles such as `taw' or `shooter', referring to the marbles used to fire with; `dubs', `dates', `stakes', `dukes', or `changers', referring to the marbles put down to be fired at. Then there were the terms referring to particular kinds of marbles: for example, agates, aggies, aggotties, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cat's eyes, chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, molly-bars, mulley-bars [mullibars: large marbles], peelies, peewees, piss-wees, pretties, Scotties, Scottish alleys, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers, white alleys, and in more recent years ball-bearings, chippies, plastics, and woodies.
Notes:

Date: 0/1/1951
Source: Here & Now
Author:
Vol / Page: 16
Edition:
Quote: `Bah!' you say, `the play way'. Wait a bit, my friends. Reflect on what your children of five here learnt by the play way before they ever went to school. [17] What is the `play-way'? Is it universally practised in schools today? The term `play-way' is well known to students of education as the name given by Caldwell Cooke to a highly successful experiment, mainly in the teaching of English, carried out by him at the Perse School, Cambridge - a fee-paying school, with a high staffing rate and a tradition of experimentation.

Plimmer's Ark
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/6/2001
Source: Absolutely Positively Wellington
Author:
Vol / Page: 10
Edition:
Quote: [Hdg] Plimmer's Ark back from the dead. A new chapter in the eventful saga of the <i>Inconstant</i> - the ship that became a building - has started following the recent opening of the new Plimmer's Ark Gallery on Queens Wharf... For many years life in Wellington basically revolved around the hulk of the <i>Inconstant</i>... Built in 1847 and launched on 3 Jan 1848 at Cape Breton in Nova Scotia, the <i>Inconstant</i> sailed to England and there had her hull clad with copper...On entering Wellington Harbour [in 1849] the ship ran on to the rocky beach between Pencarrow and the point now named Inconstant Point. The <i>Inconstant</i> was towed across the harbour to Te Aro. John Plimmer bought the by then derelict ship and had it moved in 1850 to Lambton Beach where he built a pitched roof over the mid section. It became known as Noah's [<i>sic</i>] Ark because of its appearance.
Notes:

Date: 0/9/2003
Source: NZ Heritage
Author:
Vol / Page: No. 90/6
Edition:
Quote: Plimmer's Ark is one of the most significant pieces of maritime history entrusted to the Maritime Archaeological Association. In 1977, construction workers digging in the old Bank of New Zealand building on Wellington's Lambton Quay discovered a slab of wood. Archaeologists identified it as part of the <i>Inconstant</i>, a ship that was towed into Wellington and was eventually bought by John Plimmer who dragged it ashore and modified it for use as business premises. The ship became known as Plimmer's Ark.
Notes:

Notes:

plough
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: [entries at swing, lever, stilt]
Citations
Date: 30/10/1963
Source: Weekly News
Author:
Vol / Page: [farming page]
Edition:
Quote: When the first settlers came to New Zealand, they didn't bring many ploughs with them from their home countries. ... [Blacksmiths] set up their smithies and began making implements more suitable for the terrain. One of the first of [the New Zealand made ploughs] was a long sleek job known as a swing plough. Just why is hard to say ... The furrows were the result of the accuracy of the ploughman's eye, as it had no wheels whatever. The depth was graduated by the bridle adjustment but was corrected in uneven ground by leverage from the long handles, or stilts as they were called. If the the share struck anything these [swing ploughs] had a kick like a run cow. It is said that a good man could land on his feet six yards in front of the horses ... The next development was the lever plough which ran on three wheels and had no handles except a stubby one at the back.
Notes:

plough
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:2
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 20/11/1890
Source: Otago Witness
Author:

Date: 0/0/1937
Source: Dictionary of Slang
Author: PARTRIDGE
Vol / Page: 641
Edition:
Quote: <i>Plug</i>. 3. An inferior horse: s.>, ca. 1920, coll.: Colonial and-prob. ex-U.S.: 1872, in U.S. Also<i> old plug</i>, ob. Ex <i>plug</i>, a stop-hole, perhaps influenced by<i> plug-tobacco</i>, often inferior and rank. But in Australia, from ca. 1880, a good steady, though slow horse, and in New Zealand, late C. 19-20, a horse that is `a good sort' O.E.D.

Citations
Date: 0/0/1946
Source: New Zealand (various authors/titles)
Author: SOLJAK
Vol / Page: 117
Edition:
Quote: New Zealanders have coined or adapted many expressions to meet local requirements, as illustrated by the following: ... <i>plunk a baby</i>: to given [sic] an infant scientific care; derived from name of Plunket Society.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1949
Source: Dictionary of Slang Addenda
Author: PARTRIDGE
Vol / Page: 1139
Edition:
Quote: <i>Plunk a baby; get plunked; get trubied; get karitanied.</i> To go into a maternity home and have one's baby there hence, to become pregnant: New Zealand: C. 20. B., 1941. The first (<i>plunk a baby</i>) refers to the Plunket Society, as obviously does the derivative second; the third refers to Sir Truby King, noted for sage advice upon, and sustenance for, the feeding of infants; the fourth comes ex Karitane Home.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1966
Source: Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An
Author: McLINTOCK
Vol / Page: 2/680
Edition:
Quote: <i>Plunket</i> for the Plunket Society has developed a verbal use `to <i>plunket</i> (or <i>plunk</i>) a baby'.
Notes: (Wall NZ Speech)

Date: 0/0/1941
Source: NZ Slang
Author: BAKER
Vol / Page: 58
Edition:
Quote: For the past twenty years [the Plunket Society] has been known as the Plunket, and from it we have derived to plunket a baby, or, even more tersely, to plunk a baby, with further extensions to get plunked, to get trubied (recalling the noted Sir Truby King), and to get Kari tanied (derived from the Karitane Home).
Notes:

Plunket
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:the popular name of the Royal New Zealand Plunket Society Inc., formerly the Royal New Zealand Society for the Health of Women and Children. Compare KARITANE. Plunket baby, a baby raised under a Plunket Society regime; Plunket nurse, a registered, general or maternity, nurse from the Plunket Society who checks and advises on the health of mothers and babies. [Lord Plunket, Governor of New Zealand 1904-1910]
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:

Source: Sunday Star Times
Author:
Vol / Page: C6

Quote: "In the early 20th century Plunket served a real function for women, for whom paid employment outside of the home was not an acceptable option. It got middle class married women out of the home and into the public sphere where they could contribute meaningfully and it no longer serves that function"... Now women no longer have to channel their energies into voluntary organisations, such as Plunket to find a niche in the public world. <i.Ibid.</i> C7 She began with the view which arose out of 1970s feminism, that Plunket had been a foce that dictated to women and kept them in their place.

Quote: The distinction between a. Plunket nurse and a Karitane is an important one. Plunket nurses must be registered nurses before they embark on the 17-week Plunket training course and they often have additional midwifery or nursing qualifications. Karitanes have basic child-care training with no nursing qualification required.

They were developed by Californian company Zaiger Genetics 11 years ago using an intricate method of hybridising.

Source: Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
Author: McGILL
Vol / Page: 85
Edition:
Quote: <i> pluty</i> wealthy, but worse, perceived as assuming airs and graces above the level of the egalitarian Kiwi herd; refers also to suburbs that fancy themselves, such as Fendalton in Christchurch, Khandallah or Karori (`We are the Park Lane of New Zealand' overheard comment in London of a woman from Karori) in Wellington, Remuera in Auckland; comes from `plutocracy', the land barons of the South Island last century.
Notes:

Source: Gold Fossicker's Handbook
Author: NOLAN
Vol / Page: 113
Edition:
Quote: <i>Pluton</i>: a large body, often dome-shaped, of intrusive rock (such as granite, granodiorite, syenite, etc.) that has been exposed at or near the surface. The vicinites of plutons have been the source of many valuable mineral deposits. `Bubbles' are smaller plutons.

Date: 3/7/1894
Source: Star, The
Author:
Vol / Page: 3
Edition:
Quote: "Kaituna," a locality of great repute for this staple article of the aboriginal's food, prior to the introduction of the "poaka" (pig), and the nearest approach to flesh (literally, eat eels) but probably intended to convey the idea of its being a noted fishing ground for this, to them, delicious and life-sustaining commodity - let us hope that it may remain undisturbed.

Date: 6/12/1861
Source: Wellington Independent
Author:
Vol / Page: 5
Edition:
Quote: Betty replied, "she has come for her pig;" Brown said "I have not seen your pig;" I then went outside the house, and stayed out there a little while, when the pig grunted; I called "poaka poaka," and the pig grunted a good deal; the noise came from a little house behind; I went to the house, and saw the pig inside grunting to me; I opened the door, and I found that the pig had been marked; the ear was cut, and the tail was cut off; the blood was quite fresh, it having been recently done; I examined the pig, and found it was the same that I had missed.
Notes:

Vol / Page: 64
Edition:
Quote: The pig, though present in Polynesia, is not mentioned in Maori traditions. After its introduction by Europeans, it was named <i>poaka</i> after the English name pork or porker which resembles the old Polynesian name of <i>puaka</i> but must not be confounded with it.
Notes:

Notes:

Date: 0/0/1873
Source: Wild Will Enderby
Author: PYKE
Vol / Page: Bk I iv 17
Edition: 1889
Quote: The Dunstan gold workings were of two kinds - technically known as `beach claims' and `bank claims'. The latter were on the gravelly river banks which the miners sluiced away bodily for the golden grains ... The former were on the sandy margins of the river, and were often extended by means of `wing-dams' and other ingenious devices far into the rushing waters. In these claims the gold was found lodged in `pockets' or fissures formed by the slate bars ...
Notes:

Quote: I want now to ask the kind assistance of some amongst your readers in collecting from books, periodicals, or newspaper quotations to illustrate the use of the various words in the following list .. List of Fish .. Poddly, 1872 ...

Date: 0/0/1872
Source: Edible Fishes
Author: HECTOR
Vol / Page: 108
Edition:
Quote: SEA PERCH ... The Pohuiakaroa (<i>Sebastes percoides</i>), though not figured deserves mention, as it is a small fish representing in these seas the genus to which the Norway Haddock belongs. ... It is the proper <i>Sea Perch</i> of these waters, that name having been by mistake applied in the Catalogue to a small Wrasse (No.67), which is generally called the Spotty or Poddly. [No.67 is <i>Labrichthys celidota</i>)
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1898

Author: MORRIS
Vol / Page: 363
Edition:
Quote:  ~ a New Zealand and Australian fish, <i>Sebastes percoides, </i>Richards., called in Victoria <i>Red-Gurnet Perch</i>. The name is applied in England to a different fish.

Source: Early Runholding in Otago
Author: BEATTIE
Vol / Page: 32
Edition:
Quote: We went down a spur for two miles that was very soft from the late rain, and full of waterholes, called crab-holes. These holes were formed by the large snowgrass tussocks being burnt out roots and all, leaving a hole, or by the uprooting of trees, where the hole was very large ... In some places these holes made by(?) cattle mustering a most hazardous undertaking. In Mr Alex Garvie's report in 1858 he refers to `podge holes,' presumably a variety of `crab-holes.'

Notes:

Date: 12/4/1773
Source: Journal
Author: BAYLY
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  There are great plenty of a kind of birds much resembling our black birds, except they have a few white feathers in the wings and tail and some fine loose downy feathers round the neck which grow out among the black ones & has the appearance of fine white hairs intermixed with the feathers & under the throat are 4 fine curling white feathers growing in a tuff. These are called Poey-birds. They are thought to be the finest eating for delicacy & richness ... <i>Ibid.</I>  2/213 During our ramble [in Queen Charlotte's Sound] I saw Wood Pigeons, Parroquets, Grey Parrots, Poey Birds & Quails & vast variety of singing Birds but no animal great or small or any fruit Trees of any kind whatever.
Notes: 1773 April 12 Bayly's Journal in 1908 McNab Historical Records 2/206

The sweetness of this bird's note they described as extraordinary, and that its flesh was delicious, but that it was a shame to kill it.'

Date: 0/0/1830
Source: New Zealanders, The
Author: CRAIK
Vol / Page: 187
Edition:
Quote: The most remarkable bird is one to which Cook's people gave the name of mocking-bird, from the extraordinary variety of its notes. There is also another which is called by the English the poe, or poi bird, from a little tuft of white curled feathers which it has under its throat, and which seemed to them to resemble certain white flowers worn as ornaments by the people of otaheite, and known there [188] by a similar name.

Date: 3/2/2004
Source: Dominion Post TV Week
Author:
Vol / Page: 8
Edition:
Quote: They are one of only a few whanau who continue the tradition of making poha, or containers used for preserving muttonbirds.
Notes:

Date: 18/1/1844
Source: Southern Districts of NZ
Author: SHORTLAND
Vol / Page: 224
Edition:
Quote:  ... the cargo with which they had been freighted, consisting chiefly of `poha-titi' or casks of preserved mutton birds. Many of these were from five to six feet high, and ornamented with feathers: they were all designed as presents to relatives at Waiateruati, or Banks's Peninsula; ... The `poha,' which I have called a cask - as it performs the office of one - is constructed by the natives in an ingenious manner, worthy of description. A kelp bag - the air bladder of a fucus - is easily found of the size required, made by nature. In this the young `titi' are packed, after being cooked, and the oil which has escaped in the cooking is poured on them. Over the exterior of the bag is then laid the bark of the `totara' tree, ...
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1847
Source: Great Journey
Author: BRUNNER
Vol / Page: 54
Edition: 1952
Quote: There is great taste shown by the natives in the poha, or bag of preserved wekas.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1851
Source: Southern Districts of NZ
Author: SHORTLAND
Vol / Page: 312
Edition:
Quote: POHA, a sort of cask shaped like a sugar loaf, constructed from the air bladder of a species of sea-weed, strengthened outside by layers of the bark of the `totara,' and kept firmly together by means of stakes tied with flax.
Notes:

Date: 20/4/1952
Source: Diary
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote: Out on line by door bull-kelp bags blown up and drying. Under the table finished pohas stacked. Birds in kelp bags with totara bark wrapping, looking fine in their new flax baskets.

pohue
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a name used for several native climbing plants: a) convolvulus; b) clematis; c) a Muehlenbeckia. [Maori pohutukawa[o-macron]] sepium, bell climber, bindweed, greater convolvulus
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 23/9/1872
Source: Daily Southern Cross
Author:
Vol / Page: 2
Edition:
Quote: Every one of them, even Paul Tuhaere, who was related by marriage to the deceased chief, had around their heads or hats massive wreaths of the creeping plant known as pohue, and in some places as pikiarero.
Notes:

Date: 1/11/2003
Source: Dominion Post
Author:
Vol / Page: E13
Edition:
Quote: "When a warrior of old wished to warn of the deviousness of an enemy," says Murdoch Riley in his book <I>Maori Healing and Herbal</i>, "he would say simply 'the roots of the pohue are many,' or 'his mouth is like the creeping convolvulus' - meaning that his thoughts spread underground like the runners of the convolvulus."
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1946
Source: Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page: 55/156
Edition:
Quote: <i>po[o]hue</i>, a vine (Calystegia Soldanella), sand-bine: C. sepium is paraha.

Source: Weeds of New Zealand
Author: HILGENDORF
Vol / Page: 137
Edition: 1967
Quote: GREATER CONVOLVULUS [BINDWEED] (<I> Calystegia sepium </I>) has the same popular names as the last species, [i.e. convolvulus] and in additions, beautiful white devil, and its native name of pohue. It is much like convolvulus [bindweed], but is larger in all its parts. The leaves are 3 to 5 inches in length and the flower 2 inches across, more usually white than pink.

Citations
Date: 0/0/1886
Source: Handbook Fishes of NZ
Author: SHERRIN
Vol / Page: 88
Edition:
Quote: SEA PERCH (<I> Sebastes percoides </I>). ... `The pohuiakaroa,' Dr. Hector says, `deserves mention, as it represents in these seas the genus to which the Norway haddock belongs. It is one of the most frequent and troublesome fish, caught in a moderate depth of water round the coast, and especially in rocky harbours, being almost worthless as food, and armed with so many sharp spines that it is a difficult task to detach it from the hook. It is the proper sea-perch of these waters.'
Notes:

Vol / Page: 384

Quote: In a narrow valley a little distance from the hut a path led along a steep bank and descended abruptly by a drop of about ten feet through a small opening in a thick mat of the foliage of stunted pohutukawa.
Notes:

Date: 23/1/1999
Source: Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author: CARMAN
Vol / Page: 52
Edition:
Quote: Pohutukawa are our remarkable trees - the symbol of New Zealand, as the oak is the emblem of England. Like the oak, the pohutukawa has a short, stout gnarled trunk that becomes beautifully gnarled with time, the wide-spreading branches forming a most stately and memorable tree... The name "pohutukawa" comes from "hutukawa" (a head-dress of red feathers) and "po" which has meany meanings, including night or underworld. Governor Grey interpreted this as meaning "the tree with red adornment near the sea", but "po" could equally be a reference to the traditional tree at Cape Reinga where the spirits of the dead descend via the pohutukawa tree to a secret cave, the entrance to Te Reinga, the spirit or underworld [sic]. A small, scrubby version still clings to the cliff edge at the leaping-off place of the spirits. In Maori, to say someone "has slid down the pohutukawa root" is a lyrical way of saying he has joined the ancestors.
Notes:

Date: 3/11/2003
Source: Dominion Post
Author:
Vol / Page: B5
Edition:
Quote: Pohutukawas are overrunning protected scrubland in Western Cape, South Africa...

Date: 0/0/1835

Quote: Running, climbing, swimming, wrestling, flying kites, and tossing the <i>poi</i>, a ball about the size of a good cricket-ball, are most of the games of native origin.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1946
Source: Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author: ANDERSEN
Vol / Page: 55/156
Edition:
Quote: <i> poi</i>, a light ball made from raupo blades, with a short string attached to it which is swung and twisted rhythmically, in the manner of Indian clubs, to the accompaniment of a song; the so-called poi-dance, which is less a dance than a whirling of the balls and a swaying of the body in time with the song. There is a long-poi, in which the string is perhaps a yard long.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1946
Source: Where the People Sing
Author: ZIMMERMAN
Vol / Page: 18
Edition:
Quote: The<i> poi</i> is an egg-shaped thing, made of the pith from a swamp plant covered with a woven cover of <i>raupo,</i> somewhat like the leaves of the cattail.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1947
Source: Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.
Author:
Vol / Page: 175
Edition:
Quote: <i>poi</i>: small stuffed ball; ball game.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1961
Source: Merriam-Webster Third International
Author:
Vol / Page: 1749
Edition:
Quote: <i>poi n</i>, pl <i>poi</i> or <i>pois</i> [Maori]: a small ball which is made typically of flax, grass, or rushes, to which a string of varying length is attached, and which is swung rhythmically by Maori performers in various dances and songs

Date: 0/0/1918
Source: Link, The
Author:
Vol / Page: 8
Edition:
Quote: The poi balls commence to spin, the deft hands twirling them move up and down, sideways, backwards and forwards, hovering over the shoulders, now over and across the knee, the whirling balls appearing to surround, as with a network of gossamer, the bodies of the dancers as they sway from side to side, lifting alternate feet and throwing one across, gently forward with a lilting motion, giving the general effect of a waltz step.

Date: 0/0/1830
Source: New Zealanders, The
Author: CRAIK
Vol / Page: 187
Edition:
Quote: The most remarkable bird is one to which Cook's people gave the name of mocking-bird, from the extraordinary variety of its notes. There is also another which is called by the English the poe, or poi bird, from a little tuft of white curled feathers which it has under its throat, and which seemed to them to resemble certain white flowers worn as ornaments by the people of otaheite, and known there [188] by a similar name.

Date: 0/0/1946
Source: Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author: ANDERSEN
Vol / Page: 55/156
Edition:
Quote: i>poi</i>, a light ball made from raupo blades, with a short string attached to it which is swung and twisted rhythmically, in the manner of Indian clubs, to the accompaniment of a song; the so-called poi-dance, which is less a dance than a whirling of the balls and a swaying of the body in time with the song. There is a long-poi, in which the string is perhaps a yard long.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1905
Source: Where the White Man Treads
Author: BAUCKE
Vol / Page: 91
Edition:

Quote: The Corriedale ... grows more wool than hair on the hocks, thereby making it imperative that they be shorn trimmed to the feet. These points or socks do not have a tendency to lift or rise off the skin. <I>Ibid.</I> 137 The Romney is a well-woolled sheep, covered right down on to the points. At the right time of the year these points lift or rise off the skin allowing the comb and the handpiece to enter easily and the blows to finish out on the points without poking.

point
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Jim says definitions in British dictionaries relate <i>point</i> to the  seacoast (headland, cape, promontory - "a high point jutting out into the sea"). NSOD gives as <i>chiefly US</i> "a tapering extremity of land etc.. constituting a geographical feature". This echoes the common use of point in NZ in <i>inland</i> placenames e.g. Arthur's Point, Awakino Point, Pleasant Point, Titoki Point, Ti-tree Point." I have not noticed any inland "Points" in England or in a cursory skim through British gazetteers. This use of the word may be worth followng up.
Citations

Author: ADKIN

Notes: check page and edition; 1st edition 1948

Vol / Page: 22

Quote:  I suppose at that time [c1860s goldrush] I would be more interested in grabbing my `dumps' out of the ring at school, when some quick eye had noticed that a young pointer had tried to get away with placing a stinkie or a chalkie into play with the rest of his marbles. The `Grab your dumps' was the roar, as we all rushed in for our own, and anybody else's one could get.

Date: 0/0/1844
Source: Notes of a Journey
Author: MONRO
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote: A tree, which I have not seen in this part of the country [Molyneux], is also sufficiently abundant there. Its leaf is like the rata, but its stem is clean and cylindrical, of a white colour, a good deal fissured. The native name of it is pokaka, and with the bark of it a black dye is made, which is equal to the dye of the hinau.
Notes: 1844 Monro Notes of a Journey (Nelson <i>Examiner </i> July 20 et seq.) in 1898 Hocken Contributions 249

Citations
Pokarekare Ana
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a popular Maori song
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 20/4/2002
Source: Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page: 6
Edition:
Quote: The documentary <i>Pokarekare Ana: A Maori Love Song</i>.. on the origins of the song, surrounds the contributions made by Sir Apirana Ngata and Paraire Tomoana with a misleading element of mystery... For a number of reasons, "Pokarekare" is unlikely tobeen the original work of either of these men. (1) "Pokarekare" was published in sheet music form in 1926 (twice), in 1927, 1936 and 1940 prior to Paraire Tomoana's death in 1946. The two 1926 versions are said to have been arranged by "Hemi Piripata" and "Alfred Hill": respectively. the 1927 version is said to have been arranged by "P H Tomoana and Archie Don". The 1936 version is said to have been "collected and sung by Ernest McKinley" and the 1940 version is again said to have ben arranged by "Hemi Piripata". in short, no published version of the song, including the 1919 booklet entry, gave any credit to either Apirana Ngata or to P H Tomoana for composing the song in their lifetimes... The most likely conclusion would seem to be that what has affectionately become "New Zealand's unofficial anthem" originated in the far north of New Zealand  circa 1900 and was adapted. modified and developed in its journey through the country by a number of gifted Maori composers of the day.
Notes: David Smith (Mandeville North, Kaiapoi)

Date: 27/4/2002
Source: Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page: 8
Edition:
Quote: ...Tomoana explains the song's origin: "7. Pakarekare. These ditties emanated in the North of Auckland and were popularised in Narrowneck Camp, and eventually drifted to ... the East Cape. There they took the present form ... and acquired close association with the last drafts of single men from the East Cape and Wairoa districts ... the 19th and 20th Maori Reinforcements."
Notes:

Date: 27/4/2002
Source: Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page: 8
Edition:
Quote: In 1978 I went with a Hamilton Teachers College kapa haka student group on a tour of Aboriginal settlements in Australia's Northern Territory... The group refused to include "Pokarekare Ana" in their repertoire because in their eyes the song had become a parody of the original, with "squashed banana" lyrics... At the Adelaide Festival, Rolf Harris asked us to accompany him in his latest hit, "Pokarekare Ana."... Anyone from Dame Kiri Te Kanawa down can sing "Pokarekare". It adds to the popular culture of New Zealand.
Notes:

Date: 27/4/2002
Source: Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page: 9
Edition:
Quote: On hearing "Pokarekare" for the first time George Bernard Shaw immediately identified the music as a Swiss cradle song.
Notes:

Date: 19/4/2003
Source: Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page: 28
Edition:
Quote: ...all too often what happens is someone gets sentimental and the song somehow stumbles on to become a mumbled medley involving "Pokarekareana". The full lyrics to which are "Pokarekareana Something Something Roto-rua".

Quote: Coasters never miss a chance to poke the borax [159] at the Cathedral City.

Date: 0/0/1988
Source: Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
Author: McGILL
Vol / Page: 19
Edition:
Quote: <i>borax </i>in phr. <i>poke the borax</i> to ridicule; most popular spelling here of Aboriginal word `borak' aka `borac' and `borack', perhaps because radio's Aunt Daisy was a great promoter of borax (no relation) powder as a household cleaner.

The `Pokeha,'[check transcription] or rain cloak. Of these, the variety of flax plant called the `Koura' yields the best fibre for the `Korowai'.

pole
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number: 1
Definition: a branch of silver poplar or willow that will take root when placed in slipped or eroded soil areas.
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:Rural
Region:[none]
See:pole-planting
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1969
Source: Big Country of the North Island
Author: NEWTON
Vol / Page: 235
Edition:
Quote: .. I gained some insight into the practice of planting "poles" for stabilisation purposes. These poles are straight lengths of willow or silver poplar up to ten feet in length and up to two inches in diameter which are simply sharpened and pushed a couple of feet or so into the ground. The planting of poles is common practice in the Gisborne districts .. along the roadsides one sees nursery blocks devoted entirely to producing these poles …
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1973
Source: Historic Sheep Stations NI
Author: WHEELER
Vol / Page: 11
Edition:
Quote: The severed 'pole' is planted in a dam site or in ground that requires stabilising, and quickly shoots up to become a tree. Four years later, the original tree is cut again, the naturally branching occurring immediately above the first cut yielding some four to five 'poles' which in their turn produce fresh trees.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1993
Source: Farming Under Aspiring
Author: ASPINALL
Vol / Page: 97
Edition:
Quote: For some years I decided to plant 1000 poles [of poplar] annually ...
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1998
Source: Information and Communication Needs
Author: BRADSHAW & WILLIAMS
Vol / Page: 22
Edition:
Quote: If too many poplar poles are planted in one year there is a chance they will not receive the care they need. At an average cost of $10 per pole it is an expensive practice if they die.

Upon [the driver's] arrival at the Union Hotel with his polers, he was rushed with enquiries. ...Seating himself on the axle in a comical position, he was `Joe'd' by a chorus of lookers-on. Replying that those who had nothing better to do than `Joe' him were a set of `tarnation fools', he drove off at top speed.

polling booth
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/1/1999
Source: NZWords
Author:
Vol / Page: 2
Edition:
Quote: We have polling places and polling booths, although the term polling booth is often used loosely to encompass also both polling places and what the Electoral Act calls 'inner compartments' where the voter marks the ballot paper.
Notes:

polling place
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a location, e.g. a school, where votes may be cast at an election
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Jim Cameron writes : See Electoral Act 1993 s. 155. The British equivalent is <i>polling station</i>>. Popularly a polling place is often referred to as a <i>polling booth</i>, which has the distinct legal meaning of a room within a polling place. For each polling booth the Returning Officer for the electorate appoints a <i>deputy returning officer (DRO)</i>. The corresponding perrson in Britain appears to be known as a <i>presiding officer</i>.

Date: 24/3/1999
Source: Dominion
Author:
Vol / Page: 1
Edition:
Quote: TVNZ said "Poms" was a term used affectionately by Kiwis and Australians, and it rejected the complainants' view that the word was comparable to terms such as "Chinks",  "Wogs", or "Horis". It agreed expressions such as "Pommy bastards" and "whingeing Poms" were terms of abuse. Authority chairman Sam Maling noted the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission's ruling that the words "Pom" and "Pommy" were unlikely to offend of insult.

Notes:

Pommie/Pommy
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:an English person; British person, especially one who has immigrated. [from a play on the pomegranate (so Australian National Dictionary), formerly an Australian name for a British immigrant through Australian pommy grant, early New Zealand jimmy grant]
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:

Vol / Page: III/115 : 5

Notes:

Date: 0/0/1916
Source: Anzac Book, The
Author: BEAN
Vol / Page: 31
Edition:
Quote: `Never met him, matey, but he is all right, you bet. A Pommy* can't go wrong out there if he isn't too lazy to work.' ... `Oh, well, yer see, mate, we don't call the like of 'im `Pommies' because we dislike 'em, but just as a matter of description. [fn] *Pommy - short for pomegranate, and used as a nickname for immigrants.
Notes: 1916 N.Ash `Anzac Dialogues' in 1916 Bean The Anzac Book 31

Date: 18/11/1950
Source: Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page: 8
Edition:
Quote: I was amused... There is no obscurity about the origin of "Pommy". The origin is the obvious one - "Emigrant". The emigrants themselves corrupted this to "Pomegranate". From 1914 to 1925 Ifrequently heard and used the term "pomegranate" to describe a new arrival. Over recent years this has been abbreviated to "Pommy". I am, etc...Thick-skinned Pommy.

Vol / Page: 8

Quote: The term is of Australian origin, of a period long ago when the military and other authorities of the time called the men of the penal settlement, "Prisoners of Mother England," which was shortenedto P.O.M.E. and later made "Pommie". The New Zealand term was "Homie" until superseded by the Australian adjective. And even now "Pommie" is being superseded by the term "Pongo".

Date: 0/0/1951
Source: Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote: (Corresp. col) Sir, - Your correspondents are incorrect regarding the origin of the term `Pommie', meaning English immigrant. The term is of Australian origin, of a period long ago when the military and other authorities of the time called the men of the penal settlements, `Prisoners of Mother England', which was shortened to P.O.M.E. and later made `Pommie'. The New Zealand term was `Homie' until superseded by the Australian adjective. And even now Pommie is being superseded by the term `Pongo'. The term certainly was derisive in origin, and as to whether it is still derisive depends entirely upon the individual addressed as such. The writer is of the fourth generation (N.Z. with Austr. connections). Winther Pedersen.
Notes: ? Jan?

Date: 0/0/1951
Source: Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote: I was amused by your reply to `T.P.P.' There is no obscurity about the origin of `Pommy'. The origin is the obvious one - `Emigrant'. The emigrants themselves corrupted this to `pomegranate'. From 1914 to 1925 I frequently heard and used `pomegranate' to describe a new arrival. Over recent years this has become abbreviated to `Pommy'. Thick-Skinned Pommy.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1951
Source: Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote: A Tasmanian gave the origin definitely as being `pomegranate', the colour of that fruit being similar to the high colour of the complexions of the English, and very noticeable against the sun-dried appearance of the Aussie complexion. This has been acceptable to many knowing the Aussies' susceptibility to using phrases such as `plates of meat' for feet and `trouble for strife' for wife. Pommy to many has become a most objectionable word owing to the way it has been used with other words. Only the most ignorant use of such terms, not thinking that their forefathers came from that same brave country. If my comrades of the Homeland, newly arrived, who use the nom-de-plume, or refer to themselves as `Pommies', read this they will now understand why it is objectionable even when used in a friendly manner. British and Proud of it.
Notes:

Date: 31/12/1951
Source: Christchurch Star-Sun
Author:
Vol / Page: 2
Edition:
Quote: Sir, - Fifty years ago a shipload of passengers arrived in Australia. Coming through the tropics, they got badly burned and their faces were scarlet. The word `Pommie' was derived from a well-known Australian fruit at the time, the scarlet pomegranate. So the Australians named the new arrivals `Pommies' (just fun), and `Pommie' is still used occasionally. -E.M.W.
Notes:

Date: 2/1/1958
Source: Christchurch Star-Sun
Author:
Vol / Page: 2
Edition:
Quote:  Sir, -A correspondent wishes to know the origin of the word `Pommie.' The famous war correspondent, the late Ashmad Barlett, in his book, `Despatches from the Dardanelles,' written at the time of the campaign, says that the term `Pommie' was applied by veteran troops of the campaign to newly arrived troops from Britain. Their fresh pink complexions were likened to the fruit pomegranate, in contrast to the bronzed features of the veteran troops. They were referred to as `Pommies.' The term, therefore, was not applied by Dominion troops in particular to those from Britain, but by veteran troops, both British and Dominion, to new arrivals. -KIWI.
Notes:

Date: 4/1/1958
Source: Christchurch Star-Sun
Author:
Vol / Page: 2
Edition:
Quote: Sir, - In reply to O.J. Davis and `Very Interested' relating to the origin of the word `Pommie.' The word apparently came into being during the 1914-18 War and is derived from the French word pommes, meaning, I believe, potatoes. During the war the front line troops of the British Army were very seriously short of food, except for potatoes, on which they subsisted for many weeks. Hence on the fields at Flanders this peculiar and, I might say, very controversial word came into being. I am sure that any British World War I veteran could affirm this explanation.-W.J.BRACKS.
Notes:

Date: 6/1/1958
Source: Christchurch Star-Sun
Author:
Vol / Page: 2
Edition:
Quote:  Sir, - It is `POM-E,' not `Pommie.' These four letters originated in the old sailing ship days. Migrants leaving the British Isles were issued with a permit of migration certificate which was headed, `Permit of migration-Ireland,' `Permit of migration-England,' depending on the part of the British Isles one was from. The first letters in these four words `Permit of migration-England' are `POM-E,' spelt now, as pronounced then, `Pommie.' -SAILS.
Notes:

Date: 23/2/1962
Source: Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page: 8
Edition:
Quote: Sir, - The red coat of the soldier gave rise to the sailors' nickname for him of `Pommy,' a corruption of the French `pomme.' This derivation is far more likely than `Prisoner of Mother England.' The derogatory nickname would be more likely to stick to the guards than to the convicts. If my explanation is incorrect am I entitled to call our trans-Tasman cousins (and others) `Pommies?' - I am, etc., A PENSIONER OF MOTHER ENGLAND.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1962
Source: Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote: Sir, - Unfortunately previous correspondents have been confused by the spelling of `Pommy.' I understand the correct spelling to be P.O.M.M.I.E., this being derived from the initial letters of the phrase, `People of Many Magnificient Immortal Epics.' This derivation was given in the Australian R.S.L. magazine several years ago. - I am, etc, DRONGATUS PONGORUM.
Notes:

Date: 3/9/1964
Source: Dominion
Author:
Vol / Page: 4
Edition:
Quote: EVERY now and then some one puts forward a new theory on why Englishmen are occasionally referred to in these southern latitudes as `Pommies'. The following note from Mr. G.T.M., of the coastal motor vessel Squall, at Wellington, may clear things up: `I first visited Aussie in 1911-Western Australia, Victoria, New South Wales, and Queensland. Immigrants were variously termed-Immygrant', `Jimmy grants', and up among the bananalanders, quite often `Pommy grants' (pomegranates). Very soon this became `Pommy'; and this, I think, would be the true derivation.'
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1938
Source: Guest of Life, A
Author: SCANLAN
Vol / Page: 141
Edition:
Quote: `[New Zealanders] like the English, provided they are the right type; the educated young man gets on well. They don't like the `Pommie' as they call him, God knows why, and no one can tell you where the name came from, but its more common in Australia than in New Zealand'. `What is a Pommie?' `Blest if I know; it's hard to define, but usually the short, shrunken industrial worker, the man with the broad accent, from Yorkshire or Lancashire. The stunted product of sweated labour, from mills factories and mines. I've heard him referred to as a Pommie, but never the upstanding educated young fellow. They seem to welcome him; he is like themselves'.

Quote: New Zealanders themselves may have been subconsciously aware of this difference of approach. They never quite knew where they had Mr. Nash. Was he one of them or was he still, if you scratched below the surface, just another Pommy? Certainly he never exchanged his Worcestershire accent for the very individual New Zealand version of our language.
Notes: 1965 Mallaby From My Level 80 in 1976 Sinclair Nash 318

Quote: He has had a rough time of it surveying a block on the ranges up the Wai-o-hine in the Wairarapa ...[sic] Once ...[sic] they had nothing to eat but a tui and a more-pork. ... They were stewing the two birds when a kuku-pa (bush pigeon) flew up and perched. Bob shot it ... This is not exactly what the Britishers call `sport' - but there is more of nature about it than 30 gents in pink and tops ... waiting for a wretched little fox who, when he is killed, is not equal for culinary purposes to a more-pork. Once coming up the Waikato in 1851 your Uncle James got a pot-shot at a lot of parera (grey duck) ...

Date: 12/8/1957
Source: Dominion
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote: [Corresp. col.] Sir, - It is to be regretted that the artist who labelled his picture `Punga with Parasites,' did not write `Tree fern with Parasites,' as punga does not mean tree fern, or anything like it. Bushmen usually called a pukatea, buckyteer; a kowhai, goey; and a kaponga, [variant of ponga] a bunger whence comes the word punga, both a noun and a verb in Maori. The kaponga or brown tree fern is not nearly so handsome as the mamaku, or black tree fern [Cyathea medullaris], the latter often being a chief's prerogative for the white heart in the middle of the young leaves, which was baked and eaten.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1982
Source: Selected Poems
Author: BAXTER
Vol / Page: 189

Quote: punga <i>tree-fern </I>
Notes:

ponga
Homonym Number: 1
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:the New Zealand silver tree-fern <i>Cyathea dealbata</i>, (silver(y), white) treefern (or its trunk) (also other <i>Cyathea</i> spp.)
Origin:Maori
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: sometimes called bunga or bungie and often misspelt punga; Various spellings (once<i> ponja</i>) representing various pronunciations among English speakers, dividing roughly into a chiefly North Island form<i> punga</i> (almost a standard spelling) and an older (possibly obsolescent 1984) South Island form <i>bunger, bungie</i>.
Citations
Date: 4/2/1868
Source: Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page: 2
Edition:
Quote: Subsequently we built our houses; the sides we built of ponga (a species of fern tree) and the roofs we thatched with flax.
Notes:

Date: 11/6/1860
Source: Taranaki Herald
Author:
Vol / Page: 1
Edition:
Quote: The butt of the staff is charred, and lined in the ground all round with ponga (the stem of the fern tree), which never rots.

Vol / Page: 2

Quote: In the distance is seen the volcanic hills of this country .. while in the fore ground the graceful pongo (tree fern) casts a shadow over the solitary kiwi.

Vol / Page: 3

Edition: 1982
Quote: ... I got a Man who went & fetched me a Fern-tree with root and all, he called it <i>Ma</i>[macron]<i>a</i>[macron,grave]<i>gu</i>, & as I pointed to a large ferntree near me, with leaves whose underside is white, he shewed me the difference & called the latter <i>Po</i>[grave]<i>nga</i>. This Tree is full of tender pulp, ... and I believe this Fern is nearly related to the <i>Sago</i>-tree, which is likewise a Fern.
Notes:

Pongo

Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a British soldier; occas. derog. for a base-wallah, =bludger, =red arse (perhaps, from the military figurative connection between (field-officers red tabs etc developing) RED-ARSE with play ape's arse, and PONGO `ape'.)

Date: 0/0/1988
Source: Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
Author: McGILL
Vol / Page: 86
Edition:
Quote: <i>pongo</i> British person; originally used by British sailors to describe marine or soldier they were required to join forces with in WWI, probably not unaware that the word meant `monkey', though derivation credited to forage cap resembling that worn by the dog Pongo in a Punch and Judy show; brought back by Anzacs as name for their British counterpart.
Notes:

Pronunciation:
Notes: ca1938 (espec. children's)

Author: BAKER
Vol / Page: 42
Edition:

Date: 0/0/1949
Source: Dictionary of Slang Addenda
Author: PARTRIDGE
Vol / Page: 1140
Edition:
Quote: <i>Ponk</i>. As a New Zealand usage, however, it must be modified in the light of B., 1941: I suspect ... that when we speak of an offensive stench as a <i>ponk</i> we are coupling the Maori <i>puhonga</i>, stinking, offensive, with the earlier English use of <i>pong</i>.

Date: 0/0/1988
Source: Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
Author: McGILL
Vol / Page: 86
Edition:
Quote: <i>ponk</i> stink; possibly from Maori `puhonga', stinking or offensive, and English word `pong', which has the rare form `ponk'.

pool house

Sense Number:
Definition:a state house allocated for state servants on transfer ca1945 at least
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: I think pool housing probably arose from the committee mentioned in the Jan. 1947 cit; however, the only use of the term "pool" I found in 1947 and 1949 PSJs was the second which could be the first printed surfacing of an underground term.  The December 1946 issue has numerous "wanted to swap state house" advertisements indicating the need existed.

Quote: ...Tom says I am a sheeler for playing Poor Jenny ... My spelling cannot have improved much with the years for I had to look up the dictionary to find whether one spelt the word `sheila' or `sheilagh'. Of course `Poor Jenny' or `Poor Sally', as it is perhaps better known, was and no doubt still is a girl's game. As I had three doting sisters I cheerfully joined their games when my boy friends were not looking. Remember the words of the song? Poor Sally is a-weeping, a-weeping, a-weeping, Poor Sally is a-weeping, On a bright summer's day. On the carpet she shall kneel While the grass grows in the field - Stand up, stand up, upon your feet, And choose the one you love so sweet. Then followed `the moment of truth' and with girl and boy standing demurely in the middle of the ring of children, the circle danced around them singing: Now you're married I wish you joy, First a girl and then a boy. I forget the final words, if any. Usually this game was followed by `Ring-a-ring a rosie, Pop down a posie.' Strange, though, how the love-making aspect would come into many of these old games. I must have been a pronounced `sheeler' about this time because I also remember joining in the singing of I sent a letter to my love And on the way I dropped it, Some of you have picked it up And put it in your pocket. Dropped it - dropped it! And so on. A year or two later at the mellowing age of 10 years I abhorred all these `sissy' games though I still had a hankering to play `Oranges and Lemons', even at the great age of 12.
Notes: (1903 June 27) Pat Lawlor Wellington Diary in 1977 Aug. 27 Dominion 6 June 27 1903

poor pretences
Homonym Number:

Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: folk etymology

Citations
Date: 27/4/1880
Source: Hawke's Bay Herald
Author:
Vol / Page: 3
Edition:
Quote: I saw some man sowing grass seed the other day on one of the public roads, and to satisfy an innate curiosity I asked him what it was. "It's what they call 'poor pretences,'" he said, "and bedad, sir, it's a very good name, for it is that same, for divil a one of it iver comes up that ivir I sees!"
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1926
Source: Tutira
Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH
Vol / Page: 283
Edition:
Quote: In the early 'eighties occurred two dry seasons during which grass fires were run over the hot western and northern faces of certain portions on eastern Tutira; on the blackened ground then and once again seedlings of brome-grass (<i>Bromus mollis</i>) appeared in so great profusion that other grasses were temporarily submerged in hillsides of waving hay. [284] `Poor Pretences' was then the name by which this brome-grass was known on the east coast : it may be worth putting on record a suggestion as to how the plant came by such a curious designation. It was a `poor pretence' compared with ryegrass, cock's-foot, and white clover, the mixture sown then almost as a religious duty on Hawke's Bay runs, good and bad alike. So much for the sense; as regards the sound, `poor pretences' can, I think, only be a corruption of <i>Poa pratensis</i>; the Latin name of the one plant done into English has been fitted to another. The reader will recollect how this grass - more widely known as goose-grass - was sown wholesale over the trough of the run.
Notes:
