Source: tlc creativity Newsletter
Author:
Vol / Page: No. 25/1
Edition:
Quote: Finally, beware of the big purple poozle person (to poozle is to snaffle; to take).Things do go missing if left lying around – that includes tools, resources, equipment, materials and artwork. Put things away, be conscious of what you’re using and where it comes from. If something disappears whilst you’re using it, let the tutor know. And don’t poozle other people’s stuff without asking, or the original owner might forget to look after you and may break some furniture in their effort to get at you.

Date: 0/0/1971

Quote: Antique Alley is poozler heaven on Dominion Road.
Notes:

Date: 1/10/2004
Source: Letter
Author: HUGHES
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote: My old friend Kae Miller used to drive a gaily decorated van with "A Pride of Poozlers" inscribed on the side. My son Jonathan, who has driven that van, believes it was around in the early 1770. I am sure it was some time in the 70s. I have the impression, perhaps wrongly, that Kae invented the words poozle, poozling and poozler. Jonathan has the same belief but neither of us is sure if it is correct. She certainly used these words. Kae (single name Katrine Hursthouse), was a dedicated environmentalist,long before it was fashionable. Poozling was a part of her environmentalism. She poozled (I think she would have resisted the word "scavenge") diligently in the old Wilton tip and claimed to have rescued valuable antiques.
Notes:

poozling
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:scavenging for (especially old or antique) collector's items
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: e.g. `their bottle collection came from poozling under old houses'.       ca1974 p.c. P.B.O., et al. in Wellington and Christchurch -- a fanciful word (used also in Sydney now)

Citations
Date: 0/0/1980
Source: Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A
Author: LELAND
Vol / Page: 79
Edition:
Quote: <I>poozling</I>: Going through abandoned houses scheduled for demolition and removing the (usually antique) fittings that strike your fancy. Until recently this was a socially acceptable practice (although not strictly legal), however, as demolition contractors catch on to the value of these fittings legal and moral pressure is exerted to discourage the practice.
Notes:

popokatea
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:albicilla, white head; sometimes misspelt popokatea the whitehead, a North Island insectivorous forest-dweller, similar to but smaller than its South Island cousin, the mohua or yellowhead. [Maori popokotea[o1-macron]]
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:

Vol / Page: 1/29

Quote: In the lower regions the forest was much enlivened by birds. I shot some parrots [fn Nestor meridionalis. Kaka of the natives.], pigeons [fn Columba spadicea, Lath. Kukupa.], and wattle-birds [fn Glaucopis cinerea, Gmel. Kokako.]. Among the branches of the trees hopped the neat fantail flycatcher [fn Muscicapa flabellifera, Gml. Piwakawaka.], and a social bird of a yellow colour, which has been depicted by Forster [fn Orthornyx heteroclytus, Lef. Popokatea.], and which had much the habits of the finch.

Quote: The natives distinguish the bird as Tau-hou (which means stranger), or Kanohi-mowhiti (which may be interpreted as spectacle-eye or ring-eye). It is also called Poporoke [check = poporohe] and Iringatu, names suggested by its accidental or periodical occurrence.

Date: 0/0/1938
Source: Nor the Years Condemn
Author: HYDE
Vol / Page: 151
Edition:
Quote: The air beat and shimmered with sound . . . [sic] the poppers, eating with their thin blue tongues into rock ... <i>Ibid.</I> 186 The air [in the hydro tunnel] was filled with a ceaseless roar of air-compressors, poppers, and the biggest air-picks they had ever seen, all new machinery ... As the men's hands steadied the poppers (the tongues of flame eating into rotten sandstone ...), you could watch their taut arms vibrate, their bodies tremble.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1978
Source: Gold Mining at Waihi
Author: McARA
Vol / Page: 185
Edition:
Quote: It was not until considerably later that the `swing type' stoper with its pneumatic-feed-leg for drilling uppers, and known as the `popper', came into use. In it the drill was rotated in the hole by swinging the machine handle backwards and forwards. At first the miners did not like it, as they considered it `shook up' the roof too much, causing falls of ground, but it was light and easily transportable and was fast in good ground. It remained in use in the stopes for many years, until the much later introduction of the rotary stoper. At one stage the popper was given the rather undeserved name of the `widow-maker'.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1986
Source: Off the Sheep's Back
Author: RICHARDS
Vol / Page: 85
Edition:
Quote: For the first time in my life I saw, and heard, pneumatic drills at work. They were referred to as `poppers'.
Notes:

Date: 20/5/1912
Source: Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page: 7
Edition:
Quote: The miners at Blackwater have refused to work the popper, and only surface hands are now at work.
Notes:

Date: 27/5/1912
Source: Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page: 2
Edition:
Quote: In theory the rock drill which figures so prominently in the dispute at Reefton is a Waugh, but in practice it is a "popper." It is worked by compressed air, and a hammer, stirking 500 blows a minute, pops like a Maxim gun on the quartz overhead. Hence the name "popper."
Notes:

Date: 22/7/1912
Source: Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page: 7
Edition:
Quote: Sir Arthur Guinness interviewed the Prime Minister this morning, and urged him to appoint a Royal Commission to enquire and report whether the "popper" drill could with safety, and especially in regard to the health of the miners, be worked by one man.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1967
Source: West Coast Gold Rushes
Author: MAY
Vol / Page: 528
Edition: 1962
Quote: POPPET HEADS: cross-pieces of timber above the mouth of a shaft on which rest the axles of the pulleys used for winding. At Ballarat and at Ross `Poppet Heads' covered the whole erection at the mouth of a deep shaft.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1978
Source: Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary)
Author: McARA
Vol / Page: 329
Edition:

Date: 29/1/1994
Source: Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page: 56

Quote: When I was a child, a well-used term for any female accidentally showing too much underwear was "poppy show" - just saying the two words ensured a rapid hitching of petticoat or smoothing of rumpled skirts.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1953
Source: Unorganized Games
Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page: 2/665
Edition:
Quote: For example, when a girl's dress blows in the air, boys will claim they have seen a `poppy show'. This is a widespread term.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1981
Source: History of Children's Play
Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page: 223
Edition:
Quote: Pin dips were also another popular amusement. `A pin or a bull or a button, To see a rary rary show show show!' (1875; Tahataki). A piece of glass backed by cardboard was covered with a piece of paper that could be flicked up to show the `rary rary show' or had a slit in it through which one could peep. One saw through the glass a variety of colors, pieces of colored paper, flower petals, pictures, and later pieces off cigarette boxes. Sometimes these had been arranged in some pattern, at other times they were kaleidoscopic only, and the perceiver had himself to add the configurations of intelligibility. The price for the view was always a pin `which we did not want anyhow but always accepted,' a relic from an age when such things were rare. Pin dips were known also as `poppy shows' (perhaps it was the similar flash of color that gave the same name - `the poppy show' - to the exciting experience of seeing a girl's dress blown upward by the wind; pins were not charged for flowers of this sort). In fact, the pin dip or the prick book may have developed from the poppy show. The poppy show was common before 1900 and the prick book after that date, a fact connected with the ever-increasing stock of picture cards and magazine pictures available to children.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1968
Source: Pagan Game, The
Author: SLATTER
Vol / Page: 51
Edition:
Quote: The poppy shows with the Robertson tart in the pine plantation behind the hospital ... .
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1945
Source: Maori Place-Names of Canterbury
Author:
Vol / Page: 65
Edition:
Quote: Pora is an introduced vegetable run wild. The word `pora' means a ship. The plant flourished up the rivers, and the first settlers called it `Maori cabbage'. The lists also call it Pora-kawa-kawa, but this is amalgamating two names, for the kawakawa is another vegetable run wild.

Date: 0/0/1882
Source: Brighter Britain
Author: HAY
Vol / Page: 2/151
Edition:
Quote: In the bays and tidal rivers are the mango or sharks - the most highly-prized food-fish - the tamure or schnapper, the whapuka or rock-cod, the kahawai or mackerel, the porahi or herring, the kanae or mullet, the patiki or sole, and many others. On the shores are oysters, mussels, cockles, mutton-fish, crabs, and other shell-fish in profuse abundance. In the fresh-water creeks are eels (tuna), lampreys (pipiharau), and whitebait (inanga). <i>Ibid.</I> 2/231 We prefer the substantial schnapper, the goodly whapuka or kanae, or the luscious poraki. [ceck transcr. if use:?= porahi = porae]

Date: 0/0/1927
Source: Natural History of Canterbury
Author: SPEIGHT
Vol / Page: 192
Edition:
Quote: Three sharks built for speed are the Mako, the Porbeagle and the Great White Shark. ... The Porbeagle (<i>Lamna nasus </i>) has long sharp teeth, each with a small cusp at the base on either side; the Mako (<i>Isurus glaucus </i>) has teeth of similar shape without the cusps, and the Great White Shark (<i>Carcharodon carcharias </i>) has large triangular teeth with serrated edges.
Notes: Archey `Native Fishes of Canterbury' in Speight et al. Natural History of Canterbury

Date: 0/0/1981
Source: Fisherman's Bible
Author: WILSON
Vol / Page: 219
Edition:
Quote: PORBEAGLE SHARK<i> Lamna nasus</i>: A swife-swimming shark similar in appearance to the mako, but not rated highly by game fishermen as it lacks the mako's superb fighting qualities. Also known as Beaumaris-shark and Mackerel-shark. Prominent in New Zealand, particularly in Cook Strait. and pelagic shark of cool to temperate waters.

porch
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Jim writes: The question is whether the <i>British</i> use of porch is also wider than the dictionaries suggest. The absence of the terms sunporch etc from these dictionaries may be significant. I have noticed two (apparently) wider uses in Humphrey Carpenter's biography of Tolkien p.246 - "Now they had time simply to sit and talk especially on summer evenings after supper, on a bench in the front pocrch of Sandfield Road." [This is interesting for the author's phrase <i>in the porch</i>, whereas we would normally say <i>on the porch</i>. Also in Ruth Rendell, <i>Harm Done</i> p. 213. A 1987 Midlands Property Supplement has porch only in the sense of entrance porch (and then seldom); one or two ads have the term <i>storm porch</i> which was new to me. (Although porch and verandah are partly interchangeable, I think that the covered entrance to a meeting house - whare tipuna, wharenui - is always in English "porch", although it extends for the full width of the building.)

Quote: PLATYCERCUS NOVAE ZEALANDIAE. (RED-FRONTED PARRAKEET.) ...<i> Native names.</i> Kakariki, Kakawariki, Powhaitere, Porere[sic, check transc.], and Torete ...[59] The Red-fronted Parrakeet is very generally dispersed over the whole country - but is more plentiful in the southern portion of the North Island than in the far north, where the yellow-fronted species predominates. <i>Ibid.</I> 62 {1888 2nd edn 1/142} PLATYCERCUS AURICEPS. (YELLOW-FRONTED PARRAKEET.) ... <i>Native names</i>. Kakariki, Kakawariki, Powhaitere, Porere[sic, check tranc], and Torete ...[59] The Red-fronted Parrakeet is very generally dispersed over the whole country - but is more plentiful in the southern portion of the North Island than in the far north, where the yellow-fronted species predominates.

Date: 0/0/1941
Source: NZ Journal of Science & Technology
Author:
Vol / Page:  22/309A-310A
Edition:
Quote: The depredations of the subterranean grass caterpillar [<i>Oxycanus</i> sp.] in the rye-grass and clover pastures, particularly in ... the east coast of the South Island, have been recognized for some years as demanding control measures. The damage ... is probably only second in importance to that done by the true `grass grub,' <i>Odontria zealandica</i>. Until recently, practically all damage done to pasture was attributed to <i>Odontria</i>, [310] and only recently have farmers commenced to distinguish between the two pests, and to refer to<i> [Oxycanus]</i> as `grass caterpillar,' or`<i>Porina </i>caterpillar.' It is unfortunate that the generic name <i>Porina</i>, which was coming into general use, must now be changed to <i>Oxycanus</i>, since the name <i>Porina</i> is preoccupied as a molluscan genus.
Notes:

porina
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number: 1

Source: South Canterbury
Author: GILLESPIE
Vol / Page: 10
Edition: 1970
Quote: The ones attracting most attention were the owlet moths, the caterpillars of which destroyed the first pastures and cereal and root crops. There were also porina moths (<i>Oxycanus spp.</i>) whose caterpillars also destroyed pastures; the bag moth (<i>Oeceticus omnivorus</i>) which left cigar-shaped cocoons hanging from shrubs and tree [sic]; and the ghost-like white moth ... of the flax grub (<i>Orthoclydon praefectata</i>) which eats longitudinal slits on the surface of [flax] leaves ...

pork(y)
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:(in Maori use) a pig
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1963
Source: Speech and Idiom of Maori Children
Author: ANDERSON & AITKEN
Vol / Page: 38
Edition: 1965
Quote: Terms such as `moo-cow' and `baa-lamb' were not encountered once [among Maori schoolchildren]. In the light of this, it is interesting to note the common form `pork' or `Porky' for `pig'. This occurs several times and in contexts which would not lead one to suspect baby talk of any kind; <i>We just about got some pork.</i> This usage refers not to the meat, but to the living animals, and against this usage the form `pig' occurs only once. <i>Ibid</i> 105 <i>Please, it's a porky. I'm a pork</i> ... When they use [`pig'] themselves it tends to be only in derogatorative [sic] contexts; Get out of my sight, you dirty pig!
Notes:

porker
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a (wild) pig; a Captain Cooker
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: the few early (pre-1900) recorded uses suggest that it is a re-anglicisation of Maori <i>poaka</i>, itself an anglicised version of <i>pork(er)</i>, rather than a direct use of OED `young hog fattened for pork', etc (1657) - as elsewhere in NZ English (cf <i>baconer</i>). Perhaps the first of the following uses are merely whimsical. (cf poaka, porky) [?1838 cit. really poaka]
Citations
Date: 3/6/1843
Source: Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle
Author:
Vol / Page: 260
Edition:

Had the Englishmen given a word they would probably have said `pig,' not `porker,' and the Maoris would have called the animals<i> piki</i>.

Quote: (from the <i>Australasian</i>) .. The yellow clusters of the spreading dark-leaved pura-pura .. the little fiery branches of the red porokaiwhiria; the rich luscious berries of the kotukutuku, or giant fucshia, whose flowers hang side by side with ripe fruit, and unopened buds. All these, and many another fruit of the woods, fell upon the warrior's path, and allayed their hunger.

poroporo
Homonym Number: 1
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:<i>Solanum aviculare</i> (also <i>S.nigrum</i>; also called bull-a-bull a) a fruit-bearing shrub of the nightshade family. b) its edible orange-yellow berry.  BULL-A-BULL (etc.), =POTATO BERRY, the plant and its fruit
Origin:Maori
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]

Date: 29/10/2005
Source: Dominion Post
Author:
Vol / Page: E13
Edition:
Quote: Poroporo is a common, leafy soft-wooded shrub that grows throughout New Zealand.  It is quickly growing colonising plant, reaching a height of three metres (ideal for native bush revegetation sites) and grows on the edge of coastal and lowland forests and along road edges and clearings.  ... Reputedly having a mild acidic taste similar to the cape gooseberry, poroporo was cultivated and eaten by Maori and early European colonists who made jam from it.

Vol / Page: 168
Edition:
Quote: <i>SOLANUM LACINIATUM.</i> Poroporo (bullibul) is a soft-wooded shrub ... Two species are called by one Maori name. Two Latin names, <i>S. laciniatum</i> and <i>S. aviculare</i>, are both more than a hundred years old but it was only in 1954 that Baylis defined clearly the difference between the two species and then the two names came into general use.

Date: 0/0/1926
Source: Weeds of New Zealand
Author: HILGENDORF
Vol / Page: 99
Edition: 1967
Quote: PIRI PIRI (<i>Aceara ... sanguisorbae</i>). This name is commonly corrupted into [called] bidi bid. In the North Island the plant is called hutiwai or utiwai and by mistake poroporo. It is a native species well known to all New Zealanders, and is a weed chiefly on land in process of being brought into occupation.
Notes:

Before our guides returned, I had shot a great many of the unweary pukeko, or porphyrio, which proved excellent game.
Notes:

Port Craig cocktail
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Excerpt from Wise: PORT CRAIG Remote locality on the western shoreline of Te Waewae Bay, on the Foveaux Strait coast of Wallace County, South Island... Crayfishing. Once the port for sawmilling settlement with a large timbermill but the site was abandoned when the venture folded in the financial depression of the 1930s. Named after mill hand John Craig, one of two men drowned at the mouth of the nearby Waikoua River. Reed's Place Names says: Well known at one time as having the largest timbermill in NZ. This was established by the Marlborough Timber Company. A recent pamphlet by Bremer gives a good account of the mill in 1927 but does not mention cocktails.

Date: 0/0/1967

Author: MILLER
Vol / Page: 176

Quote: They decided to try as a reviver a "Port Craig cocktail", made as follows:: Take a cup - or a round tobacco tin - and drop in one egg. Add one tablespoon of Worcester sauce and one eggcup of methylated spirits. Mix well, hold nose, swallow rapidly.<i> Ibid.</i> 177 The Port Craig cocktail was made and sampled.

Author: FORSTER
Vol / Page: 2/220
Edition: 1982
Quote: We saw a great Variety of bird this day viz. A white & sooty Albatross <i>Diomedea exulans & palpebrata</i>). The black & sooty Petrel, (<i>Procellaria aequinoctialis & fuliginosa</i>) the black banded Petrel (<i>Procellaria vittata</i>); the small white rumped Petrel (<i>Proc. pelagica</i>) & we saw likewise three times a <i>Port Egmont Hen</i>, which is commonly thought a mark of the vicinity of Land. [ed. fn] The birds listed here are, respectively, the Wandering Albatross; Light-mantled Sooty Albatross; White-chinned Petrel; Great-winged Petrel; <i>Pachyptila</i> spp; Wilson's Storm Petrel and Antarctic Skua.

porthole
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:the small gate in a shearing shed through which sheep are released after shearing or dagging

Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1913
Source: Country Work
Author: CARR
Vol / Page: 14
Edition:
Quote: Fleece-picking. - As soon as a shearer has taken the fleece off and let the sheep go through the port-hole to the counting-out pen, the picker gathers the fleece up in such a manner that she or he can on getting to the rolling table, throw it out with the breech part at the right end.
Notes:

Date: 11/2/1977
Source: Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page: 19
Edition:
Quote: As he talked about this Mr Loughnan chanced to speak of shearers putting their sheep out through the "ports" or "portholes" of sheds and jotted down these words to check whether he had them on his lists.
Notes:

Vol / Page: 256

Quote: Porthole The rectangular opening (with sliding door) facing the shearer on his stand through which newly shorn sheep are discharged to the yard via counting-out pens. Sometimes shortened to ports. [port; porthole]

posher
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a copper-stick for beating clothes when washing them
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Joh saw one of these for sale in Taupo "The man behind the counter said it was an English term; bsasically it was a broomstick with a hollow copper head, like a plunger in shape. The man said sometimes the copper head contained marbles so that madam could hear that the maid was indeed working. Ian Douglas (51 Liverpool St, Wanganui; dougie@xtra.co.nz) says the term used in England 60 years ago was "poss stick" a long wooden stick.  "There was also a 'posser'which was a pole with a sort of vacuum creating hood on the end which was used to dump or dunk the clothes up and down and help shift the dirt."

In much the same way that consumers could have their coffee flavoured in a complex range of strengths, flavours and styles, the POSIFood system could alter the formula of snack foods to suit health needs depending on a person's age, weight or physical condition.

Date: 0/0/1963
Source: In the Sticks
Author: BACON
Vol / Page: 182
Edition:
Quote: <i>possum</i>-The Australian marsupial introduced in the early days (in 1858, 1870, 1895) as a means of fostering a fur trade, but now one of New Zealand's greatest pests. Not to be confused with the American opposum which is carnivorous, the Australian possum is vegetarian.
Notes:

Date: 28/6/1988
Source: Auckland  Star
Author:
Vol / Page: 1
Edition:
Quote:  `I believe that the member for Tarawera is referring to the possum (Trichosurus vulpecula), not opossums (genus Didelphis) which are American marsupials,' [Agriculture Minister Moyle] said in his written reply. ... And for the name, you can be forgiven if you call our imported possum (the `brushtail possum,' to be precise) an opossum. The Aussie possum - there are about six types across the Tasman - looked so much like the American counterpart when first discovered by Europeans that it was called an opossum. As recently as 1981, scientists who turned up for the first New Zealand symposium on marsupials ... were sagely talking about possums in 12 of the papers presented while their colleagues talked about opossums in six papers. All were referring to the same nocturnal nuisance. One of the great achievements of that symposium was to finish up talking the same language after taking a vote that favoured for possum. ... The fur trade is pushing for `NZ phalanger' (a generic name for a group of marsupials) while possum stew exporters are trying to win acceptance for `Kiwi bear' in Oriental restaurants.
Notes:

Date: 27/10/1989
Source: Letter
Author: STUART C. MACDIARMID
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote: In Australia and New Zealand the word possum is now almost universally accepted among professional zoologists and is the most widely-used colloquial name for the Australian phalanger of which the common brushtail possum, <i>Trichosurus vulpecula</i>, is an example.
Notes: STUART C. MACDIARMID, National Adviser, Health MAFQUAL

Register:
Register 2:
Domain:Rural
Region:[none]
See:posts and rails
Pronunciation:
Notes: posts and rails		Also elsewhere; aka post and rails; note also posts and rails usually in reference to components of fence rather than the fence; includes attributive use
Citations

post and rail tea
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: aka post and rail(s) [check Burdon see if independent occurrence in NZ or Morris tradition]
Citations
Date: 0/0/1940
Source: Te Waimate
Author: STUDHOLME
Vol / Page: 91
Edition: 1954
Quote: Many of the old station cooks, with the assistance of an `offsider' (mate) found no difficulty in cooking for fifty or sixty men. ... it has to be remembered that ... bread cost only 6d. or 7d. a 4lb. loaf, and tea (post and rails) could be bought for 1/- per lb. Some of these contract cooks were great fossickers and managed to find quite a lot of green stuff for vegetables ...
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1898
Source: Merriam-Webster Third International
Author:
Vol / Page: 2029
Edition:
Quote: <i>Post </i>(p&omacr.st),<i> n</i>. [Add.] <i>Post and rail tea, or Posts and rails, </i>a decoction of coarse tea; - so called because the floating leaves resemble sticks or rails.<i> [Colloq., Australia] </i>
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1968
Source: NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins)
Author:
Vol / Page: 16
Edition:
Quote: <i>post-and-rails (tea)</i> strong, coarse, inferior tea made in a billy (q.v.) with pieces of stalk or leaves floating in it.
Notes:

post and rail tea
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number: 1
Definition:a coarse drinking tea with pieces of leaves and stalk floating on the surface.
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:Rural
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1898
Source: Austral English
Author: MORRIS
Vol / Page: 367
Edition:
Quote: Post-and-Rail Tea, slang name for strong bush-tea: so called because the large bits of the tea, or supposed tea, float about in the billy, which are compared by a strong imagination to the posts and rails of the wooden fence so frequent in Australia. [1851]
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1914
Source: Diggers' Story, The
Author: PFAFF
Vol / Page: 43
Edition:
Quote:  I forgot tea, 4s. .. but the quality; we used to call it Posts and Rails [on the diggings c1860s].
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1982
Source: Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery
Author: BURTON
Vol / Page: 16
Edition:
Quote:  ... the tea was `of the commonest kind'. The brand was Young Green Hyson, but the [missionary] settlers nicknamed the foul brew `post and rails'. This was a reference to the twigs which floated about on the surface, large enough to form the posts and rails of a wooden fence.
Notes:

Source: Wellington Independent
Author:
Vol / Page: 5
Edition:
Quote: But even that sparkling individual himself must be aware that "post and rail" tea and roasted corn coffee are "filth;" and sugar impregnated with arsenic is unfortunately "poison."

postie
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:(informal) the person who delivers letters. (spg occas. posty) a Post Office worker who delivers the mail; (formerly) postman.
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: This term has, I consider, become general in N.Z. only after WW2, prob'y from ca1950; first as an urban endearment (everyone loves the postman or postwoman. - but cf the quot. below).
Citations
Date: 5/12/1992
Source: Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page: 43
Edition:
Quote: He dropped out to become a postie and play in a band, giving it up when he realised he wasn't going to "cut it as a muso."
Notes:

Date: 10/5/1997

Author:
Vol / Page: 11
Edition:
Quote: He maintains a serious commitment to his postie round...
Notes:

Date: 25/7/1963
Source: Dominion
Author:
Vol / Page: 4
Edition:
Quote: Sir, - According to a recent report in `The Dominion' the Chief Postmaster at Wellington is reported to have used the term `posties' in referring to certain of his staff of postmen and postwomen. This is a slang term, derogatory and discourteous, like the term `cop' for police officer, `cockie' for farmer, and `rag' for newspapers. He should be asked to apologize to these diligent people who work on Saturdays when most other workers enjoy this day off duty, and when speaking about his staff should in future refer to them by thier correct and proper designation, postmen and postwomen. GEORGE H. DAVIS. New Plymouth.
Notes:

pot
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a drink, a jar, a flagon; often pl, in phrase <i>a few pots</i>; or <i>a quiet pot,</i> a drink (esp. a beer)  (The NZ usage seems more specific than OED sb1 2.b ellipt. A pot of liquor; transf. liquor, drink; drinking, potation. (also pl) cf <i>Cup</i> sb 10. 1583-1849. It may however be merely standard English. Part: usage seems not as specific as in NZ I have only heard this usage post WW2; ? introduced from Britain)
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: ? cf WF n(5) + (6)
Citations
Date: 0/0/1963
Source: Half-Gallon Jar
Author: McCALLUM
Vol / Page: 18
Edition:
Quote: [I] go down to the pub to have a few pots with the boys <i>Ibid.</i> I ... have just settled down to enjoy a quiet pot ... when ...
Notes:

pot and pan
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:old man; parent
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: ca1949 Havelock (Len Climo) (fairly well-known in NZ. Perhaps brought back by 2NZEF, WW2) . rhyming slang

potae
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a hat, head covering. [Maori potae[o-macron]]
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: ca1900 Auckland P.S.Ardern Quite commonly used for<i> hat. </i> ca1935 Havelock (? jocularly used; as also was <i>tile</i> from the popular song `Where did you get that hat?') ca1965 Jan Heard in Wellington `Crikey, cop that potae.'

potato bird
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:cuckoo
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1904
Source: TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page: 36/134
Edition:
Quote: Like the Cuckoos in other parts of the world, they appear before rainy weather or coincident with it, and have thus come to be known in many widely different localities as `Rain-birds' and `Storm-birds'. In many parts of Otago and Canterbury they were called by the early settlers `Potato-birds', as they invariably came on the scene as the potato-planting was going on; similarly, in the North Island they got the name of `Kumara-birds'.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1940
Source: TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page: 36/134
Edition:
Quote: In many parts of Otago and Canterbury they [long-tailed cuckoos] were called potato birds by the early settlers as they invariably came on the scene as the potato-planting was going on; similiarly, in the North Island they got the name of `Kumara-birds'.
Notes: (Fulton)

pothead
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a worthless person, fool (a loan translation of Maori upoko kohua, i.e. someone whose head is fit only for the cooking pot)
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: (Finlayson 141) Pothead: translation of a Maori insult more serious than it sounds in English.

Register 2:
Domain:Rural
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:

Citations
Date: 0/0/1985
Source: Woolscours of NZ
Author: BREMNER
Vol / Page: 9
Edition:
Quote: <i>Potstick</i> wooden pole 6 feet long and 2 inches thick, used to stir and lift wool during the wash. <i>Ibid.</I> 17 The potstick woolwashers were the industry's founders. <i>Ibid.</I> A hot soak preceded the cold-water wash, and in the Medieval manner a strong arm wielded the six-foot potstick or the sluice fork stirring and lifting sodden wool. Scouring machines were a remote dream. <i>Ibid.</I> 34 Even in the mid-1960s, recalls Brian Redding, the present owner , `they were potsticking slipe wool from the fellmongery; via a wooden chute, water went into a box with a mesh base and a fellow stirred [35] the wool with a stick!'

Notes:

Date: 0/0/1980
Source: Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A
Author: LELAND
Vol / Page: 79
Edition:
Quote: <i>pottle</i>: The South Island term for a SMALL CONTAINER. Originally applied to the little wooden boxes in which berry fruit was sold, it then transferred to the plastic boxes which replaced them. A further extension of the term applied it to small plastic containers of yoghurt and sour cream. (see: <i>punnet, chip</i>)
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1986
Source: NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary
Author:
Vol / Page: 589
Edition:
Quote: <i>pottle n. NZ</i> open cardboard or plastic container in which potato chips etc. are sold; closed container (for yoghurt).

Vol / Page: 12

Quote: Many people here in the South Island, where the best strawberries are grown, refer to a small strawberry container as a pottle. On the June 29 programme one of the teams gave the answer `pottle' to a question about what small strawberry containers were called, and were then penalised for a wrong answer. Their puzzled expressions were quite understandable to anyone living south of Cook Strait.

Date: 0/0/1897
Source: TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page: 29/162
Edition:
Quote: In this paper I will endeavour to prove that the large, mythological, and extinct bird the poua, traditionally spoken of by the remaining surrvivors of the Moriori people who inhabit the Chatham Islands, was not allied to the moa ... but was a species of swan, and belonged to the family <i>Anatidae</i>.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1989
Source: Prodigious Birds
Author: ANDERSON
Vol / Page: 91
Edition:
Quote: Post-European re-working of different legends about big birds.. seems even more evident in the names poua and pouaki. These were alleged by Tare te Maiharoa an influential South Island chief about the turn of the 20th century to be the true, ancient names for moas.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1875
Source: TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page: VII/117
Edition:
Quote: It appears that the Morioris have traditions about a great bird, called by them Puoa... The Morioris have a song about it, and repeat the first syllable as a chorus, Pu, pu - Pu, pu - Pu, o-a, in a manner which recalls the hollow drumming noise made by the emu. The word is probably a contraction for Pu-pu-moa.
Notes: This is the article by Cockburn-Hood referred to by Anderson in "Prodigious Birds"

poukai
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:any of a round of annual hui attended by the Maori King (or, formerly, Queen) in Kingite territory
Origin:Maori
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1993
Source: Dictionary of NZ Biography
Author:
Vol / Page: 2
Edition:
Quote: Home in Waikato, Tawhiao sought solutions to Maori problems through the establishment of Maori institutions to deal with them. In 1885 he initiated the institution of Poukai, where the King would pay annual visits to King movement marae to encourage people to return to their home marae at least once a year. The first Poukai (originally called Puna-kai, or 'source of food') was held at Whatiwhatihoe in March 1885. It was a day for the less fortunate to be fed and entertained. The Poukai developed into an event which would later ensure direct consultation of the people with the King.
Notes: from the DNZB entry on King Tawhiao (R.T. Mahuta) (updated online version 2007)

Date: 18/1/2007
Source: Whakatane Beacon
Author:
Vol / Page: 1
Edition:
Quote: KOKOHINAU Marae in Te Teko had the honour of hosting, for the first time in the Mataatua area, the Maori King, Tuheitia on Sunday.... Mr Eruera said the king was attending a poukai, or assembly, and this was the 44th year it had been held at Kokohinau. ...  A copy of a publication celebrating the 44 years of the poukai being held at Kokohinau was also given to the king by Katerina Waiari. Teriaki Amoamo, on behalf of Whakatohea and Te Whanau-a-Apanui, presented a ceremonial hoe waka (canoe paddle).Mr Eruera said the open debate session, which is what a poukai is all about, raised a few issues. One of those issues was brought up earlier in the day by Whakatohea and Te Whanau-a-Apanui who requested to share the poukai in the future. Mr Eruera said the request would have to go to hapu members to consider.A restored flagpole was also erected – hapu members, under the direction of carver Graham Junior Niao, carried out the restoration on the carved pole – and the special poukai flag was flown.
Notes:

Notes:

pounamu
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:greenstone
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: alternate spelling: Poonamoo, Poenammoo, Poanamo, Poeananiamiou; note also inanga / inanga pounamu, whitish variety
Citations
Date: 21/12/1904

Author:
Vol / Page: 21
Edition:

Date: 5/8/1857
Source: Lyttelton Times
Author:
Vol / Page: 5
Edition:
Quote: Mr. Fyfe had found a moa's egg, at the Kai Koras, while digging the foundation for his store. It is a foot long, about 6 inches in diameter, and 27 inches in circumference. The shell is the 16th part of an inch in thickness. A hole is drilled in the end of it, and the egg must have been considered of great value by the natives, as it was found deposited at the head of a skeleton, with a number of very large poenamu axes. Mr. Fyfe, we understand, is going to send them home to the British Museum.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1929
Source: Primitive Economics of NZ Maori
Author: FIRTH
Vol / Page: 388
Edition:
Quote: Among the Maori, considerations of aesthetic interest helped quite materially .. to decide the relative worth of objects made of the <I>pounamu</I>, the nephrite so much prized for pendants, <I>mere</I>, and adzes. Most prized was the <I>kahurangi</I> stone, bright green, translucent, hard and clear; the <I>inanga </I>variety perhaps comes next, with its white milky-veined appearance, 389] followed by the <I>kawakawa</I>, dark olive-green, dull and opaque. .. <I>Tangiwai</I> (`tear drop'), <I>bowenite</I>, a softer stone of a clear pale green, with the appearance of drops of water in the texture, was less esteemed, though more beautiful in the European eyes, whilst <I>kahotea</I>, green, spotted or streaked with black, was an inferior type, and was used for small chisels, and for objects of subordinate interest.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1962
Source: Pound of Saffron, A
Author: JOSEPH
Vol / Page: 113
Edition:
Quote: `The jade, the pounamu .. It's a beautiful stone .. Look,' he said, holding up a long hooked ear-drop of pearly translucence, `that's tau tau and the stone is called inanga. And this, the pekapeka - they say the shape comes from the bat. This is for the ear, too - the mako, like a shark's tooth .. And these,' - he ran his fingers along a row of .. nephrite adzes - `toki. See this one' - he held the heavy red-mottled adze in his palm - `that's the red kind, totoweka, woodhen's blood. The deep green, that's kawakawa.'
Notes:

pound
Homonym Number: 2
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:2
Definition:solitary confinement; a punishment cell or area
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1971
Source: Bullshit and Jellybeans
Author: SHADBOLT
Vol / Page: 15
Edition:
Quote: The day before the following weekend I was locked up in the pound. A pound is for locking up animals. If only we'd been animals the RSPCA and all the animal lovers would have caused a public outcry - but we were only humans so no one worried. There had been no reason for punishing me - the official reason given was that I was put there as an assistant cleaner. The cleaner already there had virtually nothing to do. So the whole deal was hell of an unusual - in fact no crim I met had ever before heard of a situation in which an inmate who'd committed no offence had been sent to the pound - especially as an assistant cleaner.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1980
Source: While We Have Prisons
Author: MacKENZIE
Vol / Page: 14
Edition:
Quote: The punishment block, known as the `pound' or the `dummy', was a prison within the [Mt Eden] prison. In the basement, through a steel grille and a wooden door, it was a dimly lit and silent annexe leading at its far end to the tiny execution yard. <i>Ibid.</I> 98 <i>pound</i> punishment block

pound
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:used in various transf. uses and fig. senses (often graded between 1 and 19) to express various conditions of alleged intellectual handicap, mental bankruptcy, implying that a person is not all there; see also bob, quid, shilling; the formula is usu.: to be/pay (only) [x] bob (shillings) in the pound or not to be 20 shillings in the pound; cf. not the full quid; ?a synonym from punting for to be a shingle short, be two bob in the pound, to be sixpence in the shilling
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: 1951 14 M 14 St Bede's, Chch 2 POUND, NINETEEN AND ELEVEN IN THE

Date: 0/0/1838
Source: New Zealand  (Polack)
Author: POLACK
Vol / Page: 1/91
Edition:
Quote: A <i>powaka</i> [a's-acute], or hut raised on poles, with some elaborately carved facing boards, on which was executed several figures of an indelicate nature, stood in the centre of the village.  <i>Ibid.</I> 2/32 The powaka [a2-acute] or village store has been described, in which the tribes keep their best apparel, ammunition, &c.; ...
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1840
Source: Manners & Customs of the NZers
Author: POLACK
Vol / Page: 1/209
Edition:
Quote: [caption to carved buildings raised on posts] <i>Na[acute] Powaka, or Village depositaries of the natives. ... </i>[210]Next to the <i>Warre no te Rangatira, </i>or native palace, the village museum <i>(po[acute]waka)</i> in which the valuables of the community of the place are deposited, receives careful attention of the native Vitruvius. These erections are raised on four stout carved poles, the sides of the house are faced with boards, carved with a profusion of indelicate subjects, exaggerated in such a manner as to leave no spectator in any dilemma as to the actual meaning and intention of the artist. In these huts, or rather boxes (the literal meaning) are placed fowling-pieces, esteemed garments, ... <i>Ibid.</I> 1/228 The most elaborate carvings are bestowed on the boxes (<i>powa[acute]ka</i>) that serve to enclose feathers for decorating the head on gala days, and other portable trinkets.
Notes:

(RED-FRONTED PARRAKEET.) ... <i>ive names</i>kariki, Kakawariki, Powhaitere, Porere, and Torete ...[59] The Red-fronted Parrakeet is very generally dispersed over the whole country - but is more plentiful in the southern portion of the North Island than in the far north, where the yellow-fronted species predominates. <i>Ibid.</I> 62 PLATYCERCUS AURICEPS. (YELLOW-FRONTED PARRAKEET.) ... <i>Native names</i>. Kakariki, Kakawariki, Powhaitere, Porere, and Torete ...[59] The Red-fronted Parrakeet is very generally dispersed over the whole country - but is more plentiful in the southern portion of the North Island than in the far north, where the yellow-fronted species predominates.

Informal public-private relationships are not new - governments have long invited business people to Wellington to discuss policy formulation or test ideas, often over lunch or dinner. But formal PPPs, in which a government enters into a contract with a private company to build new infrastructure, are not yet legal in New Zealand.

They occur when a government needs major capital works done, but the work is on a scale that would seriously unbalance the public balance sheet. <i>Ibid.</i> 24 Essentially, the PPP term entered the national lexicon only with the Birch report for Auckland City Council in 2001. Treasury had also once suggested that a PPP variant might be a way of financing construction of the new hospital planned for Wellington.

Sense Number:

Related to a similar species inSouth Australia also erroneously calledprawnkiller and quite different from theEastern Australia prawnkiller which doeshave the chelae to crunch prawns.

pre-emption
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:The collocations pre-emptive right, right of pre-emption, pre-emptive land, were all used in the early days of the Colony when land-purchasing was keen; a legal or historical word, modified in Colonial usage formerly well-known but now dropped in popular speech. --

Vol / Page: 2/37

Quote: As to the preemptive right, please send me the best description you can of what we should apply for. We have a right to <i>`80 acres at one of the stations and 10 acres at each of the other stations erected upon the run'</i> ... It seems, however, that there must be a station of some sort at the place where preemptive is applied for; but it would be easy to have a hut put up at any place where we wanted to take our land.
Notes: (C.W. Richmond)

Edition:

Vol / Page: 11
Edition:
Quote: A pastoral licensee could use his, and rarely her, pre-emptive rights to lock up the land along a mile of road for the cost of the fencing, say £60, when to buy the same land outright would cost a settler £600 .. in some cases huts and fences would be erected to obtain a pre-emptive right over the adjacent land after which they were pulled down and put up elsewhere to enable fresh claims to be made.

prefab
Homonym Number: 1
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:1. a prefabricated building, esp. a class room: abbrev. of prefabricated building, in New Zealand originally chiefly applied to such Army huts during and after WW2; thence, and now almost specifically, to pre-fabricated classrooms (the idea for these originally deriving from the availability of surplus prefab. army huts) which have been since about the mid forties, such a feature of school-building practice to meet expanding school rolls.>esp. temporary educational
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:

Date: 0/0/1968
Source: Pagan Game, The
Author: SLATTER
Vol / Page: 85
Edition:
Quote: There was [postal] work [in the 1960s], hard satisfying work. Unloading parcel bags, huge cumbersome containers nicknamed pre-fabs, from a three-door Z. There was slots, there was lumps, there was packing fragies in bottlos, there was the tying down of the north line for a clearance, the scissors, lead seals and squeezers. The sorters on call-back flicking circulars with precision. The volcanoes of letters on the facing-up table, the checker chanting the reds onto the lorry, the checker calling the overseas in, London 45 ... The queue of men working at the parcel depot or the postal siding ... Tieing down the cargon. ... The sorters' school at the posties' pub known colloquially as Box 44 or the B.B.C., the Back Bar of the Cecil. The cheerful abuse of cobbers.

Notes:

Date: 0/0/1966
Source: Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An
Author: McLINTOCK
Vol / Page: 2/868
Edition:
Quote: In the constitutional debates of 1854 during the first session of the New Zealand Parliament, the term `Prime Minister' was frequently used in a somewhat casual fashion. This explains in part why it was some years before the term `Premier' came into general usage. William Fox (q.v.) who took office in July 1861, was described in the <I>Gazette</I> as Attorney-General `with first seat in the Ministry'. In November 1864 Weld (q.v.) was gazetted as holding `a seat in the Executive Council and the office of Premier'. Stafford (q.v.) his successor, in October 1865 was termed `First Minister'. In June 1869, when Fox again headed a Ministry, he was described officially as `Premier and member of the Executive Council.' Thereafter the term `Premier' was regularly used. Nevertheless, in the Schedule of the Civil List Act of 1873, provision was made for the salary of the Leader of the Government `being the Prime Minister'. The first Premier to use the title `Prime Minister' officially was Richard John Seddon (q.v.). It was used in the <I>New Zealand Year Book</I> of 1900 and the Imperial Conference of 1903 confirmed the practice.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1880
Source: Chudleigh Diary
Author:
Vol / Page: 289
Edition: 1950
Quote: Wellington. Interviewed the premier Sir John Hall ... Dined at Bellamys ...

presently
Homonym Number:
Word Class:adverb
Sense Number:
Definition:At directly this etym. comment: [OED2 6c dial and US 1851 `shortly' applies generally in NZ rather than 6 a. `immediately'. Compare the use ofpresently.] The following is moved from the DIRECTLY entry for check at PRESENTLY: presently. In NZ presently usually means `in a short while' (as OED 4), but I have heard it used occas. as immediately (OED 4). At <i>presently</i> 4, OED notes `In blunted sense (gradually weakened from 3): ... soon, shortly. (cf ANON 5, BY and BY 4, and colloq use of <i>directly, immediately,</i> and nearly all advbs of the same kind.) Now the ordinary use.'; W3]
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: The OED would seem to belie the citation from the Listener

Citations
Date: 26/7/1986
Source: Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page: 11
Edition:
Quote: This was in the days when "presently" meant "later" - not "as of now" as it seems to today.

press

Date: 27/5/1880

Vol / Page: 3
Edition:
Quote: My wish is to see a proper use made of all the natural resources, and I would even go so far as for instance to use the pressure of the water, before it is supplied to the ships, or before a street is filled with it, to press wool, or do some other service on the wharf.
Notes:

Date: 24/11/1862
Source: Chudleigh Diary
Author:
Vol / Page: 67
Edition: 1950
Quote: My employment was chiefly in packing the woolbales which is very heavy work. You put from 90 to 120 fleeces in a bail which way [sic] from 300 to 350 lbs. It is hard to press the wool into so small a compass. We sheared some 850 sheep to-day.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1945
Source: NZ Geographer
Author:
Vol / Page: 1/39
Edition:
Quote:  `Press' and `sweep' are technical terms for necessary operations in the woolshed at shearing time. The former refers to pressing the fleeces into tight-packed bales ... to facilitate the transport of an otherwise bulky commodity. The latter is the process of keeping the floor (the `boards'), on which the sheep are shorn, clear of loose ends of wool, dirt and excrement.
Notes:  (Pascoe `Canterbury High Country')

Date: 0/0/1894
Source: In the Land of the Tui
Author: WILSON
Vol / Page: 242
Edition:
Quote: At the main entrance of the shearing-shed, which is a long building with pens down the centre, and an outlet at each end, stands a wool-press, and behind this are the bins into which the fleeces, after having been classed, are placed preparatory to being pressed.
Notes:

Date: 15/11/1889
Source: Chudleigh Diary
Author:
Vol / Page: 1950
Edition:
Quote: 368 9548 sheep shorn, 139 bales pressed. I think sheep and wool will be up to last year; run sheep much better. Ewe and paddock sheep not so good. Lice in wool and [dust from] ploughed ground all through Ewe mob. All the paddock sheeps wool must be scoured.

Date: 0/0/1838
Source: New Zealand  (Polack)
Author: POLACK
Vol / Page: 1/75
Edition:
Quote: Every one of them [sc. Maoris] came up to press noses, which I enacted with a few of the foremost; but respect for the shape and position of this ornamental member, made me  abridge the ceremony, or I should never have retained its pristine form, so eager were these new friends to greet and welcome my arrival. <i>Ibid.</i> 85 Each presentation was accompanied by the pressing of noses  (e'ongi) and expressions of `Friend, welcome; how are you all,' &c.  `Ekoro airamai tenarakokoe[a2-acute],' in a whiningtone, as if each were about to condole for the loss of their entire generation.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1913
Source: Country Work
Author: CARR
Vol / Page: 14
Edition:
Quote:  The boss Maori undertakes to supply all the rouseabouts (as shed hands are termed) i.e., fleece pickers, wool rollers and `Sheep oh!' the [sic] owner or manager generally gets his own pressers and expert (where machines are run). <i>Ibid.</I> 15-16 Pressing. - When there is sufficient wool in one bin, the pressers (generally two) get to work. One gets into the `box' as the lower portion of the patent presses is called, while his mate ... hands him ... the fleeces. These are placed in tiers, and tramped down until the lower box is full. An upper box is then swung ... or [16] lowered on to the lower one, and the process repeated. When full, the `monkey' or cover is put into position, the spears (wire rope) affixed, and the two men lever the cover down until the top box is clear.
Notes:

Source: NZ Observer
Author:
Vol / Page: 21
Edition:

Quote: Pressing. - When there is sufficient wool in one bin, the pressers (generally two) get to work. One gets into the `box' as the lower portion of the patent presses is called, while his mate ... hands him ... the fleeces. These are placed in tiers, and tramped down until the lower box is full. pretties
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1972
Source: Folkgames of Children
Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page: 174
Edition:
Quote: Marbles had a language of its own. There were names for the marbles, the games, and all the various aspects of the play. There were terms for marbles such as `taw' or `shooter', referring to the marbles used to fire with; `dubs', `dates', `stakes', `dukes', or `changers', referring to the marbles put down to be fired at. Then there were the terms referring to particular kinds of marbles: for example, agates, aggies, aggotties, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cat's eyes, chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, molly-bars, mulley-bars [mullibars: large marbles], peelies, peewees, piss-wees, pretties, Scotties, Scottish alleys, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers, white alleys, and in more recent years ball-bearings, chippies, plastics, and woodies.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1984
Source: NZ Yesterdays
Author: KEITH & MAIN
Vol / Page: 288
Edition:
Quote: Marbles were the currency of childhood and there were an astonishing number of names for them, some referring to the material or colour, others to value or function in the game. There were agates, aggies, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cats-eye, [sic] chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, mollies, peelies, peewees, pisswees, pretties, Scotties, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers and whities. The march of technology added ball bearings - ballies or steelies - which were unbeatable when it came to smashing an opponent's miserable glassie. World War II[roman] brought `clayeys' often imperfectly spherical they were pathetic terracotta substitutes for real marbles.
Notes:

preventive detention
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:an indeterminate sentence introduced by the Criminal Justice Act 1954 for offenders repeatedly convicted of certain crimes.
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Jim Cameron writes : This replaced the previous sentence of <i>reformative detention</i> (1910) and <i>declaration as habitual offender</I> and <i>habitual criminal</i> (1906). None of these terms is recorded in DNZE. Its scope has been protean. In its present form (Criminal Justice Act 1985 as amended) it is a sentence of indefinite detention with no fixed maximum that may be imposed on persons aged 21 or more convicted of certain sexual and other serious offences. A sentence under the same name existed in England from 1908 to 1967.

Citations
Date: 0/1/1999
Source: NZWords
Author:
Vol / Page: 2
Edition:
Quote: At  the  other end  of  the  scale  is  the indeterminate   sentence   of   preventive detention.  A sentence of the same name existed  in  Britain  from  1908 to  1967. Introduced in New Zealand in 1954 to replace the sentence of reformative detention (1910) and declaration as an habitual offender and habitual criminal (1906), it remains very much alive here.
Notes:

That is the word `naughty', for sexual intercourse.

pricker
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:get/have the pricker: to be upset, annoyed with, often in a sulky manner; in the general sense of temper, sulks (variously get one's pricker up, get the pricker (with), give somebody the pricker, to become, get, make, somebody, angry, annoyed, nettled)
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: OED says Aus & NZ.

Citations
Date: 0/0/1984
Source: South Pacific Street
Author: WILSON
Vol / Page: 69
Edition:
Quote: `You deserve everything you get.' `Now don't get the pricker, Len.' She smiled and patted my hand.
Notes:

Date: 27/8/1952
Source: Personal Communication
Author: J B CAMERON
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote: ca1945 (W.Cameron) and heard in Wellington 1952 Aug 27<I>get one's pricker up</I>, to get one's temper up<I> get the pricker,</I> get angry, nettled, or sulky; fed up (Suggests<I> pricker</I> = pricks = spines : ie get one's back up (as a cat etc), or <I>get hairy</I>)
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1988
Source: Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
Author: McGILL
Vol / Page: 88
Edition:
Quote: <i>pricker</i> , phr.<i> get the pricker with</i> to be angry with; ref. Gordon Slatter; eg `Watch out, mate. The Sarge has really got the pricker with you.' c. 1930. NZA.

prickly thorn
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:karo
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1851
Source: Spring in the Canterbury Settlement, A
Author: TORLESSE
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote: `There are two plants, the karo (prickly thorn) and taramea (spear grass). which are well worth of their names, but are almost exclusively confined, that is, the larger varieties, to the hilly regions. There gen erally grows near these a plant called tikuma (cotton- or leather-plant) from the leaf of which the natives make mats and leggings, which are impervious to the sharp points of the former ...' TCS, par. 51.
Notes: 1851 Torlesse Canterbury Settlement (Lyttelton Times) (And)

priest

Vol / Page: 2

Notes:

Date: 0/9/2000
Source: Wel-com (Wellington)
Author:
Vol / Page: No. 167 : 17
Edition:
Quote: Fr Delaney said: "I did not know till recently that trout fishers are accustomed to take a priest with them when they go for a catch. They take a wooden mallet or other weapon with them and use it for the last rites when the fish is in its final struggle. And the mallet is called a priest.Nor did I know, until a book of angling, 1880, told me, that an all-purpose fisherman's fly called a priest is likely to make a good catch."

Prime Minister
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:.
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: [? date] G.H. Scholefield (ed) NZ Parliamentary Record [?p] [Mr Seddon was first Premier to assume the title, which he did in 1899. It was officially used in the N.Z. Yr Bk of 1900+5 the Parliamentary debates of 1902, it was used in the constitutional debates in the 1st session of the 1st N.Z. Parliament in 1854, + it appeared in the schedule of the Civil List Act of 1873.] [check this] The operative date for the introduction of this term to official documents was August 1900, although from context in NZPD in which it was used (more than once) by Prime Minister Seddon (who was still addressed in Parliament as Premier during the debate), it appears to have been in some general use before that date.

Citations
Date: 21/6/1902
Source: Hawera & Normanby Star
Author:
Vol / Page: 2
Edition:
Quote: PRIME MINISTER GIVES AN AT HOME. An at home at Hatfield House was attended by five hundred.
Notes:

Date: 17/7/1913
Source: Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page: 8
Edition:
Quote: With respect to the allegations regarding sly grog, the Prime Minister said that the Government believed in the strict administration of the law ...
Notes:

Date: 7/6/1960
Source: NZ Truth
Author:
Vol / Page: 42
Edition:
Quote:  `INFORMATION,' of South Otago, disputes `Snippet's' statement (April 26) that Richard John Seddon was New Zealand's first Prime Minister on the grounds that the term `Prime Minister' was not used officially till New Zealand obtained Dominion status on September 26, 1907.  THE term `Prime Minister' was first used in New Zealand during a constitutional debate in New Zealand's first Parliament in 1854, and was subsequently used on many occasions during the late 19th century. In 1873, for example, in a schedule to the civil list, provision was made for the leader of the Government `being the Prime Minister.' The title `Prime Minister' was adopted officially in 1899 and Richard John Seddon was the first New Zealand Premier to use it. It was officially used in the New Zealand Year Book in 1900 and in Parliamentary debates in 1902.
Notes:

Source: Speeches & Documents
Author:
Vol / Page: 42

Date: 0/0/1980
Source: Land of Munros, The
Author: NEAVE
Vol / Page: 65
Edition:
Quote:  I was to get a liberal screw and found for four months [at Otematata Station], beginning the 8th of March [1858], with... two cotton shirts ... no underclothing, no socks, but pieces of blanket rolled round your feet (we called them Prince Alberts) ... I had to make myself a cap out of a piece of an old opossum rug.

Vol / Page: 71

Quote: The cocky's wife spotted my Prince Alberts, a piece of blanket cut into eighteen-inch squares which I wound over my feet. ... Prince Alberts were more serviceable than ordinary socks, were warmer, longer-wearing and would take up the slack in my boots, preventing blisters.

prison camp
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a low security prison
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:prison farm
Pronunciation:
Notes: Jim writes: a historical form of penal institution in NZ. The first prison camp was at Milford Sound in the 1890s; subsequently there were <i>tree-planting camps</I> in the North and South Island. See annual reports in AJHR series H-20. Prison camp may be an international term in this sense as well as in relation to war prisoners. NZOD defines it ambiguously as a camp for detaining prisoners of war <i>or of the State</i>.

They did not know its proper spelling or pronunciation. `Kingy-seeny' it was to them and they did not care whether that had a meaning or not. This rough and tumble game was the most popular of all.

Probationary Assistant
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a Teachers College graduate in the first (probationary) year of teaching.
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: short form is P.A.

Citations
Date: 0/0/1963
Source: In the Sticks
Author: BACON
Vol / Page: 182
Edition:
Quote: <i>Probationary Assistant</i>-New Zealand student teachers normally do two years' training in one of the country's Teachers' Colleges. During this time, they work about five separate monthly practice periods in selected schools. Their third year of training is as Probationary Assistant in a larger school. If this probationary year's service is satisfactory, trainees receive their Teacher's Certificate, and are then eligible to apply for a teaching position anywhere in New Zealand or in New Zealand's Island Territories.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1963
Source: Coal Flat
Author: PEARSON
Vol / Page: 8
Edition:
Quote: <i>Probationary Assistant</i>. J.W. Perry. The term said to have become official in the `Regulations for Public Schools: Salaries, Grading, Staffing, etc. ' as amended by Regulation 6 of the Amended Regulations under the Education Act 1914 made on the 22/3/1926 (Previously known as <i>Student Assistant</i>)
Notes:

producer board
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number: 1
Definition:a specific developmental and/or marketing body of primary products such as wool, meat, dairy products and fruit.
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:Rural
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 20/7/1995
Source: NZ Farmer
Author:
Vol / Page: 8
Edition:
Quote: .. we must abandon any remaining statutory powers the producer boards possess and maybe the producer boards themselves.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1996
Source: Historical Dictionary of NZ
Author: JACKSON & MCROBIE
Vol / Page: 57
Edition:
Quote: The first primary producer boards were set up in the wake of the collapse of the commandeer system (q.v.) following the end of World War I. In the years that followed [the establishment of the meat and Dairy Boards] producer boards were set up to oversee the production and export of fruit, honey, poultry and hops. After the [second world]war producer boards were re-established and extended to include wool, eggs, kauri gum, maize, barley, potatoes, bobby calves, pork, apples, berry and citrus fruits, tobacco, and as recently as 1988, kiwifruit (q.v.).
Notes:

Date: 0/0/2001
Source: Wool Grower
Author:
Vol / Page: Winter 4
Edition:
Quote: Looking forward, Wiggins agrees that the days of the producer boards are numbered.

Pronunciation:
Notes: see ODE to pronk (Afrikaans)

Source: Dominion
Author:
Vol / Page: 12
Edition:
Quote: He was puzzled when a workmate called him a pronker. At first he thought he had been identified as a plonker, but found the word pronker was chosen deliberately. The South African verb pronk means to show off, as a springbok might do when it makes a spectacular leap, perhaps to score a try to win the World Cup.

prophet
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a nickname for the Australian supporters of a pastoralist or sheepfarming regime in early Canterbury settlement as against those (mainly newly-arrived English 'Pilgrim' settlers who looked rather towards agricultural small-farming

Register 2:
Domain:[none]

Pronunciation:
Notes:

prophet
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:

Origin:[none]

Domain:Rural

Citations
Date: 9/8/1951
Source: Lyttelton Times
Author:
Vol / Page: 7

Quote: Gaily the pilgrim harnessed his plough, / When he had built up a roof o'er his head; / Singing, `From Albion hither I come;' / `Land of mine! land of mine! grow me some bread.' Proudly the prophet flourished his crook, / When he had landed his sheep from the west; / Singing, `From Philipland hither I come;' / `Silly men! silly men! wool pays the best.'

Date: 0/0/1859
Source: Story of New Zealand, The
Author: THOMSON
Vol / Page:  2/186-187
Edition:
Quote: ...An old Australian squatter, who visited the Canterbury settlement in 1851, divided the inhabitants into pilgrims, shagruns, and prophets; the first were the original colonists, the second were people from other parts of New Zealand, and the last were settlers from Australia.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1866
Source: Canterbury Rhymes
Author:
Vol / Page: 5
Edition:
Quote: `Pilgrims and Prophets'. [title of Poem] <i><Ibid.</i> 9. The pilgrim toiled for his crop. ... Shortly the pilgrim and prophet agreed The plough and the crook couldn't live far apart. [NOTE 1866] <i>Ibid.</I> 101 [Notes] During the first year of the Settlement, Canterbury was invaded by a body of Sheep-farmers from Port Philip (Victoria), who were regarded by the Settlers partly with admiration as successful colonists, and partly with horror as disbelievers in the art of colonization and the `Canterbury System'. ... One of the visitors, who seem to have delighted in the <i>soubriquet</i> of `Shagroon', ventured to prophesy, in a letter which found its way into print, that the `Canterbury Pilgrims' would soon be ruined ... The `pilgrims' sought no harsher revenge than to nick-name their Port Philip visitors `prophets', and to take example from their experience in pastoral pursuits. <i>Ibid.</i> 125. During the first year of the Settlement, Canterbury was invaded by a body of sheep-farmers from Port Philip (Victoria) who were regarded by the settlers partly with admiration as successful Colonists, and partly with horror as disbelievers in the art of colonisation and the `Canterbury System'. The visitors found the country admirably adapted for sheep-farming, and they treated with some contempt the raw emigrants from England who looked to agriculture as the foundation of their fortunes. One of the visitors, who seem to have delighted in the soubriquet of `Shagroon', ventured to prophesy, in a letter, which found its way into print, that the `Canterbury Pilgrims' would soon be ruined and their country left for occupation by his more enlightened comrades. The `pilgrims' sought no harsher revenge than to nickname their Port Philip visitors `prophets' and to take example from their experience in pastoral pursuits. The Canterbury pasturage system was quickly adapted to the requirements of sheepfarming on a large scale, and `pilgrims' and `prophets' were soon merged into one class of Canterbury runholders.
Notes:

Date: 18/11/1933
Source: Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote: <i>Prophet</i>.- Nickname of the Australian squatters who came down to Canterbury in 185(1) They were caled Ps. because they prophesied ruin for the farming pilgrims. It was they who finally persuaded Godley to authorise the squatting system here. See also <i>Shagroon</i>. (C.R., p. 5)
Notes: Acland Gloss

Date: 0/0/1966
Source: Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An
Author:
Vol / Page: 3/231
Edition:
Quote: Not only did Australian sheep arrive, but during the 1850-60 period many Australian squatters (disgruntled by the fickle rainfall) also sold or abandoned their properties and migrated to New Zealand. These men arrived with capital to invest, with experience in colonial farming, knowledgeable of the peculiar habits of the Merino sheep, and with whole-hearted support of a `squatting' policy of land tenure based on the occupation of large areas of grazing country at low rentals. They became known as the `Prophets' because they forecast failure for the small-area arable farm plans of the established settlements.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1851
Source: BLANK ENTRY
Author:
Vol / Page: 5
Edition:

Vol / Page: 2029

Quote: <i>Pros&#769;.pect </i>(pr&obreve.s&#769;.p&ebreve.kt), <i>n. [Add.] 7</i>. [Perh. directly from PROSPECT, <i>v. i.] (Mining) (a) </i>The gold or other mineral obtained by washing a sample of wash-dirt in a dish. <i>(b) </i>The gold or other mineral obtained by crushing and washing a sample of ore.

Date: 0/0/1898
Source: Austral English
Author: MORRIS
Vol / Page: 370
Edition:
Quote: <i>Prospect, v.</i> to search for gold. In the word, and in all its derivatives, the accent is thrown back on to the first syllable. This word, in such frequent use in Australia, is generally supposed to be of Australian origin, but it is in equal use in the mining districts of the United States of America. [1861]

prospect
Homonym Number:
Word Class:verb
Sense Number:
Definition:(merely a further example of 2?)to look for wapiti in an area where they have not previously been reported or shot for.
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: 1965 Bruce Branwell <I<TS</I>. of <I>Wapiti Hunters</I> (Note by Les Cleveland) 69 A party prospected for wapiti in the area between the Wapiti river and the Doon Valley. <I>Ibid.</I> 71. Five blocks and two prospecting blocks were offered in 1933. [Adj. usage is more common in the phrase <i>prospect blocks</i>, hence] 71 Three new coast blocks were opened to enable better coverage of the peninsulas between the alternate sounds. These were known as prospect blocks. The first parties to stalk these areas were, in most cases, entering country no stalkers had previously covered.

Quote: <i>Pr&obreve.s&#769;.p&ebreve.kt-&ibreve.ng)</i>, a. & n. <i>from PROSPECT,</i> v. i. <i>Prospecting claim (Mining)</i>, a specially large claim, allotted by the warden of the gold fields to the first miner discovering gold in a new district; - called also <i>reward claim</i>.

Author:
Vol / Page: 2
Edition:
Quote: Gold from Karori. .. The stone, taken from all parts of a 14ft reef, has been roughly broken up with a hammer so as to liberate the precious metal, and the particles resulting from this operation carried by means of water across a ripple-table, the stuff collected in the ripples being then panned off in an ordinary digger's prospecting dish.

protection order
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a court order aimed at protecting persons who are or have been in a domestic relationship, and their children, from violence, abuse or harassment by or on behalf of their partners.
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Jim Cameron writes : Introduced by the Domestic Violence Act 1995, it replaces the <i>non-molestation order</i> under the Domestic Protection Act 1982.

Protector of (the) Aborigines
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a statutory official charged under the ... Act (184 ) with protecting Maori (esp. land) interests.
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: [See quote Landjobber.] ... the acquisition of large tracts of Country by mere Landjobbers, it will be your duty to obtain, by fair and equal contracts with the Natives, the Cession to the Crown of such Waste Lands as may be progressively required for occupation of Settlers resorting to New Zealand. All such contracts should be made by yourself, through the intervention of an Officer expressly appointed to watch over the interests of the Aborigines as their Protector.]

Citations
Date: 18/12/1847
Source: Daily Southern Cross
Author:
Vol / Page: 4
Edition:
Quote: On the division of New Zealand into provinces. 1. For the present, and until further order be made in that behalf, the islands of New Zealand shall be divided into two provinces, to be known respectively by the designations of the "Province of New Ulster", and the "Province of New Munster". 2. The Province of New Ulster shall comprise the whole of the island hitherto called the Island of New Ulster, with the exception of those parts of the said island adjacent to Cook's Straits, which the Governor-in-Chief of New Zealand may, by any such proclamation as aforesaid, except and exclude from the province of New Ulster.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1958
Source: Crown Colony Government in New Zealand
Author: McLINTOCK
Vol / Page: 214
Edition:
Quote:  ... Earl Grey decided in mid-1846 to confer on the colony a most complex constitution which, inter alia, provided for the creation of two provinces, New Ulster and New Munster, whose boundary line was to run due east across the North Island from the mouth of the Patea River'. [Then you'll have the later constitution, the abolition of the provinces and its extension in meaning today in sporting circles to include Bush, Waikato, King Country etc. which were never provinces. J. Winchester 1963]

Vol / Page: 130
Edition:
Quote: It is not now remarked for the first time that the islands of New Zealand will not be settled from one centre; that the character of the country will enforce a different mode; and that most of its towns will be each the nucleus of a district especially its own, and bound to it by ties which will substitute for a long time, and perhaps for ever, the feeling of provincialism for that of nationalism, or rather patriotism in its limited sense.
Notes:

Date: 22/7/1854
Source: Richmond-Atkinson Papers
Author:
Vol / Page: 1/150
Edition: 1960
Quote:  I see you are a very prominent figure in the G.A. I expect to see the intense provincialism of you Aucklanders a good deal softened down.
Notes: (C.W.Richmond) [to T.S.Forsaith, Auckland]

Date: 7/4/1858
Source: Richmond-Atkinson Papers
Author:
Vol / Page: 1/379
Edition: 1960
Quote: As regards Centralism and provincialism, do not let us run into extremes either way. Provincialism up to a certain point is indispensable for the progress of the Colony. ... Pruned and reduced to right dimensions our provincial governments may be made admirable institutions.
Notes: (H. Sewell)

provincialism

Sense Number:
Definition:the political system of control by Provinces as distinct from central Government (1856-1878?)

Date: 11/9/1858
Source: Lyttelton Times
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote: After all, the names `Centralist' and `Provincialist' do not in most cases give a truer impression than party nick-names generally convey. `Centralism', properly so called, is repugnant to all the political instincts of Englishmen. `Provincialism' is as repugnant their educated sympathisers who are called or erroneously call themselves Centralists are truer friends of local self-government than many of the defenders of `Provincialism', while some who find themselves classed under the name of Provincialists have the most profound contempt for the assumption and local tyranny that have distinguished one or two of our little centralisms.
Notes: 1858 <i>Lyttelton Times</i> 11 Sept (Editorial) in 1971 Speeches and Documents 105

Date: 0/0/1859
Source: Story of New Zealand, The
Author: THOMSON
Vol / Page: /223
Edition:
Quote:  Two parties were now [mid 1850s] developed in the colony; one was called Centralists, the other Provincialists. The former aimed at the incorporation of the provincial governments, with a view to their ultimate absorption, and maintained the right of the General Assembly to intermeddle in all provincial affairs. The latter, on the other hand, insisted that the Imperial Parliament had established two independent governments in New Zealand, each for its own sphere, the provinces having exclusive jurisdiction in all provincial matters, and only under the control of the General Assembly on matters of general concern.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1865
Source: England's NZ War
Author: HURSTHOUSE
Vol / Page: 49
Edition:
Quote:
Notes: [F.N.] [see CENTRALIST

Quote: When the Ngati Awa arrived in the late 1820s, the people of Karaka knew nothing of guns, and when some fugitives from the various settlements in Kura Te Au (Tory Channel), brought tidings that a taua from the North Island were killing people with 'Pu'(which meant a strong wind or explosive breath), they scoffed, "Let them come!" "We have plenty 'pu'"...  The deadly effect of the 'pu' caused great consternation in the Pa.

Notes:

Date: 0/6/1992
Source: North & South
Author:
Vol / Page: 18
Edition:
Quote: &#65279;It has neither roots nor green leaves, and is found only in New Zealand. Maori named it Pua o te reinga, Europeans call it the Flower of Hades, or Wood Rose, and to the botanist it is Dactylanthus taylorii.
Notes:

Date: 22/1/2011
Source: Dominion Post
Author:
Vol / Page: A13
Edition:
Quote: Its Maori name, pua o te reinga, means flower of the underworld - and refers to the way the flowers emerge from underground.
Notes:

Date: 9/4/1997
Source: Waikato Times
Author:
Vol / Page: 21
Edition:
Quote: Dactylanthus taylorii has a special place n New Zealand's native flora as the country's only fully parasitic flowering plant. Also known as pua o te reinga, wae-wae-atua, the wood rose or flower of Hades, it is hard for the untrained eye to spot as it nestles among tree roots.
Notes:

Truly, this pubbery was just short of shanty, typical of the `Outer Barcoo', but where Maories, their Wahines, or broken down `Remittancers' could drown their sorrows, wander into the `arms of Bacchus' or chase pink elephants.
