Citations
Date: 0/0/1956
Source: NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author: GRAHAM
Vol / Page: 378
Edition:
Quote: GLOBE-FISH <i>Contusus richei</i> (Freminville) ... It has several other popular names such as Balloon-fish and Mouse-fish. In America it is known as Rabbit-fish and Stink-fish. The most humorous name is that of Publican-fish. ... The most witty name, Publican-fish given to it by Australian fishermen, is said to have originated from the resemblance of an inflated Globe-fish to the rotundity of many successful publicans.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1981
Source: Fisherman's Bible
Author: WILSON
Vol / Page: 176

Date: 0/0/1969
Source: Awatea
Author: MASON
Vol / Page: 43
Edition:
Quote:  WHA. Haangi puckerooed by now, I bet. Kumaras like bullets, pigs all burnt up. [note 99] <i>puckerooed</i>: English version of Maori <i>pakaru</i>, meaning shattered, or broken or rendered useless. The word is used several times in the play, both in its Maori and Pakeha form; it is much stronger in Maori.
Notes:

Sense Number:

Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: [AND 1852] OED 6. Gold-mining: to work [washdirt] with water in a tub so as to separate the ore (1859 Austr. 1864 US.)

Edition:

Notes: c1875? Thatcher The Leary Boy

There are also two brothers, puddlers, of the same place, who have lately received the intelligence from America of a third brother having made provision for the annuity of £250 per annum for each of them for life.

Date: 0/0/1981
Source: NZ Medicinal Plants
Author: BROOKER et al.
Vol / Page: 23
Edition:
Quote: <i>Calvatia caelata</i> (Bull.) Morg. Common name: <i>Puffball </I> Maori name: <i>Pukurau.</i> In Hooker's `Handbook ...', the name `pukurau' or `pukuvau' is <i>applied to</i> Lycoperdon fontanesei ... <i>which is now </i>known as<i> Calvatia caelata</i>. In Williams ... the name `pukurau' is identified as <i>Clathrus cibarium</i> ... a net-like fungus ... [C. caelata is found in Europe ...as well as NZ.]

Date: 0/0/1907
Source: NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin
Author:
Vol / Page: No. 4 (N.S.)/102
Edition:
Quote: An undetermined kaolinic product - the `pug' of the miners - is fairly abundant in the reefs. <i>Ibid.</i> 113 (Coromandel) The actual vein-walls are frequently smooth and slickensided, being separated from the wass-rock by a narrow selvage of plaster finely comminated rock (locally termed `pug') <i>Ibid </i>114 They are in almost all cases fissures filled, as the result of rock-movement and decomposition processes, with clayey material (`pug')
Notes: (Fraser and Adams)

Vol / Page: No. 15 (N.S.)/127
Edition:

pug ring
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1943
Source: Pure Gold
Author: HISLOP
Vol / Page: 116
Edition:
Quote: Some of the lads made their [sun-dried] bricks in what they called a pug ring, formed by driving the horses round in a circle as with the old-time chaffcutter, but Cecil made his on what they called a straight. A strip of ground about 30 yards long by four or five wide was scooped free of top soil, which was dumped on the garden nearby. It was then ploughed about ten inches deep, or according to the number of bricks required, and very well watered, which was usually done with a shovel from a tank on a sledge for even distribution, and left to soak all night. A good layer of chopped-up tussocks was then evenly spread over the top. After more watering a six-horse team was driven up and down the strip until the pug was well mixed.
Notes: [c1910, Otago]

pug up
Homonym Number:
Word Class:verb
Sense Number: 1
Definition:[used elsewhere but sign. in NZ with stock kept out of doors year-round] 1. [land & soils] to become heavy and sticky. 2. [animals] to cause hoof damage to pasture.

Register:
Register 2:
Domain:Rural
Region:[none]

This is the sow thistle, better known as `rauriki' in the Wellington district, which, marketed as `puha,' finds a ready sale at 1/- a bundle. There are two varieties, puha tiotio or prickly-leaved, and puha pororua, or smooth - leaved. [So Williams Dict 318]

Date: 0/0/1926
Source: Weeds of New Zealand
Author: HILGENDORF
Vol / Page: 210
Edition: 1926
Quote: PRICKLY SOUR THISTLE [SOWTHISTLE] (<i>Sonchus asper</i>) is also called rough sour thistle [sowthistle,] and also by its Maori name of Puwha. This is very similar to the former [S.oleraceus, sowthistle] in all respects, except that the margins of the leaves are much more prickly, ... This form seems scarcely as common as the former, though it was found in New Zealand when Cook arrived here.

Date: 6/11/1998
Source: Dominion
Author:
Vol / Page: 16
Edition:
Quote: [Caption] Sonchus oleraceus, pororua or common puha; S. kirkii, raurorua or NZ native puha. Ibid. The original Maori puha was rauroroa or S. kirkii - a ntive which has a whitish bloom on the leaf surfaces and is usually found near the coast... Puha leaves were put on cuts and wounds to prevent infection, and waipuha, or water in which puha had been boiled, was drunk to cure stomach complains and loss of appetite.

Vol / Page: 17/216
Edition:
Quote: The traveller who visits Stewart Island in December or January will have his attention arrested by the blaze of crimson presented by the rata (<i>Metrosideros lucida</i>), often flecked with the pale racemes of the kamahi (<i>Weinmannia racemosa</i>), the deep green leaves of the puheretaiko and the tupari (<i>Senecio rotundifolius</i> and <i>Olearia colensoi</i>), and the grass-like leaves of the inaka (<i>Drachophyllum longifolium</i>), all of which form a fringe of greater or less breadth at the water's edge, and (except the puheretaiko) often expand into large masses ascending to the crests of the hills.

puia

Sense Number:
Definition:a geyser; a boiling spring
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 3/8/1859
Source: Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle
Author:
Vol / Page: 1
Edition:
Quote: [From the Auckland Provincial <i>Gazette</i>.]  .. The principal "puia" at Tokanu is called Pirori, an intermittent fountain, whose column of boiling water, of two feet in diameter, sometimes reaches a height of more than 40 feet.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1878
Source: Forty Years in NZ
Author: BULLER
Vol / Page: 11
Edition:
Quote: Hochstetter divides the steam jets into three kinds: 1. <I>Puias</I>, which are geysers, continuously or intermittently active. 2. <I>Ngawas</I>, which are inactive <I>Puias</I> - emitting steam, but not throwing up columns of water. 3. <I>Waiarikis</I>, which mean any sort of cistern of hot water suitable for bathing.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1870
Source: TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page: 2/171
Edition:
Quote: The word Puia is especially used in the Taupo country, to designate the intermittent, geyser-like fountains of Tokanu ... and of Whakarewarewa on Lake Rotorua. Puia has ... the more general meaning of crater or volcano, and is applied to active as well as extinct volcanoes. ... Ngawhas [is] a term specially used for non-intermittent springs, for the solfataras and sulphurous hot-springs on the Rotomahana, Rotorua, and Rotoiti. Finally, the springs suited to bathing purposes, the water of which never reaches the boiling point, and all naturally warm baths are called `Waiariki,' corresponding to the Laugar of Iceland.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1903
Source: TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page: 35/172
Edition:
Quote: In her passage underground she set fire to the world below, hence the hot springs, puias, fumaroles ... in the line of route.
Notes:

puka

Domain:[none]

Date: 25/6/2005
Source: Dominion Post
Author:
Vol / Page: E13
Edition:
Quote: The English common name -- shining broadleaf -- derives from the puka's bright green leaves, which are thick with a glossy sheen. ... Puka often starts life with other epiphytes, such as colospermum or astelia, high up in the crown of a mature rimu, Pukatea or rata.

Quote: <i>Pu&#769;.ka</i> (pu&#769;.k&adot.), <i>n</i>. [Maori.]<i> 1. (Bot.)</i> A New Zealand tree <i>(Meryta Sinclairii)</i>, of the order <i>Araliaceae</i>; - called also <i>broadleaf. [Local, North Island of N. Z.] 2. (Bot.)</i> Either of two species of New Zealand trees <i>Griselina lucida</i> and <i>G. littoralis</i>) of the order <i>Corneae. G. littoralis</i> is usually called <i>broadleaf</i> by the settlers.<i> [Local, N. Z.] </i>

See:

Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/2/1777
Source: Journal
Author: LEDYARD
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  ... they add what they call the Bugabuga or the Toga, and sometimes both. The Bugabuga is a very coarse covering made with little trouble, and affords a good shelter from cold or wet weather : The Toga is different and is equally calculated for use and elegance : The Bugabuga is formed round and converging to the top where there is an apperture just sufficient to admit the head to pass through, and when on, covers the body as low as the hip : If it storms, or they have occasion to stop where they have no other shelter they squat down upon their hams, and then the bottom of the Bugabuga reaching the ground, forms a shelter to the whole body (the head excepted) which looks in that situation as if it had been severed from a human form, and fixed upon a hay-cock.
Notes: 1777 Feb in 1783 Ledyard Journal (1963) 14

Notes:

Date: 0/0/1899
Source: TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page: 31/479
Edition:
Quote: ... the floor of the kauri bush is covered with a thick coating of vegetable humus (<i>pukahu</i>), which is rendered highly inflammable by a mixture of dead leaves, particles of gum, and scales dropped from the resinous bark. <i>Ibid.</I> 493 Wherever the kauri-trees grow ... the ground is covered with a thick [493] layer of humus (<i>pukahau</i>),  composed of vegetable fibre intemingled with fallen leaves, particles of gum, and scales from the resinous bark, the latter helping to form a solid bank, sometimes several feet in height, round the base of the trees.
Notes: Walsh

Date: 0/0/1951
Source: Grasslands of NZ
Author: LEVY
Vol / Page: 14
Edition: 1970
Quote: Really hot, white-ash burns of the felled forest were rarely secured, [15] which meant that large numbers of the felled trees did not burn, much raw pukahu was left merely blackened, ... <i>Ibid.</I> 94 In high humidity forests, ... pukahu - undecomposed dead forest litter - may accumulate on the forest floor, feet in depth.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1953
Source: Story of the Kauri, The
Author: REED
Vol / Page: 84
Edition:
Quote: In early days the volume of the timber would not have warranted the time and expense involved clearing away the accumulated debris, known as pukahu (Maori: masses of rootlets), and usually referred to by the bushmen as `bookau'. <i>Ibid.</I> 208 The platform enabled a man to go from side to side, in order to pour <i>pukahu </i>down the face of the dam as a preventive of leaks in the planking. This pukahu (bookau to the bushman) was the matted, fibrous material which gathered at the foot of large Kauris.
Notes:

Author: MOORE & IRWIN
Vol / Page: 94
Edition:
Quote: <i>MERYTA SINCLAIRII, puka, pukanui. Meryta </i>is a genus of the south Pacific. Its southernmost occurrence is in New Zealand, where its natural distribution is limited to two groups of islands, the Hen and Chickens, and the Three Kings. ... [<i>M.sinclairii</i>] is widely cultivated as an ornamental tree ...in warmer parts of the country.

Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1978
Source: Oxford Book of NZ Plants
Author: MOORE & IRWIN
Vol / Page: 60
Edition:
Quote: <i>PISONIA BRUNONIANA.</i> Parapara is a small tree of quick, rather soft growth carrying leaves up to 40cm long, of dark glossy green ... Nodular ridges down the length of the `fruit' ... secrete a glutinous substance ... Most spectacular is the ability of this tarry substance to hold small birds. ... anyone who has seen a waxeye struggling to free itself from amongst a cluster of these fruits can easily understand why parapara has earned the name `bird-catching tree'. ... Where it grows with pukanui (<i>Meryta sinclairii</i>) two of our largest-leaved trees come together.
Notes:

Quote: There are [sic] a number of native trees in blossom at the same time as pukapuka, including puriri, tea-tree, 'bush-lawyer' clematis, cabbage-tree, mingi and ohoho. Of these, 'bush lawyer,' cabbage-tree and ohoho bloom only at the same time as pukapuka and all three yield more nectar than pukapuka does. [pungapunga]

Date: 0/0/1868
Source: Past and Present of NZ
Author: TAYLOR
Vol / Page: 16 (fn)
Edition:
Quote: <I>Pukapuka</I> - the word applied either to paper or books - at first sight appears to be derived from our English word <I>book</I>; it is not so, but from the large white leaf of the Pukapuka Rangiora (Brachyglottis repanda), to which the natives likened paper when they first saw it. They said, `He rau pukapuka tenei!' `Oh! this is a leaf of the Pukapuka.' The Greeks derived their [<I>biblos</I>] book, and the Latins their <I>Liber,</I> book, in a similar way, from the inner bark of the Linden or Teil tree, and the Egyptians theirs from the leaf of the Papyrus, whence comes our word paper.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1844
Source: Notes of a Journey
Author: MONRO
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote: The pukatuola is another wonderful animal of the southward [sc. Otago], told of by the old men. Under a different name he is heard of in the north. A gigantic animal of the lizard species, most dangerous to humanity. A very shrewd man, whom we met to the southward, was of opinion that these hairy men and crocodiles had their origin in the Maories seeing pictures of animals in books belonging to Europeans, and then persuading themselves that they existed in their woods: but I cannot take this view of the case.
Notes: 1844 Monro Notes of a Journey (Nelson Examiner July 20 et seq.) in 1898 Hocken Contributions 263

Date: 0/0/1938
Source: Promenade
Author: LANCASTER
Vol / Page: 44

Quote: At this stage of its existence [early pioneer days] New Zealand seemed specially made for lovers; ... with blue waters and mangroves along the rivers ..., and stalking, red-legged pukeka-birds would never tell.
Notes:

pukeko
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a brightly coloured native swamp-hen; the pukeko is called TANGATA TAWHITO `old, ancient, original, primeval' (Williams 409), but it may have introduced itself from Australia melanotus, swamphen; also pook, red-bill, sultana bird, (swamp-)turkey; pukaki is a common mainly South Island mainly pl form; a Maori variant (of Ngati-Pukeko tribe) =pakura Besides having possibly the greatest number of descriptive names of any NZ bird, it has many chiefly oral, anglicised, variants of the original Maori <I>pu[u]keko</i>, based on these alternations: /p/ as [p] or [b] /u:/ as [u:], [ju:], [u], [ju], [?], [j?]; and after [b], [ou], [o] /e/ as [E], [ae] /o/ as [ou], [?], [i]
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:

pukeko
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: c1890 and spg. bowcacker used c1890 in Turakina-Bulls district by D.M. Mason. Used in Pohangine district by N.T. Moar's father (see bowie) (R. Mason) ca1935 Havelock, Marlborough [pju:kaek?] [pu.'kaek?] etc [bokaek] [`boukaek?] etc [kaek?] (children) [boui:]] spg <i>bo-kakka </i> bowcacker: (R.M.) `Used ca1890 Turakina-Bulls district (B.M. Mason), and in Pohangina district.'

Date: 0/0/1957
Source: Mr Explorer Douglas
Author: PASCOE
Vol / Page: 234
Edition:
Quote: [Birds S.W.] Besides being a jack of all trades, this bird has a variety of names, no two people being agreed as to which is correct. The Maories call it the bu-ka-ka - is this spelling correct? Some people call it the coote, from some fanciful resemblance to the water hen of the Old Country. Swamp hen it is generally called in Westland, but I have heard it also called bald pate and New Zealand Turkey.
Notes: c1899 (1957) Pascoe Mr Explorer Douglas 234

TAIHOA - - The Police have the matter in hand POAKA - -a pig PUKEKO A bokakker out of season KORERO A long talk UTU - - The spike HAPU - - A Tribe KUMERA - - A sweet Spud

pukeko disease
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number: 1
Definition:a salmonella disease causing brown scours in sheep and thought to be carried by pukeko or swamp-hens.
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:Rural
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:

Quote: pukeko disease: salmonella disease in sheep carried by pukeko.

puku
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:the stomach, especially when large and distended.
Origin:Maori
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: ca1935 (Havelock) frequent:a full puku; how's your little pukie ?

Quote: [Maoris' nicknames for the pakehas in Power's party] A stalwart officer of the grenadiers, for instance, is generally known as Puku-nui, or Big-belly; an artillery officer is Biggy-bung; one wearing spectacles is Four-eyes, or No-eyes.

Definition:Charadrius obscurus, New Zealand dotterel

Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:also tuturiwhatu

Vol / Page: 13
Edition:
Quote: Mr. E. Tregear, in his <i> Maori Polynesian Dictionary</i>, and the Rev. H. W. Williams in the <i>Polynesian Journal</i>, give "Pukunui" as the Maori name of the dotterel.
Notes:

Date: 1/8/1908
Source: Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page: 13
Edition:
Quote: Has anybody ever seen the bird Pukunui (<i>"Big Stomach"</i>)? It was once supposed to exist in the North Island, but no European has reported it to science, and its existence has now become very problematical and perhaps mythical.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1835
Source: New Zealand (various authors/titles)
Author: YATE
Vol / Page: 68
Edition:
Quote: <i>Pukunui</i> - A bird so called from the largeness and rotundity of its breast, about the size of the crow, and remarkable for the deep red with which the feathers are tinged upon the back and under the wings. (Williams 309 2.n) <i>Pluvialis obscurus</i>, dotterel : see TURIWHATI
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1843
Source: Travels in NZ
Author: DIEFFENBACH
Vol / Page: 2/195
Edition:
Quote: 48. <i>Charadrius obscurus. Gmel</i>. ... Ha-poko-wera of the natives of Dusky Bay. <i>Forst</i> Tuturiwatu of the natives. <i>Yate. </I> To this order may also be referred two other birds spoken of by Mr. Yate under the names of Pukunui, Pututo.
Notes: 1842 Gray's Fauna in 1843 Dieffenbach Travels in NZ 2/195

Date: 0/0/1869
Source: TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page: 1/iii/32
Edition:
Quote: [Also eaten were] several <i>Fungi</i> [especially] ... four ... which grow on trees, - the Harori <i>(Agaricus adiposus)</i>, the Hakeke, and the Popoiahakeke (<i>Polyporus</i> species, and the Pekepekekiore (<i>Hydnum clathroides</i>); also, three terrestrial ones, - the Paruwhatitiri (<i>Ileodictyon cibarium), the Pukurau</i> (Lycoperdon Fontainesii), ... <i>Ibid.</i> 57 ... for severe burns ... [Maoris] applied ... the fine reddish dust of the large decaying fungus pukirau (<i>Lycoperdon fontainesii</i>).
Notes: (Colenso Botany North Isd); in 1981 Brooker et al. NZ Medicinal Plants 15

Date: 0/0/1981
Source: NZ Medicinal Plants
Author: BROOKER et al.
Vol / Page: 23
Edition:
Quote: <i>Calvatia caelata</i> (Bull.) Morg. Common name: <i>Puffball </i>Maori name: <i>Pukurau</i>. In Hooker's `Handbook ...', the name `pukurau' or `pukuvau' is applied to <i>Lycoperdon fontanesei </i>... which is now known as <i>Calvatia caelata</i>. In Williams ... the name `pukurau' is identified as <i>Clathrus cibarium</i> ... a net-like fungus ... [C. caelata is found in Europe ...as well as NZ.]
Notes:

Domain:[none]
Region:[none]

Citations
Date: 0/0/1981
Source: NZ Police National Headquarters
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote: pull your head in: a saying applied to any person or persons to stop doing anything; e.g., `Settle down son and pull your head in.'
Notes: (Goldie Brown Collection)

Date: 0/0/1988
Source: Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
Author: McGILL
Vol / Page: 55
Edition:
Quote: head, phr. need your head read you are insane or stupid; eg `That's the third time this week you've put on odd socks. You need your head read, you do. Mostly NZA. <i>Ibid.</i> 88 pull your headin advice to mind one's own business; eg `I'd prefer to handle this my way. Why don't you just pull your head in?' Partridge traces to army men sticking heads out of troop trains and being advised to pull them in lest they be mistaken for cattle; c. 1930. ANZ. ]
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1877
Source: Tikera
Author: WISNIOWSKI
Vol / Page: 150
Edition: (trans. Podstolski 1972)
Quote: `I didn't like him at all. A real pumpkin head.' This is the name Australian colonists of English extraction give to German settlers, on account of their round features. Now that even the natives have learned to despise the miserly Teuton land grabbers, the name pumpkin head is often used by people who speak only pidgin English. [1972 ed. note] `Pumpkin head in English in the original. ... may be a confusion between two Americanisms, `pumpkin head' meaning a stupid person and `square head' or a similar term for a German.

puna-weta
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:putaputaweta
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1907
Source: Plants of NZ
Author: LAING & BLACKWELL
Vol / Page: 188
Edition: 1940 p. 194
Quote: <I>Carpodetus serratus (The Serrate Carpodetus).</I>.. The native name <I>Puta-puta-weta</I> signifies full of weta holes. In the North Island trees of this species are rarely cut down unperforated by longitudinal insect galleries. Another name by which it is known is <I>Puna-weta</I>. In the Urewera country it is called <I>Kai-weta</I> (i.e., weta food). [That ugly innocent the weta (<I>Deinacrida</I>) has thus been accused of perforating the tree; but as a matter of fact though often used as convenient residences [195] by the weta, the holes are made by the caterpillar of the large moth <I>Hepialus virescens</I> ...]
Notes:

Vol / Page: 170
Edition:
Quote: A <i>bullock puncher </i>is a man engaged to drive bullocks to market or port. The expression is painfully true, as these men, who receive but very poor wages, are recruited from the worst class, ill-treat the poor animals by <i>punching</i> their sides with pointed stick.

Punch King
Homonym Number:

Sense Number:
Definition:a children's game
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1981
Source: History of Children's Play
Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page: 57
Edition:
Quote: Punch King was similar to Bar the Door, but more violent. The game was called Punch King Sinio. ... Five were left uncrowned. ... The five had their backs to the wall, and woe betide any luckless mite who dared to come within reach of their punches, so indiscriminantly were they delivered. Any punch was legal, rabbit or otherwise. ... (1876; Wellington)

Date: 0/0/1982
Source: Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery
Author: BURTON
Vol / Page: 5
Edition:
Quote: The inner parts and roots of the raupo (<i>Typha orientalis</i>) provided a meagre amount of food, but the seed heads were prized for their bright yellow pollen which was made into loaves known as<i> pungapunga. </i>
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1881
Source: TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page: XIII/28
Edition:
Quote: Another highly curious article of vegetable food was the <i>pungapunga</i>, the yellow pollen of the <i>raupo</i> flowers- the common bulrush, or cat's reed mace (<i>Typha augustifolia</i>... To use it as food it is mixed up with water into cakes and baked. It is sweetish and light, and reminds one strongly of London gingerbread.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1972

Vol / Page: 156
Edition:
Quote: `Punk' [a fungus] taken from the trees was at hand everywhere in the bush, and was used for a [home-made cricket] ball. Large pieces of punk two or three pounds in weight would cut out three balls. ... [Carterton, Wairarapa, 1880]
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1978
Source: Maori Food and Cookery
Author: FULLER
Vol / Page: 15
Edition:
Quote: ... a dried bracket fungus - <i>Polyporus hasularis</i>, called punk by the European settlers and bushmen, was collected and prized for its slow-burning properties.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1966
Source: Maori Life and Custom
Author: PHILLIPPS
Vol / Page: 61
Edition:
Quote: Little has been recorded of the bracket fungus <i>[Polyporus] </i>and its importance in the generation of fire. ... Dr G.B. Cone has spoken to an old Pakeha bushman who has used it in the Thames district where it was known as `punk' to the early settlers, who learned of its use from the Maoris. Punk burns very slowly and persistently. It can be put out only when smothered. ... Punk has now been recognised as the dried flesh of the <i>Polyporus hosularus<i> which may be found in many parts of the North Island.
Notes:

punnet
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:also called pottle, chip a small squarish container, such as is used to hold strawberries. a `strawberry box'; originally a small chip basket for holding (usually) berry fruit; chip; pottle

punui
Homonym Number: 1
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:2
Definition:lyallii, a plant most commonly growing in islands south of the New Zealand mainland.
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1891
Source: NZ Journal of Science
Author:
Vol / Page: 1/143
Edition:
Quote: The punui [on the Snares] is a strong growing herb, which resembles ... the punui of Stewart's island. <i>Ibid.</I> 1/163 The most striking herbaceous plant is ... the punui, <i>Aralia Lyallii</i> T. Kirk, var. <i>robusta</i>, the large orbicular leaves of which are sometimes two feet in diameter.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1884
Source: TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page: 17/293
Edition:
Quote: For the sake of conciseness, in the following paragraphs the native name<i> punui</i> will be restricted to the Stewart Island plant; the generic name <i>Stilbocarpa</i> to that from the Auckland Islands.
Notes: (Kirk)

Date: 0/0/1907

Author: LAING & BLACKWELL
Vol / Page: 317

Quote: <i>Stilbocarpa polaris (The Polar Stilbocarpa)</i> ... Auckland, Antipodes, Macquarie, and Campbell Islands. ... Maori name <i>Punui. </I>
Notes:

Author: WODZICKI
Vol / Page: 155
Edition:
Quote: Goats have also been placed...on small mutton bird islands in order to destroy punui <i>(Stilbocarpa lyallii)</i> and thus improve the islands as mutton bird grounds (R. Trail, <i>in litt.</i>, 1947)

Vol / Page: 240
Edition: 1929
Quote: The PUNUI (<i>Stilbocarpa</i>), an araliad with circular leaves measuring on occasion two feet across, ... occupies [the Auckland and Campbell Islands] as well as the coast of Stewart Island ... .

Date: 0/0/1982
Source: In the Grip of an Island
Author: SANSOM
Vol / Page: 69
Edition:
Quote: Herekopare and Woman's Island are the only two beneficiary muttonbird islands. All the rest are Crown lands. ... I know ... that the fierce nettle also grows on Herekopare. Other lovely ... plants are there too - the Stewart Island yellow senecio, teteaweka of course, ... Cook's health-giving scurvy grass, soft native tatahi grass and punui, the giant-leafed umbrella-like araliad.
Notes:

Date: 0/4/2008
Source: NZ Gardener
Author:
Vol / Page: 91
Edition:
Quote: While my punui (<i>Stilbocarpa lyallii</i>) is out of its comfort zone, it had grown well for three years since it arrived as a seed from Putauhinu, one of the most southern titi (muttonbird) islands. Back on the mainland, my punui was growing well under the cover of a sinuous brachyglottis - until the heat of our La Nina summer overwhelmed it.
Notes:

Author:
Vol / Page: 17
Edition:
Quote: The punui of the Auckland Islands, with leaves sometimes 12 in. broad, and purple-eyed flowers, and its near relation on Stewart Island, are important members of this family.

Citations
Date: 0/0/1952
Source: History of Northern Southland
Author: HAMILTON
Vol / Page: 44
Edition:
Quote: A machine under the charge of an inexperienced man would deliver sheaves that greatly varied in size .. some extra large, others, called pups by the stookers, extra small.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1981
Source: Loughnan Glossary
Author: LOUGHNAN
Vol / Page: 64
Edition:
Quote: pup: a miniature of the round, conical-topped sheaf-stack. Sheaves, sheaf-stacks, and stooks are all rarely seen now. What could not be included in the last full-sized stack to be built was made into a pup.
Notes:

Quote: [It was stated in the Marine Department Annual Report] that 12,116,000 borers and 10,660 pupus had been destroyed during the year. Mr. Broadfoot wanted to know how this total had been estimated. "Did you count them?" he asked Mr. Semple, "and having got them did you brand or earmark them?" "As a matter of fact, we leg-ironed them," remarked Mr. Semple with complete gravity.

pupuharakeke
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:[u]pu[u]-harakeke, Placostylus hongii., flax snail
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1947
Source: Native Animals of NZ
Author: POWELL
Vol / Page: 33
Edition:
Quote: PUPUHARAKEKE or FLAX SNAIL (<i>Placostylus hongii</i>). ... reddish-brown coloured snail about 3 inches in height. These snails are vegetarian and feed largely upon fallen karaka leaves. They are found hidden under leaves and around sedges, but only in flax when there is no other cover.
Notes:

Date: 0/5/1985
Source: Forest & Bird
Author:
Vol / Page: 10
Edition:
Quote: The flax snail, pupuharakeke, a species endemic to the Te Paki region.
Notes:

Date: 0/5/1985
Source: Forest & Bird
Author:
Vol / Page: 9
Edition:
Quote: Unuwhao has its own unique fauna. Best known are the large land snails: two sub-species of pupuharakeke (<i> Placostylus ambagiosus </i>) survive only there, along with pupurangi (<i> Paryphanta busbyi watti </i>).
Notes:

pupurangi
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:kauri snail one of a group of large carnivouous snails found only in New Zealand. [Maori pupurangi[u's-macron]]
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:

Citations
Date: 20/11/1850
Source: New Zealander, The
Author:
Vol / Page: 1
Edition:
Quote: FOR SALE At the Stores of the Undersigned, a few good specimens of the New Zealand Pupurangi Shell.
Notes:

Date: 7/10/1871
Source: Daily Southern Cross
Author:
Vol / Page: 2
Edition:
Quote: Sir, - I am informed that there exists in New Zealand a whistling snail, called by the Maoris a pupurangi. .. I am told this snail is a tree-climber, and that the natives procure them by posting themselves below the trees in which the pupurangi are located, and that on their whistling to them the snails fall to the ground, and are then greedily devoured by their captors, as their flavour is said to be curiously delicious.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1947
Source: Native Animals of NZ
Author: POWELL
Vol / Page: 32
Edition:
Quote: PUPURANGI or KAURI SNAIL (<i>Paryphanta busbyi</i>). A North Auckland representative of a group of large carnivorous snails found only in New Zealand. The shell is a flattened spiral of dark greenish colour, about 2 1/2 to 3 inches in diameter.
Notes:

Date: 0/9/1950
Source: NZ Journal of Agriculture
Author:
Vol / Page: 285/2
Edition:
Quote:
Notes:  (OEDS)

Date: 18/11/1871
Source: Daily Southern Cross
Author:
Vol / Page: 2
Edition:
Quote: For the benefit of the inquirer, I may state that the pupurangi of the Maoris is Helix busber, and the largest land-snail in New Zealand. I have three specimens, and am willing to sell one or two at the price of £1 5s. each, having refused £1 1s. repeatedly.
Notes:

Date: 0/6/1921

Author:
Vol / Page: 4/121
Edition:
Quote: CONGIOPODUS LEUCOPAECILUS (Richardson). <i>Pigfish; Puramorua.</i> Large numbers commonly sold throughout the year in Christchurch under the name of `silver trumpeter.' Rarely seen in Dunedin markets unless other fish are scarce. ... Distribution: South Island and southern coasts of North Island.
Notes: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes

puriri
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:formerly called New Zealand teak a large native hardwood tree growing in the North Island; the fruit forms in large clusters of red berries. [Maori puriri[u-macron]]

Vol / Page: No. 40

Quote:  	Herries Beattie describes a different method: "This tussock was placed in the paraerae (sandal) and the foot inserted. Then the tussock was brought up the leg and tied above the ankle. This protection was called puru and the sandals were then known as tupuru." Patiti was also regarded as "a fine thing to put in the paraerae to keep the feet warm and if one was wading it was warmer with patiti around the feet than without it."

purupuru
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a Maori marlinspike
Origin:Maori
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Williams purupuru 'caulking of a canoe'
Citations
Date: 11/6/1908
Source: Grey River Argus
Author:
Vol / Page: 3
Edition:
Quote: By the natives the spike was, Dr Newman explained, called an ahao or purupuru.
Notes:

Date: 10/6/1908
Source: Otago Witness
Author:
Vol / Page: 11
Edition:
Quote: [The Maori implement's] genuineness has been questioned, one sceptic asserting that it was neither more nor less than a British marlinspike; but the carving was of Native pattern, and the pointed portion, instead of being conical as is common in European, was also characteristically Maori in type ... The late Archdeacon Williams had told him it was called an ahao, and he found that another name was purupuru. Only recently, through the assistance of Mr. Percy Smith and the knowledge of some old-time Maoris at New Plymouth, had he found its purpose. It was really a marlinspike used for the caulking of sea-going canoes, and having a like end in view, the Maori had developed an implement almost exactly resembling that of the Europeans.
Notes:

Quote: Mention of the above term in 1890 reminds me of another side of Christchurch in those days - namely the gangs, or `pushes' as they were called - of larrikins. They wore bell-bottomed trousers, fancy shoes and well-oiled forelocks. These young ruffians frequently assaulted any lone pedestrian who happened to come their way.

Notes:

Date: 0/0/1898
Source: Austral English
Author: MORRIS
Vol / Page: 372
Edition:
Quote: <i>Push, n.</I>  gang. The word is of late, very common in Australia. It was once a prison term. Barrere and Leland quote from M. Davitt's `Leaves from a Prison Diary,' `the upper ten push.' In thieves' English it is (I) a crowd; (2) an association for a particular robbery. In Australia, its use began with the larrikins (q.v.), and spread, until now it often means clique, set, party, and even jocularly so far as `the Government House Push.' [1890]
Notes:

pussy's tit

Sense Number:

put (one) on the coat

Sense Number:

Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1982
Source: Big Huey, The
Author: NEWBOLD
Vol / Page: 66
Edition:
Quote: This is one of the reasons that informal social control mechanisms at Paremoremo are so strong. Anybody who deviates from the required standard of thought or behaviour - the criminal standard - is quickly observed and `put on the coat' by the rest of the community. At Paremoremo you have to learn quickly to conform to criminal norms or live the life of a pariah. <I>Ibid.</I> 130 A lot of my old mates ... disapproved totally of what was happening and put me on the coat. We remained on speaking terms, but it wasn't the same as it had been before. . <I>Ibid.</I> 246 Coat (n) Put on the Coat. Ostracise, excommunicate. In the sense of reprimand, British prison slang early in this century. <i>See also</i> JACKET.

Notes:

Date: 13/6/1908
Source: NZ Truth
Author:
Vol / Page: 156/6/1
Edition:
Quote: Walsh was abusing Mrs. Kerr, the landlady, when she said she would `put his pot on' with the police. The term is familiar, but is believed to have a highly respectable origin, `Put his pot on!' being the death warrant uttered by the chief when the early cannibals proposed having boiled missionary for dinner.

put (one's) weights up
Homonym Number:
Word Class:phrase
Sense Number:
Definition:to inform on, tell on, expose; get (one) into trouble
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: possibly from racing or bookmaking referring to the putting up or publishing the weights to be carried by horses so that punters can read the facts for themselves; or perhaps, from raising the handicap weights carried so making things more difficult both for the horse and for the bettor who fancies it: perhaps (though very unlikely) from a general analogy of tipping the balance, making the true weight (or, metaphorically, character) of somebody known, as one finds out a true weight literally when one `tips' old-fashioned scales by raising the weights and the thing to be weighed off the surface into a weighing position; ca1952 June Wellington I'll put his weights up with his cobbers tomorrow about his flirting.

Citations
Date: 0/0/1968
Source: Pagan Game, The
Author: SLATTER
Vol / Page: 163
Edition:
Quote: Got the pricker with me because I put his weights up -  A terrible stick man, that Tank - Woppit Upper -
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1986
Source: NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary
Author:
Vol / Page: 875
Edition:
Quote: <i>weight ... 3. put person's weights up NZ colloq.</i> inform on (someone).
Notes: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]

Date: 0/0/1988
Source: Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
Author: McGILL
Vol / Page: 121
Edition:
Quote: weights, phr. -->putting your weights up putting someone in trouble; possibly from weights carried in handicap horse races; eg `I'd watch Monk if I was you, he'd put your weights up with the cops soon as look at you.' Australian miners c.1925. ANZ.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/2001
Source: Dogside Story
Author: Grace
Vol / Page: 187
Edition:
Quote: ...they’d been given everything they needed from Maina, who, once she’d decided to put her husband’s weights up, had done it in a big way.
Notes:

Quote: <i>put across a beauty</i> make a smart or tricky move; eg `Sims put across a beauty with that double dummy.' c.1910. Mostly NZ.

Notes:

Date: 0/0/1980
Source: Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A
Author: LELAND
Vol / Page: 16
Edition:
Quote: <i>boot</i>: can be used for the things you hike in, and there is an expression `to put the boot in' which means metaphorically to kick someone, as `then he really put the boot in and sent him down the road' (fired him); or gave him the boot. How ever, the commonest use of boot refers to what you would call the TRUNK of your car.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1974
Source: Australian & NZ English [TS]
Author: SYDER & HODGETTS
Vol / Page: 90 [987]
Edition:
Quote: To aim a blow at the morale or the material position of him who is already at a loss. .in 4;`He's dropped the ball. The mug! Oh the useless bleedin' mug! They'd be better off without him.' `Well, he's not going too good today, but there's no need to stick in the boot. You didn't say that last Saturday when he went like a train.' -->to PUT THE BOOT IN means the same thing.
Notes: (1962-63) 1974 Syder and Hodgetts Aust and NZ English [TS] 90 [987]

Quote: PUTAKITAKI<i> (carsarca variegata),;a duck with beautiful plumage, rather larger than the common grey variety. It is very common in the south of New Zealand, and is generally known as the paradise duck. </i>

Date: 0/0/1906

Vol / Page: 137

Quote: <i>C[arpodetus] serratus, Forst. ... Piripiriwhata; Putaputawheta. </i>
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1907
Source: Plants of NZ
Author: LAING & BLACKWELL
Vol / Page: 188
Edition: 1940 p. 194
Quote: <i>Carpodetus serratus (The Serrate Carpodetus)</i>... The native name <i>Puta-puta-weta</i> signifies full of weta holes. In the North Island trees of this species are rarely cut down unperforated by longitudinal insect galleries. Another name by which it is known is <i>Puna-weta</i>. In the Urewera country it is called <i>Kai-weta</i> (i.e., weta food). [That ugly innocent the weta (<i>Deinacrida</i>) has thus been accused of perforating the tree; but as a matter of fact though often used as convenient residences [195] by the weta, the holes are made by the caterpillar of the large moth <i>Hepialus virescens</i>... ].
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1910
Source: NZ Plants
Author: COCKAYNE
Vol / Page: 37
Edition:
Quote: The putaputaweta (<i>Carpodetus serratus</i>) is a rival of the English may.
Notes:

putting on hobnailed boots
Homonym Number:
Word Class:phrase
Sense Number:
Definition:

Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1898
Source: Contributions to the Early History of New Zealand
Author: HOCKEN
Vol / Page: 181
Edition:
Quote: A fortnight before its sittings, Mr. Peter Proudfoot, Chief Commissioner of Lands, died, and the Superintendent appointed his own son-in-law, Mr. Cutten, to the vacant post, which was in the gift of the Executive and should have been filled by them. In his opening speech to the Council he justified this action, or rather rode roughshod over any objections to it. `Now,' he said, `I would have Mr. Cutten and all others to know that I am in no degree to be swayed from doing what I have a right to do - to put the right man into the right place - whether that man happens to be my son-in-law or any one else' - a mode of speech now known amongst politicians as `putting on hobnailed boots.'
Notes:
